[[Image:Starr 050415-0034 Acacia podalyriifolia.jpg|thumb|left|150px| ''Acacia podalpodalyriifolia'' seedpods – Photo by Forest & Kim Starr]]

'''''Acacia podalyriifolia''''' is a perennial tree which is fast-growing and widely cultivated.  It is native to Australia but is also naturalised in [[Malaysia]], Africa, [[India]] and South America.  Its uses include environmental management and it is also used as an [[ornamental tree]].  It is very closely related to ''[[Acacia uncifera]]''.  It grows to about {{convert|5|m|abbr=in}} in height and about the same in total width.<ref>[http://asgap.org.au/a-pod.html Association of Societies for Growing Australian Plants (ASGAP)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070612151138/http://asgap.org.au/a-pod.html |date=12 June 2007 }}</ref> It blooms during winter.

[[Image:Starr 020911-0001 Acacia podalyriifolia.jpg|thumb|left|150px|''Acacia podalyriifolia'' foliage]]
[[File:Acacia podalyriifolia MHNT.BOT.2009.13.19.jpg|thumb|left|150px|''Acacia podalyriifolia'' – [[MHNT]]]]

Common names for it are '''Mount Morgan wattle''' and '''Queensland silver wattle'''.<ref name="ILDIS"/>

'''''Acacia sassa''''' is a [[legume]] that grows in the forests of [[Senegal]].<ref>[http://www.biodiv.org/doc/programmes/cro-cut/gti/gti-needs-summary-en.pdf Convention on Biological Diversity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203230240/http://www.biodiv.org/doc/programmes/cro-cut/gti/gti-needs-summary-en.pdf |date=December 3, 2008 }}</ref> It was first described by [[Carl Ludwig von Willdenow]].  Smoke from certain parts of it is known to be [[psychoactive]].<ref>[http://www.deutschesfachbuch.de/info/detail.php?PHPSESSID=671b6aae5958d853f3f650eeed1bece7&isbn=3038003026 Book Index from Christian Rätsch Räucherstoffe - Der Atem des Drachens Presented at DeutschesFachbuch.de]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>

{{Italic title}}{{taxobox |name = Paperbark acacia |image = Kirstenbosch - Acacia sieberiana.jpg |image_caption = In Kirstenbosch, Cape Town |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fabales]] |familia = [[Fabaceae]] |genus = ''[[Acacia]]'' |species = '''''A. sieberiana''''' |binomial = ''Acacia sieberiana'' |binomial_authority = [[A. P. de Candolle|DC.]] |synonyms_ref = [http://www.ildis.org/LegumeWeb?version~10.01&LegumeWeb&tno~373&genus~Acacia&species~sieberiana ILDIS LegumeWeb] |synonyms = * ''Acacia abyssinica sensu auct.'' * ''Acacia amboensis'' [[Schinz]] * ''Acacia davyi sensu auct.'' * ''Acacia purpurascens'' [[Vatke]] * ''Acacia sieberiana'' subsp. ''vermoesenii'' ([[Émile Auguste Joseph De Wildeman|De Wild.]])[[Troupin]] * ''Acacia vermoesenii'' De Wild. |subdivision_ranks = varieties[http://www.ildis.org/LegumeWeb/6.00/fam/f2.shtml ILDIS List] |subdivision = *''Acacia sieberiana'' var. ''sieberiana'' (DC.) Kyal. & Boatwr. *''Acacia sieberiana'' var. ''villosa'' (A.Chev.) Kyal. & Boatwr. *''Acacia sieberiana'' var. ''woodii'' (Burtt Davy) Kyal. & Boatwr. |}} '''''Acacia sieberiana''''',{{cite web|title=Acacia sieberiana |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/ild-613 |website=The Plant List (2013). Version 1.1 |accessdate=5 November 2015}}{{cite web |last1=Hyde |first1=Mark |title=Acacia sieberiana DC. var. woodii (Burtt Davy) Keay & Brenan |url=http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/species.php?species_id=126200|website=Flora of Zimbabwe |accessdate=5 November 2015|display-authors=etal}}{{cite web |last1=Joffe |first1=Pitta |title=Acacia sieberiana DC. var. woodii (Burtt Davy) Keay & Brenan |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantab/acaiasieber.htm |website=PlantzAfrica |publisher=SANBI |accessdate=5 November 2015}} commonly known as the '''paperbark thorn''' or '''paperbark acacia''', is a tree native to [[Africa]] and introduced into [[Pakistan]]. It is used in many areas for various purposes. The tree varies from 3 to 25 m in height, with a trunk diameter of 0.6 to 1.8 m.[http://www.worldagroforestrycentre.org/SEA/Products/AFDbases/AF/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=113 World Agroforestry Centre] It is not listed as being a [[threatened species]]. == Uses == ''Acacia sieberiana'' is valued largely as a source of forage, medicine and wood. The inner bark is a source of fibre purposes such as stringing [[bead]]s). The gum is edible) and both [[livestock]] and [[game animal|game animals]] [[Browsing|browse]] the tree and feed on the dropped pods, spreading viable seeds in their dung. [[File:Img00522-A-sieberiana.jpg|thumb|right|Close-up of the leaves]] [[File:Acacia sieberiana, blomme, Pretoria, a.jpg|thumb|right|The creamy-white, spherical flower heads]] [[File:Kirstenbosch - Acacia sieberiana close-up of bark.jpg|thumb|right|A close-up of the papery bark that gives the tree its vernacular name]] The flowers of the tree make good forage for [[bee]]s and [[bee hive]]s are put directly in the trees to exploit the resource. The leaves of the tree commonly release toxic chemical compounds when the tree has been heavily browsed, some of the compounds may release [[hydrogen cyanide]] when ingested, which may be lethal to [[cattle]]. They fallen pods and foliage can provide lifesaving forage during dry times of the year. The gum of the tree is used as food, as an [[adhesive]], and as an ingredient in making [[ink]]. ===Traditional medicinal uses=== In [[Africa]], the bark or root is used to treat [[urinary tract]] [[inflammation]]. The bark has [[astringent]] properties and it is used to treat colds, [[cough]], and childhood [[fever]]. According to the World AgroForestry Centre,
"A [[decoction]] of the root is taken as remedy for stomach-ache. The bark, leaves and gums are used to treat [[tapeworm]], [[bilharzia]], [[haemorrhage]], [[orchitis]], colds, [[diarrhoea]], [[gonorrhoea]], [[kidney]] problems, [[syphilis]], [[ophthalmia]], [[rheumatism]] and disorders of the [[circulatory system]]. It is also used as an astringent. The pods serve as an emollient, and the roots for stomach-ache, [[acne]], tapeworms, [[urethra]]l problems, [[oedema]] and [[dropsy]]."
===Nitrogen fixation=== ''Acacia sieberiana'' is a [[legume]] and like many legumes it hosts [[Rhizobium]] [[bacteria]] in its roots. The bacteria [[nitrogen fixation|fix nitrogen]] gas from the air and without requiring nitrogen fertilizer or soil nitrates, they convert it into nitrogen compounds necessary for plant nutrition. Ultimately, surrounding plants also benefit from the increase in available nitrogen, which means that plants such as ''Acacia'' species are of particular ecological importance. ===Tannin=== [[Tannin]] is found in the bark and seed pods. ===Wood=== The wood is fairly hard and it is used for [[furniture]], handles for implements and [[tools]] for grinding grain manually. The wood of ''V. sieberiana'' has a density of about 655 kg/m³.[http://www.fao.org/docrep/V5360E/v5360e0f.htm FAO] ==Ecology and conservation== This tree is widespread in its natural habitat and is not threatened. It is browsed upon by livestock and game such as [[elephant]] and [[giraffe]]. == References == == External links == {{Commonscat|Acacia sieberiana|''Acacia sieberiana''}} {{WestAfricanPlants|Acacia sieberiana}} {{taxonbar}} [[Category:Acacia|sieberiana]] [[Category:Plants used in traditional African medicine]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]] [[Category:Forages]]
2.title: Acacia sieberiana

{{taxobox
|image = Baobab and elephant, Tanzania .jpg
|image_caption    = Baobab tree in [[Tanzania]]
|regnum           = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo    = [[Rosids]]
|ordo     = [[Malvales]]
|familia  = [[Malvaceae]]
|genus    = ''[[Adansonia]]''
|species  = '''''A. digitata'''''
|binomial = ''Adansonia digitata''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
|synonyms = *''Adansonia bahobab'' <small>L. </small> 
*''Adansonia baobab'' <small> Gaertn. </small>
*''Adansonia integrifolia'' <small> Raf. </small> 
*''Adansonia scutula '' <small>Steud. Syno</small>
*''Adansonia situla '' <small>(Lour.) Spreng. </small>
*''Adansonia somalensis '' <small>Chiov. </small>
*''Adansonia sphaerocarpa '' <small>A.Chev. </small>
*''Adansonia sulcata'' <small> A.Chev. </small> 
*''Baobabus digitata'' <small> (L.) Kuntze </small> 
*''Ophelus sitularius'' <small> Lour. </small><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-2621135|title=Adansonia digitata L.|work=The Plant List|accessdate=21 November 2015}}</ref>
}}
'''''Adansonia digitata''''' ('''baobab''') is the most widespread of the ''[[Adansonia]]'' species, and is native to the African continent. The long-lived [[pachycaul]]s are typically found in dry, hot [[savanna]]hs of [[sub-Saharan Africa]], where they dominate the landscape, and reveal the presence of a watercourse from afar.<ref name=wick/> Their growth rate is determined by ground water or rainfall,<ref name=hank/><ref name=red>{{cite journal|last1=Grové |first1= Naas |title=Redaksionele Kommentaar |journal=Dendron |date=November 2011 |issue=43 |page=14 |url=http://www.dendro.co.za/uploads/2/8/2/1/2821110/dendron-digital.pdf |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> and their maximum age, which is subject to much conjecture, seems to be in the order of 1,500 years.<ref name=wood>{{cite web |last1=Woodborne |first1=Stephan, Dr. |title=Dating Africa's giants reveals far more than just age |url=http://ntww1.csir.co.za/plsql/ptl0002/PTL0002_PGE013_MEDIA_REL?MEDIA_RELEASE_NO=7523503 |website=CSIR |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref> They have traditionally been valued as sources of food, water, health remedies or places of shelter and are steeped in legend and superstition.<ref name=hank>{{cite web |last1=Hankey |first1=Andrew |title=Adansonia digitata A L. | date= February 2004 |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantab/adansondigit.htm |website=plantzafrica |accessdate=28 November 2015}}</ref> Explorers of old were inclined to carve their names on baobabs, and many are defaced by modern graffiti.<ref name=wick/> Common names for the baobab include '''dead-rat tree''' (from the appearance of the fruit), '''monkey-bread tree''' (the soft, dry fruit is edible), '''upside-down tree''' (the sparse branches resemble roots) and '''cream of tartar tree''' ([[cream of tartar]]).

==Naming and description==
The vernacular name "baobab" is derived from [[Arabic]] بو حِباب (būħibāb), which means "father of many seeds". The scientific name ''Adansonia'' refers to the French explorer and [[botany|botanist]], [[Michel Adanson]] (1727–1806), who observed a specimen in 1749 on the island of [[Gorée|Sor]], [[Senegal]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baobab.com/tag/michel-adanson/ |title=Michel Adanson - Poudre Baobab bio - acheter poudre baobab bio |work=baobab.com |accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref> On the nearby [[Îles des Madeleines]] Adanson found another baobab, 3.8 m in diameter, which bore the carvings of passing mariners on its trunk, including those of [[Henry the Navigator]] in 1444 and [[André Thevet]] in 1555.<ref name=wick>{{cite book |last1=Wickens |first1=Gerald E. |last2=Lowe |first2=Pat |title=The baobabs pachycauls of Africa, Madagascar and Australia |date=2008 |publisher=Springer Science + Business Media, B.V |location=New York |isbn=9781402064319 |pages=31-}}</ref> When [[Théodore Monod]] searched the island in the 20th century, the tree was not to be found however. Adanson concluded that the baobab, of all the trees he studied, “is probably the most useful tree in all.” He consumed baobab juice twice a day, while in Africa. He remained convinced that it maintained his health for him.<ref name="powbab.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.powbab.com/pages/the-baobab-tree|title=The Baobab Tree |work=Powbab |accessdate=21 November 2015}}</ref> "Digitata" refers to the digits of the hand. The baobab's compound leaves with normally five (but up to seven) leaflets are akin to a hand.<ref name=dup>{{cite journal|last1=du Plessis |first1=Doep |title=Die Thabazimbi-bosveld se groot kremetart |journal=Dendron |date=November 2011 |issue=43 |page=11 |url=http://www.dendro.co.za/uploads/2/8/2/1/2821110/dendron-digital.pdf |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>

==Habit and physical description==
[[File:Adansonia digitata (Baobab Tree) in Hyderabad W IMG 8271.jpg|thumb|left|Each leaf comprises five leaflets]]
[[File:Adansonia digitata 0013.jpg|thumb|left|Open flower]]
[[File:Adansonia digitata MS 6682-2.JPG|thumb|left|Bisected flower]]
[[File:Baobab Frucht.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The fruit can be up to {{convert|25|cm|in|0}} long and is used to make a drink]]
The trees usually grow as solitary individuals, and are large and distinctive elements of [[savannah]] or [[scrubland]] vegetation. Some large individuals live to well over a thousand years of age.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Varmah |first= J. C. |last2= Vaid |first2= K. M. |title=  Baobab - the historic African tree at Allahbad |journal= Indian Forester |volume= 104 |issue= 7 |year= 1978 |pages= 461–464}}</ref> All baobab trees are [[deciduous]], losing their leaves in the dry season, and remains leafless for nine months of the year.

They can grow to between {{convert|5–25|m|abbr=on}} in height. They are in fact known both for their height and trunk's girth. The trunk tends to be bottle-shaped and can reach a diameter of {{convert|10–14|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="eol.org">{{cite web|url=http://eol.org/pages/584789/overview |title=Baobab (Adansonia digitata) - Information on Baobab - Encyclopedia of Life |work=Encyclopedia of Life|accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref> The span of the roots actually exceed the tree's height, a factor that enables it to survive in a dry climate. Many consider the tree to be “upside-down” due to the trunk likeness to a [[taproot]] and the branches akin to finer [[capillary]] roots. The trunk is smooth and shiny<ref name="krugerpark.co.za">{{cite web|url=http://www.krugerpark.co.za/africa_baobab.html |title=Boabab Tree - Southern African Trees - Adansonia digitata |work=krugerpark.co.za |accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref> and can range from being reddish brown to grey. The bark can feel cork-like.<ref name="powbab.com"/> The branches are thick and wide and very stout compared to the trunk.

During the early summer (October to December in southern hemisphere)<ref name=shee>{{cite book|last1=Sheehan |first1=Sean |title=Zimbabwe (Vol. 6 of Cultures of the World) |date=2004 |publisher=Benchmark Books/Marshall Cavendish |location=New York |isbn=9780761417064 |page=13 |edition=2nd}}</ref> the tree bears very large, heavy, white flowers. These are {{convert|12|cm|abbr=on}} across and open during the late afternoon to stay open for one night.<ref name=hank/><ref name="eol.org"/> The pendulous, showy flowers have a very large number of stamens. They have a sweet scent but later emit a [[carrion]] smell, especially when they turn brown and fall after 24 hours.<ref name=hank/><ref name="eol.org"/> Researchers have shown that they appear to be primarily pollinated by [[fruit bat]]s of the subfamily [[Pteropodinae]]. The flowers have 5 petals that are leathery and hairy on the inside. The [[sepals]] are cup-shaped and 5-cleft. The [[stamens]] are divided into multiple [[anthers]] and [[Style (botany)|styles]] are 7-10 rayed.

The [[indehiscent]] fruit are large, egg-shaped capsules.<ref name=hank/> They are filled with pulp that dries, hardens, and falls to pieces which look like chunks of powdery, dry bread.<ref>{{cite book |authorlink= |author=National Research Council |editor= |others= |title=Lost Crops of Africa: Volume III: Fruits |url=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=11879 |format= |accessdate=July 15, 2008 |edition= |series=Lost Crops of Africa |volume=3 |date=January 25, 2008 |publisher=[[National Academies Press]] |location= |isbn=978-0-309-10596-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter=Baobab |chapterurl=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=11879&page=41 |quote= |ref= }}</ref> The seed are hard, black and kidney-shaped.<ref name=hank/>

==Range==
[[File:Adansonia digitata 3 - African baobab.JPG|thumb|200px|Specimen in [[Epupa Falls|Epupa gorge]], Namibia-Angola border]]
[[File:Baobab Adansonia digitata.jpg|300px|thumbnail|200px|In full leaf at [[Bagamoyo]], [[Tanzania]]]]
[[File:Adansonia digitata - baobabs.JPG|300px|thumb|200px|Without leaves in [[Tarangire National Park]], Tanzania]]
The northern limit of its distribution in Africa is associated with rainfall patterns; only on the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] coast and in the [[Sudan]] does its occurrence venture naturally into the [[Sahel]]. On the Atlantic coast, this may be due to spreading after cultivation.  Its occurrence is very limited in [[Central Africa]], and it is found only in the very north of [[Southern Africa]]. In [[Eastern Africa]], the trees grow also in [[Scrubland|shrublands]] and on the coast.  In [[Angola]] and [[Namibia]], the baobabs grow in woodlands, and in coastal regions, in addition to savannahs. It is also found in [[Dhofar]] region of [[Oman]] and [[Yemen]] in the [[Arabian Peninsula]], [[Western Asia]]. This tree is also found in India, particularly in the dry regions of the country,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sec.org.in/jeevsampada/plantsindia/admin_dist.php?id=5694 |title=Adansonia digitata:Plant Database of India |accessdate=21 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826225647/http://sec.org.in/jeevsampada/plantsindia/admin_dist.php?id=5694|archivedate=26 August 2011}}</ref> and in [[Penang]], Malaysia, along certain streets.<ref>Simon Gardner, Pindar Sidisunthorn and Lai Ee May, 2011. ''Heritage Trees of Penang''. Penang: Areca Books. ISBN 978-967-57190-6-6</ref>

The baobab is native to most of Africa, especially in drier, less tropical climates. It is not found in areas where sand is deep. It is sensitive to water logging and frost.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eol.org/pages/584789/details|title=Descriptions and articles about the Baobab (Adansonia digitata) - Encyclopedia of Life|work=Encyclopedia of Life|accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref> More specifically: [[Mauritania]], [[Senegal]], [[Guinea]], [[Sierra Leone]], [[Mali]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Ghana]], [[Togo]], [[Benin]], [[Niger]], [[Nigeria]], n-[[Cameroon]], [[Chad]], [[Sudan]], [[Republic of the Congo|Congo]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|DR Congo]] (Zaire), [[Eritrea]], [[Ethiopia]], s-[[Somalia]], [[Kenya]], [[Tanzania]], [[Zambia]], [[Zimbabwe]], [[Malawi]], [[Mozambique]], [[Angola]], [[Sao Tome]], [[Príncipe]] isl., [[Annobón Province|Annobon]] isl., [[Java]] (introduced), [[Nepal]] (introduced), [[Sri Lanka]] (introduced), [[Philippines]] (introduced), [[Jamaica]] (introduced), [[South Africa]] (Transvaal), [[Namibia]], [[Botswana]], [[Puerto Rico]] (introduced), [[Haiti]] (introduced), [[Dominican Republic]] (introduced), [[Venezuela]] (introduced), [[Seychelles]] (introduced), [[Madagascar]] (introduced), [[Comores]] (introduced), [[India]] (introduced), sw-[[Yemen]], [[Oman]] (Dhofar), [[China]] (introduced), [[Guangdong]] (introduced), [[Fujian]] (introduced), [[Yunnan]] (introduced).<ref name="catalogueoflife.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.catalogueoflife.org/col/details/species/id/21510518 |title=Catalogue of Life - 18th May 2015 :: Species details |work=catalogueoflife.org |accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref>

==Food uses and nutrition==
The baobab is a traditional food plant in Africa, but is little-known elsewhere. The vegetable has been suggested to have the potential to improve nutrition, boost food security, foster rural development, and support sustainable land care.<ref>{{cite book |authorlink= |author=National Research Council |editor= |others= |title=Lost Crops of Africa: Volume II: Vegetables |url=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=11763 |format= |accessdate=July 15, 2008 |edition= |series=Lost Crops of Africa |volume=2 |date=October 27, 2006 |publisher=[[National Academies Press]] |location= |isbn=978-0-309-10333-6 |oclc= |doi= |id= |pages= |chapter=Baobab |chapterurl=http://books.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=11763&page=75 |quote= |ref= }}</ref>

The African baobab's fruit is {{convert|15-20|cm|in|abbr=on|0}} long. It contains 50% more [[calcium]] than spinach, is high in [[antioxidants]], and has three times the [[vitamin C]] of an orange.<ref name=Soares>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/the-tree-of-life-and-its-super-fruit-869737.html|title=The tree of life (and its super fruit)|work=The Independent|accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=July 2015}}  The dry pulp is either eaten fresh or dissolved in milk or water to make a drink. The leaves can be eaten as [[relish]]. Young fresh leaves are cooked in a sauce and sometimes are dried and powdered. The powder is called lalo in [[Mali]] and sold in many village markets in Western Africa. Oil extracted by pounding the seeds can be used for cooking but this is not widespread.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sidibe |first=M. |last2=Williams|first2=J. T.|title=Baobab - Adansonia digitata|year=2002|publisher=International Centre for Underutilised Crops |location=Southampton, UK |isbn=0854327762 |url=http://www.cropsforthefuture.org/publication/Monographs/Baobab%20Monograph.pdf}}</ref> In Sudan — where the tree is called ''tebeldi'' — people make ''tabaldi'' juice by soaking and dissolving the dry pulp of the fruit, locally known as ''gunguleiz''.<ref name="fruitco">{{cite web |url=http://www.baobabfruitcompany.eu/themen/literatur/art/010.pdf |title=Baobab (Adansonia digitata L.): a Review on a Multipurpose Tree with Promising Future in the Sudan |date=April 2002 |publisher=Gartenbauwissenschaft}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10722-013-9964-5 |title=A note on baobab (Adansonia digitata L.) in Kordofan, Sudan |work=springer.com |accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref>

In 2008, the [[European Union]] approved the use and consumption of baobab fruit as an ingredient in [[smoothie]]s and [[cereal bar]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.acnfp.gov.uk/assess/fullapplics/baobab |publisher=Advisory Committee on Novel Foods and Processes |title=Baobab dried fruit pulp |year=2008 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20080603122942/http://www.acnfp.gov.uk/assess/fullapplics/baobab |archivedate=2008-06-03}}</ref> The [[Food and Drug Administration (United States)|United States Food and Drug Administration]] granted [[generally recognized as safe]] status to baobab dried fruit pulp as a food ingredient in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fda.gov/Food/FoodIngredientsPackaging/GenerallyRecognizedasSafeGRAS/GRASListings/ucm174945.htm |publisher=[[Food and Drug Administration (United States)|FDA]] |title=Agency Response Letter GRAS Notice No. GRN 000273 |date=July 25, 2009 |author=Laura M. Tarantino}}</ref>

Baobab leaves are sometimes used as forage for ruminants in dry season. The oilmeal, which is a byproduct of oil extraction, can also be used as animal feed.<ref name='feedipedia'>{{cite web | last=Heuzé |first=V. |last2=Tran |first2=G. |last3=Bastianelli |first3=D. |last4=Archimède |first4=H. | title = African baobab (''Adansonia digitata'') | url = http://www.feedipedia.org/node/525 | publisher = Feedipedia.org. A programme by [[INRA (France)|INRA]], [[CIRAD]], AFZ and [[FAO]] | date = January 25, 2013 | accessdate = February 6, 2013}}</ref> In times of drought elephants consume the juicy wood below its bark.<ref name=shee/>

<!--==Wood, bark and growth==
The stem is covered with a bark layer some 5 to 10 cm thick and greyish brown. It is generally smooth but develops creases from years of growth.<ref name=hank/> The fiber of the bark can be used to make cloth.<ref name=shee/> -->==Variation and dispersal==
In Africa, the different populations of baobabs have revealed significant genetic differences. It has consequently been suggested that the taxon contains more than one species. The shape of their fruit especially, varies considerably from region to region.<ref name=braam>{{cite journal |last1=van Wyk |first1=Braam, Prof. |title=Kommentaar oor die groot kremetart van Gannahoek |journal=Dendron |date=November 2011 |issue=43 |page=14 |url=http://www.dendro.co.za/uploads/2/8/2/1/2821110/dendron-digital.pdf |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>

Baobab seed withstand drying and remain viable over long periods, as it has a hard seed coat. It can potentially be dispersed over long distances, and its germination potential is improved when it has passed through the digestive tract of an animal. Animals like [[African bush elephant|elephants]], [[black rhino]]s and [[Taurotragus|eland]] can potentially convey the seeds over long distances. [[Baboons]] likewise spread the seeds in their dung, but over shorter distances.<ref name=braam/>

Pollination in the baobab is achieved primarily by [[fruit bat]]s, but [[Galago|bush babies]] and several kinds of insect also assist. Some aspects of the baobab's reproductive biology are not yet understood. It is still speculated whether fertile baobab seeds can result from pollination by the tree's own pollen. It would appear as if pollen from another tree is required for fertile seed, as isolated trees do form seed, only to abort them at a late stage. The existence of some very isolated trees, may then be due to their [[Self-incompatibility in plants|self-incompatibility]] and inability to reproduce.<ref name=braam/>

Arab traders introduced it to northwestern [[Madagascar]]. There they were often planted at the center of villages, and sometimes outlived them.<ref name=wick/>

==Legends and myths==
[[File:The large baobab tree in Rudewa,Kilosa,Morogoro,Tanzania.jpg|thumb|left|A large baobab tree in Rudewa, Kilosa, Morogoro, Tanzania]]
[[File:A group of baobab trees in the Mikumi National Park, Tanzania.jpg|thumb|left|A group of baobab trees in the Mikumi National Park, Tanzania]]
Along the [[Zambezi]], the tribes believe that baobabs were upright and too proud. The gods became angry and uprooted them and threw them back into the ground upside-down. Evil spirits now cause bad luck to anyone that picks up the sweet white flowers. More specifically, a lion will kill them.<ref name="krugerpark.co.za"/>

In contrast, some people {{by whom|date=January 2017}} think that if one drinks from water in which baobab seeds have soaked, you will be safe from crocodile attacks.

In [[Zambia]], one baobab is said to be haunted by a ghostly [[Pythonidae|python]]. A long time ago, the python lived in the hollow trunk and was worshipped by the natives. A white hunter shot him down, and led to bad consequences. Some nights, the natives still hear the hissing of the snake.<ref name="krugerpark.co.za"/>

In [[Kafue National Park]], one of the largest baobabs is known as “Kondanamwali” or the “tree that eats maidens.” The tree fell in love with four beautiful maidens. When they reached puberty, they made the tree jealous by finding husbands. So, one night, during a thunderstorm, the tree opened its trunk and took the maidens inside.  Interestingly enough, a rest house has been built in the branches of the tree. On stormy nights, the crying of the imprisoned maidens can still be heard.<ref name="krugerpark.co.za"/>

Along the [[Limpopo River]], it is thought that when a young boy is bathed in the water used to soak baobab bark, he will grow up into a big man.<ref name="krugerpark.co.za"/>

Some people believe that women living in [[kraal]]s where baobabs are plenty will have more children. This is scientifically plausible as those women will have better access to the tree's vitamin-rich leaves and fruits to compliment a vitamin-deficient diet.<ref name="krugerpark.co.za"/>

The African bushman legend states that Thora, the god, took a dislike to the baobab growing in his garden. Therefore, he threw it over the wall of Paradise onto the Earth below. The tree landed upside down and continued to grow.<ref name="krugerpark.co.za"/>

==Conservation status and threats== 
As of April 2015 baobabs are not yet classified by the [[IUCN]]'s Red List criteria, but they are a part of the “Catalogue of Life.”<ref name="catalogueoflife.org"/> The species is [[extant taxon|extant]] over a wide range.<ref name="eol.org"/> The baobab is a protected tree in [[South Africa]].<ref name="dwaf">{{cite web |url=http://www2.dwaf.gov.za/dwaf/cmsdocs/4116___poster%20protected%20trees.pdf |title=Protected Trees |date=3 May 2013 |publisher=Department of Water Affairs and Forestry, Republic of South Africa}}</ref> In the [[Sahel]], the effects of drought, [[desertification]] and over-use of the fruit have been cited as causes for concern.<ref name=osman>{{cite web |last1=Osman |first1=Siham M. |title=Save the Baobab |url=http://practicalaction.org/baobab |website=practicalaction.org |publisher=ITDG Practical Action Sudan | date = 2014 |accessdate=6 December 2015}}</ref>

== Prominent specimens ==
{{GeoGroupTemplate}}
[[image:Slave Cemetry - Salaga.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Baobab at the slave cemetery, [[Salaga]]. The white calico cloth indicates its spiritual significance.]]
A number of individual baobab trees attract sightseers due to either their age, size, specific history or isolated occurrence.

Around [[Gweta]], Botswana, some have been declared national monuments. Green's Baobab, 27 km south of Gweta was inscribed by the 19th-century hunters and traders [[Frederick Thomas Green]] and Hendrik Matthys van Zyl besides other ruthless characters. About 11 km south of Green's Baobab is the turn-off to the multi-stemmed Chapman's Baobab, also known as Seven Sisters, or Xaugam.<ref group = note>i.e. Lion's tail in [[Tshwa language|Tsoa]]</ref> It was named for [[James Chapman (explorer)|Chapman]], but is also taken to be a camping site of [[David Livingstone|Livingstone]] and [[Frederick Selous|Selous]]. It had a circumference of 25 m before its constituent trunks collapsed outward in 2016. It is not confirmed dead, however.<ref name="afrgeo">{{cite web |title=Chapman’s Baobab – one of Africa’s largest trees – falls |url=http://africageographic.com/blog/chapmans-baobob-one-of-africas-largest-trees-falls/ |website=africageographic.com | date = 14 January 2016 |publisher=Africa Geographic |accessdate=12 April 2016}}</ref> The tree was historically used as a navigation beacon and as a post office by passing explorers, traders and travellers, many of whom left inscriptions on its trunk.

Baines' Baobabs grow on a tiny islet in Kudiakam Pan, Botswana. The seven trees are named for [[Thomas Baines]] who painted them in May 1862.<!--in Royal Geographical Society archives--> The fallen giant of Baines' day is still sprouting leaves (as of 2004), and a younger generation of trees are in evidence. The islet is accessible in winter when the pan is dry.<ref name="wats">{{cite book |last1=Watson |first1=Rupert |title=The African baobab |date=2007 |publisher=Struik |location=Cape Town |isbn=9781770074309 |pages=190–191}}</ref>

The Ombalantu baobab in Namibia has a hollow trunk that can accommodate some 35 people. At times it has served as a chapel, post office, house, and a hiding site. Some large specimens have been transplanted to new sites, as was the one at Cresta Mowana lodge in [[Kasane]].<ref name=ash>{{cite web |last1=Ashby |first1=Alison |title=The baobab’s secret |date= 26 June 2013 |url=http://www.zambezitraveller.com/chobe/history/baobab%E2%80%99s-secret |website=zambezitraveller.com |accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref>

At Saakpuli (also Sakpele) in northern [[Ghana]] the site of a 19th-century slave transit camp is marked by a stand of large baobabs, to which slaves were chained.<ref name="bri">{{cite book|last1=Briggs|first1=Philip|title=Ghana: the Bradt travel guide|date=2014|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|location=Chalfont St. Peter, Bucks |isbn=9781841624785 |page=427 |edition=6}}</ref> The chains were wrapped around their trunks or around the roots. Similarly, two trees at [[Salaga]] in central Ghana are reminders of the slave trade. One, located at the former slave market at the center of town, was replanted at the site of the original to which slaves were shackled. A second larger tree marks the slave cemetery, where bodies of dead slaves were dumped.

{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
| name = ''Afrocarpus dawei''
| status = NT
| status_system = iucn3.1
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| divisio = [[Pinophyta]]
| classis = [[Pinophyta|Pinopsida]]
| ordo = [[Pinales]]
| familia = [[Podocarpaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Afrocarpus]]''
| species = '''''A. dawei'''''
| binomial = ''Afrocarpus dawei''
| binomial_authority = ([[Otto Stapf|Stapf]]) [[Christopher Nigel Page|C.N.Page]]
}}
'''''Afrocarpus dawei''''' is a species of [[pinophyta|conifer]] in the family [[Podocarpaceae]]. It is native to Africa, where it occurs in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Tanzania]], and [[Uganda]].<ref name=iucn>Farjon, A. 2013. [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/42437/0 ''Afrocarpus dawei''.] The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.3. Downloaded on 11 April 2015.</ref>

This species is a [[tree]] that grows in swampy forest habitat that is flooded in the rainy season. It is associated with ''[[Baikiaea minor]]'' and ''[[Mimusops]]'' species.<ref name=iucn/>

This tree is valuable as timber because it grows a long trunk without many branches. It is likely overharvested, one reason that it is considered to be a [[near-threatened species]].<ref name=iucn/>

5.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
| image = Starr 061224-2830 Podocarpus sp..jpg
| status = LC
| status_system = iucn3.1
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| divisio = [[Pinophyta]]
| classis = [[Pinophyta|Pinopsida]]
| ordo = [[Pinales]]
| familia = [[Podocarpaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Afrocarpus]]''
| species = '''''A. gracilior'''''
| binomial = ''Afrocarpus gracilior''
| binomial_authority = ([[Robert Knud Friedrich Pilger|Pilg.]]) [[Christopher Nigel Page|C.N.Page]]
}}

[[File:Starr 061224-2869 Podocarpus sp..jpg|thumb|left|''Afrocarpus gracilior'' cone and foliage.]]

'''''Afrocarpus gracilior''''' (syn. ''Podocarpus gracilior'') is a species of [[pinophyta|coniferous]] [[tree]] in the family [[Podocarpaceae]] known commonly as the '''East African yellowwood'''.<ref name=iucn>Farjon, A. 2013. [http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/42439/0 ''Afrocarpus gracilior''.] The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.3. Downloaded on 11 April 2015.</ref> 

It is native to eastern [[Africa]], in [[Ethiopia]], [[Kenya]], [[Tanzania]], and [[Uganda]], in [[Afromontane]] habitats.<ref name=iucn/> 

This is a common species found in many types of tropical mountain forest habitat. It is a dominant species in some areas. Nevertheless, it may be in slow decline due to [[deforestation]] and [[logging]].<ref name=iucn/>

==Description==
''Afrocarpus gracilior'' is a medium-sized tree, growing 20–40 m tall, rarely to 50 m, with a trunk diameter of 50–80 cm. The [[leaf|leaves]] are spirally arranged, lanceolate, 2–6 cm long and 3–5 mm broad on mature trees, larger, to {{convert|10|cm|0|abbr=on}} long and 6 mm broad on vigorous young trees. 

The [[conifer cone|seed cones]] are highly modified, with a single {{convert|2|cm|0|abbr=on}} diameter seed with a thin fleshy coating borne on a short peduncle. The mature seed is purple, and is dispersed by [[bird]]s and [[monkey]]s which eat the fleshy coating. The [[pollen]] cones are solitary or in clusters of two or three on a short stem.<ref name=gd>[http://www.conifers.org/po/Afrocarpus_gracilior.php ''Afrocarpus gracilior''.] The Gymnosperm Database.</ref>

==Uses==
It is an important [[timber]] tree in its native range, where it is harvested for local use and export. It is used for construction of buildings and furniture. It is grown in [[plantation]]s elsewhere in the world. 

It is cultivated as an [[ornamental tree]], and planted as a shade tree.<ref name=iucn/>

==Notes==

9.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Albizia adiantifolia 12102003 Afrique du sud.JPG
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Albizia]]''
|species = '''''A. adianthifolia'''''
|binomial = ''Albizia adianthifolia''
|binomial_authority = (Schumach.) W.F.Wight
|}}

'''''Albizia adianthifolia''''' is a tree in the [[Fabaceae]] family. It is commonly known as the '''Flat-crown'''. Its range extends from eastern [[South Africa]] to [[Tropical Africa]]. 

==Description==
This is a large deciduous tree with a spreading, flat crown, growing to a height of {{convert|25|m|ft}}.<ref>Pooley, E. (1993). ''The Complete Field Guide to Trees of Natal, Zululand and Transkei''. ISBN 0-620-17697-0.</ref> A profusion of bright green leaves and heavily scented, fluffy flowers are produced in winter or spring.<ref>Purves, M. (2010)</ref> The leaves are twice compound with the leaflets being 2-5 x 8 mm in size.<ref>Pooley, E. (1993). ''The Complete Field Guide to Trees of Natal, Zululand and Transkei''. ISBN 0-620-17697-0.</ref> This tree favours sandy soils in warm, high rainfall areas. In South Africa it is found in [[KwaZulu-Natal Coastal Lowland Forest|coastal lowland forests]].<ref>Pooley, E. (1993). ''The Complete Field Guide to Trees of Natal, Zululand and Transkei''. ISBN 0-620-17697-0.</ref> 

==Cultivation==
''Albizia adianthifolia'' is cultivated as an [[ornamental tree]]. The attractive habit of these trees makes them a popular garden tree, often being retained as a [[native plant]] in suburban gardens when other [[indigenous (ecology)|indigenous]] vegetation is removed.<ref>Purves, M. (2010)</ref> The trees usually produce abundant seeds which are easily grown in sandy soil.<ref>Purves, M. (2010)</ref> 

==Ecological Significance==
[[African Elephant|Elephant]]s browse the leaves of these trees and [[Blue Duiker]] favour the leaves and seedpods as food.<ref>Pooley, E. (1993). ''The Complete Field Guide to Trees of Natal, Zululand and Transkei''. ISBN 0-620-17697-0.</ref> The larvae of the Satyr Charaxes butterfly (''[[Charaxes ethalion]]'') feed on the leaves of these trees.<ref>Williams, M. (1994). ''Butterflies of Southern Africa: A Field Guide''. ISBN 1-86812-516-5.</ref>

==See also==
*[[Southern African Sand Forest]]

{{commonscat|Albizia adiantifolia|'''''Albizia adiantifolia'''''}}

{{taxobox
|image =File:Albizia amara(Roxb.)Bolvin..jpg

|species = '''''A. amara'''''
|binomial = ''Albizia amara''
|binomial_authority = (Roxb.) Boiv.
|synonyms =
    {{Plainlist | style = margin-left: 1em; text-indent: -1em; |
*''Acacia wightii '' <small>Wight & Arn</small>
*''Mimosa amara'' <small>Roxb.</small>
*''Mimosa pulchella'' <small>Roxb.</small>
*''Acacia nellyrenza'' <small>Wight & Arn.</small>
*''Acacia amara'' <small>Willd.</small>
    }}
|synonyms_ref = <ref>{{cite web | url=http://indiabiodiversity.org/species/show/245368/?max=8&offset=0&classification=265799&taxon=116733&view=grid | title=Albizia amara (Roxb.)B.Boivin | accessdate=18 November 2015}}</ref>
|}}

'''''Albizia amara''''' is a tree in the [[Fabaceae]] family. Its range includes southern and Eastern Africa, from South Africa to Sudan and Ethiopia. It is also found in India and Sri Lanka.<ref name="worldagroforestry.org">"Orwa C, A Mutua, Kindt R , Jamnadass R, S Anthony. ''2009 Agroforestree Database: a tree reference and selection guide version 4.0'' (http://www.worldagroforestry.org/sites/treedbs/treedatabases.asp). Accessed 18 July 2014 [http://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/AFTPDFS/Albizia_amara.pdf]</ref>

==Description==

Albizia amara is a mid-sized, deciduous tree which resembles [[acacia]] (sans the thorns).<ref name=tod>{{cite book|last1=Krishen|first1=Pradip|title=Trees of Delhi: A Field Guide|date=2006|publisher=Penguin Books India|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=vw9IDLLkWtEC&pg=PA348&dq=albizia+amara&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=albizia%20amara&f=false}}</ref> The bark of the tree is grey in color and is grainy and scaly.<ref name=tod/> The leaves consist of up to 15 pairs of side stalks and the leaflets are tiny and can consist of about 15-35 pairs.<ref name=tod/> The flowers are whitish-yellow powder puffs with long stamens and golden pollen.<ref name=tod/> The pods are flat and are about 20 cm long.<ref name=tod/> The leaves thin out during February–March and are renewed in April.<ref name=tod/> The flowers are present throughout May and the fruits ripen during October and November.<ref name=tod/> It is a host plant for ''[[Achaea janata]]''.<ref name=fe>{{cite book|last1=Sen-Sarma|first1=P. K.|title=Forest Entomology|date=2012|publisher=APH Publishing|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=I2JnsZGGYrYC&pg=PA2&dq=albizia+amara&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=albizia%20amara&f=false}}</ref>

==Ecology==
''A. amara'' is intolerant of shade, and resistant to drought. In Africa it grows mainly in sandy woodlands.<ref name="worldagroforestry.org"/>

''A. amara'' and ''[[Hardwickia binata]]'' are the dominant canopy trees in the [[Central Deccan Plateau Dry Deciduous Forests]] ecoregion of India.<ref>Wikramanayake, Eric; Eric Dinerstein; Colby J. Loucks; et al. (2002). ''Terrestrial Ecoregions of the Indo-Pacific: a Conservation Assessment.'' Island Press; [[Washington, DC]]. pp. 324-326</ref> It is also found in the Anamalai, Palani and Cardamom hills of Western Ghats and the Godavari area, the Javadi Hills of Eastern Ghats in South India.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mani|first1=M.S|title=Ecology and Biogeography in India|date=December 2012|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=FvvtCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA726&dq=albizia+amara&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=albizia%20amara&f=false|accessdate=24 October 2015}}</ref>

==Uses==

The leaves and flowers are used for treatment of boils and ulcers. The leaf is also used for treatment of [[erysipelas]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Khare|first1=C.P.|title=Indian Medicinal Plants: An Illustrated Dictionary|date=22 April 2008|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|pages=29,30|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=gMwLwbUwtfkC&pg=PA29&dq=%22albizia+amara%22&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22albizia%20amara%22&f=false}}</ref>

Its wood is used for construction and furniture, and as a firewood. ''Albizia amara'' provides many environmental services: control of soil erosion, wind break, shade provider... It is also an ornamental tree in urban areas. Ruminants can feed its leaves.<ref>Heuzé V., Thiollet H., Tran G., Lebas F., 2016. Albizia (Albizia amara). Feedipedia, a programme by INRA, CIRAD, AFZ and FAO. http://www.feedipedia.org/node/337</ref>

==Gallery==

[[File:Albizia amara HS 4412.jpg|thumb|''Albizia amara'' with flowers and pods]]

16.text:
{{Italic title}}{{Speciesbox
<!--| name               = Flat Flowered Aloe -->
| taxon       = Aloe marlothii
| image       = Aloe marlothii subsp marlothii, habitus, Melmoth.jpg
| authority   = [[Alwin Berger]]
}}
'''''Aloe marlothii''''' (also known as the '''mountain aloe''' or the '''flat-flowered aloe''') is a large, single-stemmed Southern African [[aloe]] of rocky places and open flat country, occasionally growing up to 6m tall. 

==Description==
[[File:Aloe Marlothii,Huntington Desert Garden.jpg|thumb|left|''Aloe Marlothii'' in flower, showing the uniquely horizontal racemes of the [[inflorescence]].]] 
[[File:Aloe marlothii - Mountain Aloe - South Africa 2.JPG|thumb|left|Like many Aloe species, ''Aloe marlothii'' is more spiny when it is small and vulnerable to grazing.]]
Named after [[Rudolf Marloth]], a South African botanist, this species of aloe has an especially large robust head of stiff, grey-green leaves. These leaves can be up to 1.5m in length and usually densely covered in short spines on the convex lower surfaces and less so on the concave upper surfaces. Like many other [[arborescent]] aloe species, this Aloe is more spiny when it is small and as it becomes taller and less vulnerable to grazing, it loses many of the spines from its leaf surfaces. It normally has a trunk densely covered by the withered old leaves. 

The [[inflorescence]] is a much-branched panicle with up to 30 or exceptionally 50 racemes. Flower colour varies a great deal, and ranges from yellow through orange (most common) to bright red. Flowering takes place through the winter months, as is the case with most aloes. 

The distinctively horizontal branches of its [[inflorescence]] is an easy way to distinguish this species from other aloes. For this reason it is sometimes known as the '''flat-flowered aloe'''. (However, the type known as ''Aloe spectabilis'', has taller, less horizontal inforescences.) The densely packed flowers all tend to point upwards from the [[raceme]].<ref>http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantab/aloemarloth.htm</ref>

When not in flower, it is easily confused with the closely related [[Aloe excelsa|Zimbabwe Aloe]], and with the similar-looking [[Aloe ferox|Cape Aloe]] and [[Aloe africana|African Aloe]] species to the south.<ref>http://davesgarden.com/guides/articles/view/212/</ref>

==Distribution==
Its distribution ranges from the Klip River Hills in [[Johannesburg]], through eastern [[Botswana]], northwards over the [[Soutpansberg]] to [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Malawi]] and eastwards through [[Swaziland]] and [[Mozambique]] to the coast. Within this range, it is especially common in mountainous areas, which led it to be known as the '''mountain aloe'''. 

This species grades through intermediate forms into ''Aloe spectabilis'' [[G.W. Reynolds|Reynolds]] of [[KwaZulu-Natal]], and the two are now considered synonymous. ''Aloe marlothii'' forms natural hybrids with some 30 or more species.{{citation needed|reason=WCSP considers them distinct species|date=July 2014}}


{{commons category|Aloe marlothii}}

==See also==
*[[List of Southern African indigenous trees]]

==References==
{{Reflist}} 
*''The Aloes of South Africa'' - [[Gilbert Westacott Reynolds]] (AA Balkema, Cape Town 1969)
*''South African Aloes'' - [[Barbara Jeppe]] (Purnell, Cape Town 1969)
*''Guide to the Aloes of South Africa'' - Ben-Erik van Wyk & Gideon Smith (Briza, Pretoria 1996) ISBN 1-875093-04-4
==External links==
*{{EOL}}
* Nectar-feeding by southern African birds, with special reference to the Mountain Aloe ''Aloe marlothii'' - [http://oo.adu.org.za/content.php?id=116 Paper in ejournal Ornithological Observations]

|binomial_authority = [[Émile Auguste Joseph De Wildeman|De Wild.]]
}}

'''''Alstonia boonei''''' is a very large, [[deciduous]], tropical-forest tree belonging to the dogbane family, [[Apocynaceae]]. It is native to tropical [[West Africa]], with a range extending into [[Ethiopia]] and [[Tanzania]]. Its common name in the English [[timber trade]] is ''cheese wood'', ''pattern wood'' or ''stool wood'' (see [[Ashanti Empire]] [[golden stool]]) while its common  name in the French timber trade is "emien" (derived from the vernacular of the [[Ivory Coast]]).

The wood is fine-grained, lending itself to detailed carving; the tree also finds many uses in [[folk medicine]].{{cn|date=February 2016}} Like many other members of the Apocynaceae (a family rich in toxic and medicinal species), ''A. boonei'' contains [[alkaloid]]s and yields [[latex]].<ref>Burkhill H.M. ''The Useful Plants of Tropical West Africa'' (second edition) vol.1 (Families A-D) pp. 138–140 pub. Royal Botanic Gardens Kew 1985 ISBN 0 947643 01 X</ref>

== Description ==
''Alstonia boonei'' is a tall forest tree, which can reach {{convert|45|m}} in height and {{convert|3|m|abbr=on}} in girth, the [[Bole (botany)|bole]] being cylindrical and up to {{convert|27|m|abbr=on}} in height with high, narrow, deep-fluted buttresses. The leaves are borne in whorls at the nodes, the [[leaf shape]] is oblanceolate, with the apex rounded to [[acuminate]] and the lateral veins (see [[Leaf#Venation]]) prominent and almost at right angles to the [[midrib]]. The flowers are yellowish-white and borne in lax terminal [[cyme (botany)|cymes]]. The fruits are pendulous, paired, slender [[Follicle (fruit)|follicles]] up to {{convert|16|cm}} long, containing seeds bearing a tuft of silky, brown floss at either end to allow [[anemochory|dispersal by the wind]]. The latex is white and abundant.

18.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Lebombo ironwood
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Malpighiales]]
|familia = [[Picrodendraceae]]
|tribus = [[Picrodendreae]]
|subtribus = [[Mischodontinae]]
|genus = '''''Androstachys'''''
|genus_authority = [[Prain]]
|species = '''''A. johnsonii'''''
|binomial = ''Androstachys johnsonii''
|binomial_authority = [[Prain]]
|}}
'''''Androstachys johnsonii''''', the '''Lebombo ironwood''', is a medium-sized [[Afrotropical ecozone|Afrotropical]] tree species, and the sole member of the [[genus]] '''''Androstachys''''' in the [[Picrodendraceae]]. It is slow-growing, evergreen to deciduous,<ref name="prota"/> and [[dioecious]], with flowers that are wind-pollinated. It is native to southeastern [[Africa]] and [[Madagascar]], where it generally occurs gregariously on rocky hillsides, particularly in hot and dry situations.<ref name="yash">{{cite web|last1=Yashe |first1=Asavela |last2=Hankey |first2=Andrew |title=Androstachys johnsonii Prain | date= October 2014 |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantab/androstachysjohnsoni.htm |website=PlantzAfrica |publisher=SANBI |accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref> It produces a hard, durable wood which is of economic interest. Its specific name commemorates W. H. Johnson, a 19th-century Director of Agriculture in Mozambique.<ref name="yash"/> Four related species which are native to Madagascar, are usually placed in genus ''[[Stachyandra]]''.<ref name="prota">{{cite web|title=Androstachys johnsonii (PROTA) |url=http://uses.plantnet-project.org/en/Androstachys_johnsonii_(PROTA) |website=Pl@ntUse |publisher=Plant Resources of Tropical Africa |accessdate=27 June 2016}}</ref>

==Uses==
Its [[timber]] is of economical interest. The wood is extremely hard and durable.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/> It is widely exploited in southern Mozambique, where it is known as ''simbirre''. Here it is used for flooring, for which it is well-suited, and is commonly traded for pillars of huts and fences. South African tourist operators in Mozambique used it extensively for building structures near or in sea water. It is also traded as '''mecrussé''' in Mozambique, but rarely so, presumably due to a lack of supply.<ref name="prota"/>

==Range and habitat==
Within [[southern Africa]], it occurs in [[Limpopo Province]], [[Mpumalanga]] and [[Swaziland]]. It is commonly found at altitudes up to 1000 m. It forms dense shrub-like thickets and thrives in hot and dry climates with well drained soils, especially on rocky hillsides or along seasonal watercourses.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith">{{cite web |last=Radcliffe-Smith |first=A. |title=''Euphorbiaceae'' |work=Flora Zambesiaca: Taxon Detail |year=1996 |url=http://apps.kew.org/efloras/namedetail.do?flora=fz&taxon=6956&nameid=17635 |accessdate=2011-11-09}}</ref>

==Description==
It is described as a medium-sized, evergreen tree growing up to 20 m high.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe">{{cite web |title=''Androstachys johnsonii''|work=Flora of Zimbabwe: Species information |url=http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/species.php?species_id=134720|accessdate=2011-11-09}}</ref><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> It is characterised by a rough
[http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/utilities/utility-display-all-images-by-genus.php?genus_id=841 bark] with a whitish, woolly, hair like covering on the new growth.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/> The leaf blades are 3-9 x 2-7 cm and are oppositely paired at right angles.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> They are ovate to heart-shaped with both the apex and base rounded.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> The upper surfaces are shiny and are a green to blue-green color, beneath the surface is covered in dense, white, woolly hairs.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/>

==Flowers==
Flowering time is October–November.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> Flowers [[axillary bud|axillary]], [[unisexual]] and vary in both arrangement and appearance.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> Male flowers are yellow and are arranged in a 3-flower cluster up to 3 cm long.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> Central flowers are longer than the laterals with their [[pedicel (botany)|pedicel]] being 1–1.3 cm long versus the lateral length of 5–6 mm.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> [[Sepals]]; greenish petals that the form the [[calyx (botany)|calyx]] of the flower differ in number; 5 in central flower and 2-3 in laterals.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> The bulbous base or [[receptacle (botany)|receptacle]] of flower from which its organs grow are 2 cm long in central; 1.5 cm in laterals.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> [[Stamens]] up to c. 50 in central c. 35 in lateral, [[filament (botany)|filaments]] of lowest stamens up to 1 mm long, [[anthers]] 3 x 0.5 mm covered in fine silky hairs in early development and then smooth, lacking hairs with maturation.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> Yellowish [[thecae]] of [[anthers]]. Female flowers are yellow and are at the end of a long, white hairy stalk.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/> Pedicels are 1–1.5 cm  long, extending to up to 3 cm  long in fruit; [[sepals]] 7–8 × 2–2.5 mm and are an ovate-leaf shape, blunt tapering or sometimes split at apex, minutely ruffled with fine hairs on edge and base; otherwise smooth.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> [[Ovary]] is c. 3 mm in diameter, oval in shape, densely covered in fine white woolly hairs.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> [[Style (botany)|Style]]s c. 7 mm long with fine hair covering, [[stigma (botany)|stigma]]s are globe shaped.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/>

==Fruit==
The fruit is bright green at first and ripens to a light yellow or reddish brown and is covered in fine bristle-like hairs.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> It is a 3-lobed capsule, 8–10 x 12–13 mm in size, and is easy to detach.<ref name="Flora of Zimbabwe"/><ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/> The [[seeds]] are chestnut brown in colour, with a long, shallow, linear ridge. Their dimensions are 6.5–7(8) x 4.5–5(6) x 2–3 mm.<ref name="Radcliffe-Smith"/>

==See also==
*[[Taxonomy of the Picrodendraceae]]

23.text:
{{redirect|Gaboon|the viper|Gaboon viper}}
{{redirect|Okoumé|the Quebec-based folk-rock group|Okoumé (band)}}
{{italic title}}
{{no footnotes|date=March 2009}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Aucoumea klaineana''
|status = VU
|status_system = iucn2.3
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Sapindales]]
|familia = [[Burseraceae]]
|genus = '''''Aucoumea'''''
|species = '''''A. klaineana'''''
|binomial = ''Aucoumea klaineana''
|binomial_authority = [[Jean Baptiste Louis Pierre|Pierre]]
|}}
'''''Aucoumea klaineana''''' ('''Angouma''', '''Gaboon''', or '''Okoumé''') is a [[tree]] in the family [[Burseraceae]], native to equatorial west [[Africa]] in [[Gabon]], the [[Republic of the Congo]], and [[Rio Muni]]. It is a medium-sized [[hardwood]] [[tree]] growing to 30–40 m tall, rarely larger, with a trunk 1-2.5 m diameter above the often large basal buttresses. The tree generally grows in small stands, the roots of the trees intertwined with neighboring trees.  In Gabon it is the primary [[timber]] species.

==Uses==
It is a weak wood with low decay resistance and moderate dimensional stability. The major use of Gaboon is in the manufacture of [[plywood]]. It is about 8- 12% lighter than the other main [[Plywood#Marine plywood|marine plywood]] [[Shorea|Meranti]] that is commonly used in boatbuilding, but is not as stiff. This is useful when a boat design calls for tight radius bends such as near the bow in a single chine design because of its flexibility. However it does not resist impact damage as well as Meranti and is often sheathed in [[epoxy]] resin to increase strength and give more impact and abrasion resistance and to increase water resistance over conventional marine enamel paints. It is often used in sandwich construction using the West (and other similar) epoxy system. Its attractive appearance means that it is often used decoratively as the top surface [[Wood veneer|veneer]] in panelling and furniture or, in solid form in luxury items such as boxes for [[cigars]] or other high value items (e.g. audio equipment).{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}

Gaboon plywood is also used in the French aircraft industry to make light airplanes, such as those built by [[Avions Robin]].  It was used extensively to manufacture the [[Jodel]] range of aircraft, which are popular throughout Europe but no longer factory-built.  However, the wood's open grain, flexibility and light weight make it a popular choice for amateur builders of Jodel aircraft to this day.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}

In the form known as okoume marine grade plywood, it is considered perhaps the finest construction plywood now available for boats especially where lighter weight is needed. It is widely available manufactured and certified to [[BS 1088|British Standard 1088]]. Its users range from individual hobbyist [[kayak]] builders to some of the world's largest boat builders. Most often it is used in combination with epoxy and [[fiberglass]], the combination giving a structure that can be stronger and lighter than plastic or fiberglass, rivaling the performance characteristics of more advanced composites such as [[carbon fiber]]. The grain appearance is prized, likened to that of [[mahogany]] and is often varnished for a decorative appearance.

When used for the backs and sides of high-end acoustic guitars, Okoume (or as it is known in the trade, Akoumé) exhibits many of the tonal properties of maple. Guitars made with Okoumé are noticeably lighter in weight than those made with mahogany or rosewood.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}

==References==

*[https://web.archive.org/web/20070929203907/http://sea.unep-wcmc.org/species/tree_study/africa/1-7.html Profiles of Africa Tree Species: ''Aucoumea klaineana'']
*[https://forestplywood.com/infographics/marine-plywood Aucoumea klaineana Infographics]

24.text:
{{taxobox |image = Avicennia-germinans.jpg |image_caption = Black mangrove growing in [[Guanacaste Province]], [[Costa Rica]] |status = LC |status_system = iucn3.1 |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Lamiales]] |familia = [[Acanthaceae]] |genus = ''[[Avicennia]]'' |species = '''''A. germinans''''' |binomial = ''Avicennia germinans'' |binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) L. |synonyms = ''Avicennia africana'' [[Palisot de Beauvois|P.Beauv.]]
''Avicennia nitida'' [[Nikolaus Joseph von Jacquin|Jacq.]]
''[[Bontia]] germinans'' L.{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?70116 |title=''Avicennia germinans'' (L.) L. |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=1999-07-12 |accessdate=2010-05-20}} |range_map = Avicennia germinans range map 3.png |range_map_caption = Distribution of ''Avicennia germinans'' |}} The '''black mangrove''' ('''''Avicennia germinans'''''), is a shrub in the acanthus family, [[Acanthaceae]].{{cite web|url=http://eol.org/pages/579832/details|title= Avicennia germinans_EOL }} It grows in [[Tropics|tropical]] and [[Subtropics|subtropical]] regions of the [[Americas]], on both the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] and [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] [[coast]]s, and on the Atlantic coast of [[tropical Africa]], where it thrives on the [[sand]]y and muddy [[shore]]s that [[seawater]] reaches. It is common throughout coastal areas of [[Texas]] and [[Florida]], and ranges as far north as southern [[Louisiana]] and coastal [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in the [[United States]]. Like many other [[mangrove]] species, it reproduces by [[vivipary]]. [[Seed]]s are encased in a [[fruit]], which reveals the [[Germination|germinated]] seedling when it falls into the water. Unlike other mangrove species, it does not grow on [[Aerial root#Aerial roots as supports|prop roots]], but possesses [[Aerial root#Pneumatophores|pneumatophores]] that allow its roots to breathe even when submerged. It is a hardy species and expels absorbed salt mainly from its leathery leaves. The name "black mangrove" refers to the color of the trunk and [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|heartwood]]. The leaves often appear whitish from the [[salt]] [[Halophyte|excreted]] at night and on cloudy days. It is often found in its native range with the red mangrove (''[[Rhizophora mangle]]'') and the white mangrove (''[[Laguncularia racemosa]]''). White mangroves grow inland from black mangroves which themselves grow inland from red mangroves. The three species work together to stabilize the shoreline, provide buffers from [[storm surge]]s, trap debris and [[detritus]] brought in by [[tide]]s, and provide feeding, breeding, and nursery grounds for a great variety of [[fish]], [[shellfish]], [[bird]]s, and other wildlife. ==Habitat== [[Image:Black mangrove-everglades natl park.jpg|left|thumb|A black mangrove tree growing in shallow water in [[Everglades National Park]]]] [[Image:Avicennia germinans-flowers2.jpg|left|thumb|Black mangrove flowers]] The black mangrove grows just above the high [[tide]] in coastal [[lagoon]]s and [[brackish water]] [[Estuary|estuaries]]. It is less tolerant of highly saline conditions than certain other species that occur in mangrove ecosystems.World Wildlife Fund. 2010. [http://www.eoearth.org/article/Petenes_mangroves?topic=49597 ''Petenes mangroves'']. eds. Mark McGinley, C.Michael Hogan & C. Cleveland. Encyclopedia of Earth. National Council for Science and the Environment. Washington DC It can reach {{convert|10|–|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} in height, although it is a small [[shrub]] in cooler regions of its range. The [[seed]]s [[Germination|germinate]] in midsummer, but may be seen all year on the trees. The seeds can remain viable for over a year once released. ==Wood== The [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|heartwood]] is dark-brown to black, while the [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|sapwood]] is yellow-brown. It has the unusual property of having less dense heartwood than sapwood. The sapwood sinks in water while the heartwood floats. The wood is strong, heavy, and hard, but is difficult to work due to its interlocked grain and is somewhat difficult to finish due to its oily texture. Uses include posts, pilings, [[charcoal]], and [[Firewood|fuel]]. Despite growing in a marine environment, the dry wood is subject to attack by marine borers and [[termite]]s. Like many species, it contains [[tannin]] in the bark and has been used to [[Tanning (leather)|tan]] [[leather]] products. ==See also== {{Portal|Trees}} *[[List of honey plants]] *[[:Category:Mangrove ecoregions|Mangrove ecoregions]] == References == {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | last = Haehle | first = Robert | year = 1999 | title = Native Florida Plants | publisher = Gulf Publishing Company | location = Houston | isbn = 0-88415-425-4 }} * McKee, Karen L., Irving A. Mendelssohn, and Mark W. Hester. "Reexamination of pore water sulfide concentrations and redox potentials near the aerial roots of Rhizophora mangle and Avicennia germinans." American Journal of Botany (1988): 1352-1359. ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Avicennia germinans|''Avicennia germinans''}} *[http://www.plantmaps.com/nrm/avicennia-germinans-black-mangrove-native-range-map.php Interactive Distribution Map of ''Avicennia germinans''] {{WestAfricanPlants|Avicennia germinans}} {{wikispecies-inline}} [[Category:Avicennia|germinans]] [[Category:Mangroves]] [[Category:Halophytes]] [[Category:Plants described in 1764]] [[Category:Flora of Cameroon]] [[Category:Flora of Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:Flora of Gabon]] [[Category:Flora of Ghana]] [[Category:Flora of Guinea]] [[Category:Flora of Guinea-Bissau]] [[Category:Flora of Mauritania]] [[Category:Flora of Nigeria]] [[Category:Flora of Senegal]] [[Category:Flora of Sierra Leone]] [[Category:Flora of Togo]] [[Category:Trees of the Southeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of Belize]] [[Category:Trees of Costa Rica]] [[Category:Trees of El Salvador]] [[Category:Trees of Guatemala]] [[Category:Trees of Honduras]] [[Category:Trees of Nicaragua]] [[Category:Trees of Panama]] [[Category:Trees of Antigua and Barbuda]] [[Category:Trees of the Bahamas]] [[Category:Trees of Bermuda]] [[Category:Trees of Cuba]] [[Category:Trees of Guadeloupe]] [[Category:Trees of Hispaniola]] [[Category:Trees of Jamaica]] [[Category:Trees of Martinique]] [[Category:Trees of Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Trees of French Guiana]] [[Category:Trees of Guyana]] [[Category:Trees of Suriname]] [[Category:Trees of Venezuela]] [[Category:Trees of Brazil]] [[Category:Trees of Colombia]] [[Category:Trees of Ecuador]] [[Category:Trees of Peru]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]]

25.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Speciesbox
|name   = ''Balanites aegyptiaca''
|image  = Balanites aegyptiaca 0730.jpg
|taxon = Balanites aegyptiaca''
|authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) [[Alire Raffeneau Delile|Delile]], 1812
|synonyms = *''Agialid aegyptiaca'' (L.) Kuntze
*''Ximenia aegyptiaca'' <small>L.</small>
|synonyms_ref = <ref name = plantlistsyn>{{cite web | url = http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-19437 | title = ''Balanites aegyptiaca'' (L.) Delile | accessdate = 17 December 2016 | publisher = The Plant List}}</ref>
}}
[[File:Balanites aegyptiaca MHNT.BOT.2009.13.5.jpg|thumb|''Balanites aegyptiaca'' - [[MHNT]]]]

'''''Balanites aegyptiaca''''' is a species of [[tree]], classified either as a member of the [[Zygophyllaceae]] or the Balanitaceae.<ref name=plantlist>{{Cite web | url = http://www.theplantlist.org/browse/A/Zygophyllaceae/ | title = Zygophyllaceae | accessdate = 27 November 2016 | publisher = The Plant List}}</ref> This tree is native to much of [[Africa]] and parts of the [[Middle East]].<ref name = GRIN/>

There are many common names for this plant.<ref name=purdue/> In [[English language|English]] the fruit has been called desert date, soap berry tree or bush, Thron tree, Egyptian myrobalan, Egyptian balsam or Zachum oil tree;<ref name=Iwu>{{cite book|last=Iwu|first=Maurice M.|title=Handbook of African medicinal plants|year=1993|publisher=CRC Press|location=Boca Raton u.a.|isbn=084934266X|pages=129}}</ref>  in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] it is known as ''lalob'', ''hidjihi'', ''inteishit'', and ''heglig'' (''hijlij''). In [[Hausa language|Hausa]] it is called ''aduwa,'' in Swahili ''mchunju'' and in [[Amharic language|Amharic]] ''bedena''.<ref>Yves Guinand and Dechassa Lemessa, [http://www.ocha-eth.org/Archive/DownloadableReports/famp0300.pdf "Wild-Food Plants in Southern Ethiopia: Reflections on the role of 'famine-foods' at a time of drought"] UN-OCHA Report, March 2000 (accessed 15 January 2009)</ref>

==Distribution==
''Balanites aegyptiaca'' is found in the Sahel-Savannah region across Africa. It can be found in many kinds of habitat, tolerating a wide variety of [[soil]] types, from [[sand]] to heavy [[clay]], and climatic moisture levels, from [[arid]] to subhumid.<ref name=fao>{{cite web |url = http://www.fao.org/docrep/019/x5327e/x5327e.pdf | title = Indigenous Multipurpose Trees of Tanzania | accessdate = 27 November 2016 | publisher = FAO}}</ref> It is relatively tolerant of flooding, livestock activity, and [[wildfire]].<ref name=fao/>

==Description==
The ''Balanites aegyptiaca'' tree reaches {{convert|10|m|ft|abbr=on}} in height with a generally narrow form. The branches have long, straight green spines arranged in spirals. The dark green compound leaves grow out of the base of the spines<ref name=Iwu/>
and are made up of two leaflets which are variable in size and shape.<ref name=waf>{{cite journal |author1= Daya L. Chothani |author2= H. U. Vaghasiya |year= 2011 |pmc= 3210005 |title= A review on Balanites aegyptiaca Del (desert date): phytochemical constituents, traditional uses, and pharmacological activity |journal= Pharmacognosy Review |volume= 5 |issue=9 |pages= 55–62}}</ref> The fluted trunk has grayish-brown, ragged bark with yellow-green patches where it is shed.<ref name=Iwu/>

The [[inflorescence]] consists of bunches of a few flowers which are either sessile or are borne on short stalks. The flower buds are ovoid and covered in a short [[tomentose]] pubescence. The individual flowers are greenish-yellow in colour, [[hermaphrodite|hermaphroditic]] with five petals in [[radial symmetry]] and are {{convert|8|-|14|mm}} in diameter. The pedicel of the inflorescence is greyish in colour, downy and usually less than {{cvt|10|mm}} in length, although {{cvt|15|mm}} has been recorded in [[Zambia]] and [[Zimbabwe]]. The ellipsoid fruit is normally less than {{cvt|4|cm}} long and is green when not ripe; it ripens to a brown or pale brown fruit with a crispy skin enclosing a sticky brown or brown-green pulp around a hard stone.<ref name = worldagroforestry>{{cite web |url= http://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/AFTPDFS/Balanites_aegyptiaca.PDF |title= Balanites aegyptiaca |accessdate= 17 December 2016 |work= worldagroforestry.org |agency= Agroforestry Database 4.0}}</ref>

The [[carpenter ant]] ''[[Camponotus sericeus]]'' feeds on the nectar exuded by the flowers. The larva of the cabbage tree emperor moth ''[[Bunaea alcinoe]]'' causes [[defoliant|defoliation]] of the tree.<ref name=fao/>

==Cultivation==
===Food===
''Balanites aegyptiaca'' has been cultivated in Egypt for more than 4000 years, and stones placed in the tombs as votive offerings have been found as far back as the [[Twelfth Dynasty]]. The tree was figured and described in 1592 by [[Prosper Alpinus]] under the name 'agihalid'. Linnaeus regarded it as a species of ''[[Ximenia]]'', but [[Adanson]] proposed the new genus of ''Agialid''. The genus ''Balanites'' was founded in 1813 by [[Alire Raffeneau Delile|Delile]].<ref name = GRIN>{{cite web | url = https://npgsweb.ars-grin.gov/gringlobal/taxonomygenus.aspx?id=1241 | title = Genus: ''Balanites'' Delile | accessdate = 27 November 2016 | publisher = U.S. National Plant Germplasm System}}</ref>

The yellow, single-[[seed]]ed [[fruit]] is edible, but [[Taste#Bitterness|bitter]].<ref name=fao/> Many parts of the plant are used as [[famine food]]s in Africa; the leaves are eaten raw or cooked, the oily seed is boiled to make it less bitter and eaten mixed with [[sorghum]], and the flowers can be eaten.<ref name=purdue>{{cite web | url = https://hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/FamineFoods/ff_families/BALANITACEAE.html#Balanites%20ægyptiaca | title = BALANITACEAE | accessdate = 27 November 2016 | publisher = Robert Freedman|work = Famine Foods}}</ref>  The tree is considered valuable in arid regions because it produces fruit even in dry times.<ref name=fao/> The fruit can be [[Ethanol fermentation|fermented]] for [[alcoholic beverage]]s.<ref name=waf/>

The [[press cake|seed cake]] remaining after the oil is extracted is commonly used as [[fodder|animal fodder]] in Africa.<ref name=waf/> The seeds of the ''Balanites aegyptiaca'' have [[molluscicide]] effect on ''[[Biomphalaria pfeifferi]]''.<ref name="Hamidou">Hamidou T. H., Kabore H., Ouattara O., Ouédraogo S., Guissou I. P. & Sawadogo L. () "Efficacy of ''Balanites aegyptiaca''(L.) DEL Balanitaceae as Anthelminthic and Molluscicid Used by Traditional Healers in Burkina Faso". International Conference on Emerging Infectious Diseases 2002. page 37. [http://www.cdc.gov/ICEID/asm-iceid_program.pdf PDF]</ref>

Where the species coexist, [[African elephant]]s consume the desert date.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kinloch|first=Bruce|title=The shamba raiders : memories of a game warden|year=1972|publisher=Ashford|location=Hampshire|isbn=1852530359|pages=217|edition=3rd}}</ref>

===Medicinal===
Desert date fruit is mixed into [[porridge]] and eaten by nursing mothers, and the oil is consumed for [[headache]] and to improve [[lactation]].<ref name=purdue/>

Bark extracts and the fruit repel<ref name=Molla/> or destroy<ref name=Iwu/> freshwater  [[snail]]s and [[copepod]]s, organisms that act as intermediary hosts host the parasites [[schistosomiasis|Schistosoma]], including [[Bilharzia]], and [[Dracunculiasis|guinea worm]], respectively. Existing worm infections are likewise treated with desert date, as are liver and spleen disorders. A [[decoction]] of the bark are also used as an [[Abortifacient]] and an antidote for arrow-poison in West African traditional medicine.<ref name=Iwu/>

The seed contains 30-48% fixed (non-volatile) [[Vegetable fats and oils|oil]], like the leaves, fruit pulp, bark and roots, and contains the [[sapogenin]]s [[diosgenin]] and [[yamogenin]].<ref name=Iwu/><ref name=Molla>{{cite journal | author1 = 
Eshetu Molla | author2 = Mirutse Giday | author3 = Berhanu Erko |year = 2013 | title = Laboratory assessment of the molluscicidal and cercariacidal activities of ''Balanites aegyptiaca'' | pmc = 3703561 | journal = The Asian Pacific Journal of Tropical Biomedicine | volume = 3 | issue =8 |pages = 657–662}}</ref> Saponins likewise occur in the roots, bark wood and fruit.<ref name=Iwu/>

===Agroforestry===
The tree is managed through [[agroforestry]]. It is planted along irrigation canals and it is used to attract insects for trapping.<ref name=fao/> The pale to brownish yellow wood is used to make furniture and durable items such as tools, and it is a low-smoke [[firewood]] and good [[charcoal]].<ref name=fao/><ref name=waf/> The smaller trees and branches are used as living or cut fences because they are resilient and thorny.<ref name=fao/><ref name=waf/><ref name=nap>{{cite book | author = National Research Council |year = 2008 |title = Lost Crops of Africa Volume III Fruits | url = https://www.nap.edu/read/11879/chapter/3#29 | chapter = 1. ''Balanites aegyptica'' Desert Date | publisher = National Acdemies Press | ISBN = 0-309-10597-8}}</ref> The tree [[nitrogen fixation|fixes nitrogen]].<ref name=fao/> It is grown for its fruit in [[plantation]]s in several areas.<ref name=waf/> The bark yields [[natural fiber|fibers]], the [[natural gum]]s from the branches are used as [[adhesive|glue]], and the seeds have been used to make [[Jewellery|jewelry]] and [[bead]]s.<ref name=waf/>

===Tattoos===
Various [[Sahel]] tribes use the thorn of the tree to make incisions that result in [[tattoos]].
<ref>Tapon, Francis [http://francistapon.com/Travels/Africa/History-Of-Tattoos-In-Africa "The History of Tattoos in Africa"]. Retrieved December 7, 2016.""</ref>

==Etymology==
The generic part of the binomial ''Balanites'' derives from the Greek word for an [[acorn]] and refers to the fruit, this name was coined by [[Alire Raffeneau Delile|Alire Delile]] in 1813.<ref name = worldagroforestry/> in ''Descr. Egypte, Hist. Nat. 221 1813''.<ref name = plantlistsyn/> The specific name ''aegyptiaca'' was applied by [[Carl Linnaeus]] as the species was initially described from specimens collected in Egypt.<ref name = CRC>{{cite book | author = Umberto Quattrocchi | year = 2016 | title = CRC World Dictionary of Medicinal and Poisonous Plants: Common Names, Scientific Names, Eponyms, Synonyms, and Etymology (5 Volume Set)| publisher = CRC Press | ISBN = 1482250640 | pages = 519–520}}</ref>

26.text:
{{Speciesbox
|image  = 
|genus = Balanites
|species = angolensis
|authority = (Welw.) Mildbr. & Schltr.<ref name = plantlist>{{cite web | url = http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/search?q=Balanites+angolensis | title = ''Balanites angolensis'' (Welw.) Mildbr. & Schltr. | accessdate = 17 December 2016 | publisher = The Plant List}}</ref>
|synonyms = *''Balanites aegyptiaca'' var. ''angolensis'' <small>Welw.</small>
*''Agiella angolensis'' <small>(Welw.) Tiegh.</small>
|synonyms_ref = <ref name = plantlist/>
}}

'''''Balanites angolensis''''', or '''Angolan green-thorn''', is a species of tree from southern Africa, it is a member of the [[Tribulus terrestris|caltrop]] family, [[Zygophyllaceae]].

==Description==
''Balanites angolensis'' is a small semi-[[deciduous]] tree or shrub which grows to up to 8m in height. It has rough, corrugated bark which is green or greenish yellow on young shoots which are covered in dense hairs with yellow or green thorns which are up to 9 cm long. The flowers are greenish-yellow to whitish and are borne in small axillary clusters, each flower consisting of 5 petals and 5 sepals. The fruit is 30mm long, ovoid in shape and is orange when ripe. The leaves are alternate, consisting of one pair of leaflets, 12-17mm in length, leathery, yellowish green and downy. The leaves are ovoid with a pointed tip and tapering base and a short stalk.<ref name = TAN>{{cite web | url = http://treeatlas.biodiversity.org.na/viewspec.php?nr=74 | title = ''Balanites angolensis'', Omutungambara | accessdate = 18 December 2016 | publisher = Tree Atlas of Namibia}}</ref>

==Distribution==
''Balanites angolensis'' is found in [[Angola]], [[Botswana]] and north eastern [[Namibia]].<ref name = PROTO4U>{{cite web | url = http://www.prota4u.org/protav8.asp?en=1&p=Balanites+angolensis | title = Balanites angolensis | accessdate = 18 December 2016 | publisher = Plant Resources of Tropical Africa}}</ref>

==Habitat==
''Balanites angolensis'' occurs along seasonal watercourses<ref name = TAN/> and in savannah, on dry hills and in coastal forest.<ref name = PROTO4U/> In dry scrub forest and [[mopane]] woodland ''Balanites angolensis'' is part of the understorey community.<ref name = White>{{cite book | author = F White | year = 1983 | title = The vegetation of Africa: A descriptive memoir to accompany the Unesco/AETFAT/UNSO vegetation map of Africa | publisher = UNESCO | ISBN = 92-3-101955-4 | pages = 91 & 95}}</ref>

==Phenology==
In Namibia ''Balanites angolensis'' flowers in October and November, fruit is seen from November but peaks in March and April.<ref name = PROTO4U/>

==Uses==
The fruit is edible, the branches are used by the [[Himba people|Himba]] for fencing and the roots are used by the Himba to treat breast complaints in nursing mothers by inhaling the smoke of the burning roots and by making an ointment out of the ashes and smearing this on the breasts. Extracts from the tree are also used to treat [[genitourinary system]] disorders.<ref name = PROTO4U/>

==Subspecies==
There are two recognised subspecies:<ref name = plantlist/>

*''Balanites angolensis angolensis'' <small>(Welw.) Mildbr. & Schltr.</small> from Angola and Botswana. 
*''Balanites angolensis welwitschii'' <small>(Tiegh.) Exell & Mendonça</small> from north eastern Namibia.
