72.text:
{{distinguish2|[[Dracaena draco]], the Canary Islands dragon tree, also found in nearby islands and western Morocco}}
{{Speciesbox
| taxon = Dracaena cinnabari
| image = Socotra_dragon_tree.JPG
| image_caption = ''Dracaena cinnabari'' at Dixsam plateau
| status_system = IUCN3.1
| status = VU
| status_ref = <ref name="Dracaena cinnabari">{{IUCN2010.4 |assessor=Miller, A. |year=2004 |title=Dracaena cinnabari |id=30428 |downloaded=26 November 2010}}</ref>
| authority = [[Isaac Bayley Balfour|Balf.f.]]
}}

'''''Dracaena cinnabari''''', the '''Socotra dragon tree''' or '''dragon blood tree''', is a [[Dracaena (plant)|dragon tree]] native to the [[Socotra]] archipelago, part of [[Yemen]], located in the [[Arabian Sea]]. It is so called due to the [[Dragon's blood|red sap]] that the trees produce.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Becky Chung |title=World's Most Unique Places To Visit |url=http://www.forbes.com/2009/11/04/unique-vacations-travel-lifestyle-travel-adventure-tourism.html |journal=Forbes |date=2009-11-04}}</ref>

==Description==
[[File:Dracaena cinnabari - Koko Crater Botanical Garden - IMG 2295.JPG|thumb|Young specimen of ''Dracaena cinnabari'' in the [[Koko Crater Botanical Garden]], Honolulu, Hawaii, United States]]

The dragon blood tree has a unique and strange appearance, with an "upturned, densely packed crown having the shape of an uprightly held umbrella". This evergreen species is named after its dark red resin, which is known as "dragon's blood". Unlike most [[monocot]] plants, ''Dracaena'' displays secondary growth, ''D. cinnabari'' even has growth zones resembling [[tree ring]]s found in dicot tree species. Along with other arborescent ''Dracaena'' species it has a distinctive growth habit called "dracoid habitus".<ref>{{Cite thesis|last= Bos|first =J.J.|year= 1984|title= ''Dracaena'' in West Africa|type= PhD|publisher= Agricultural University Wageningen}}</ref> Its leaves are found only at the end of its youngest branches; its leaves are all shed every 3 or 4 years before new leaves simultaneously mature. Branching tends to occur when the growth of the terminal bud is stopped, due to either flowering or traumatic events (e.g. [[herbivory]]).<ref name="adoltage" />

Its fruits are small fleshy berries containing between 1 and 3 seeds. As they develop they turn from green to black, and then become orange when ripe. The berries are eaten by birds (e.g. ''[[Onychognathus frater|Onychognatus]]'' species) and thereby [[seed dispersal|dispersed]]. The seeds are 4–5 mm in diameter and weigh on average 68 mg.<ref name=adoltage/> The berries exude a deep red resin, known as dragon’s blood.<ref name=Edwards2001>{{Cite journal | last1 = Edward | first1 = H. | title = Raman spectroscopy of coloured resins used in antiquity: dragon's blood and related substances | journal = Spectrochimica Acta Part A: Molecular and Biomolecular Spectroscopy | volume = 57 | issue = 14 | pages = 2831–2842 | year = 2001 | doi = 10.1016/S1386-1425(01)00602-3|bibcode = 2001AcSpA..57.2831E }}</ref>

Like other monocotyledons, such as [[Arecaceae|palms]], the dragon’s blood tree grows from the tip of the stem, with the long, stiff leaves borne in dense rosettes at the end (4, 5, 7)<!-- Can we check these references? -->. It branches at maturity to produce an umbrella-shaped crown, with leaves that measure up to 60 cm long and 3 cm wide. The trunk and the branches of the dragon blood are thick and stout and display dichotomous branching, where each of the branches repeatedly divides in two sections.

===Biology===
The dragon's blood tree usually produces its flowers around February, though flowering does vary with location. The flowers tend to grow at the end of the branches. The flowers have inflorescences, and they bear small clusters of fragrant, white or green flowers. The fruits take five months to completely mature. The fruits are described as a fleshy berry, which changes from green to black as it gradually ripens. The fleshy berry fruit ends up being an orange-red color that contains one to three seeds. The berries are usually eaten and dispersed by birds and other animals.

The unusual shape of the dragon's blood tree is an adaptation for survival in arid conditions with low amounts of soil, such as in mountaintops. The large, packed crown provides shade and reduces evaporation. This shade also aids in the survival of seedlings growing beneath the adult tree, explaining why the trees tend to grow closer together.<ref name="Dracaena cinnabari" />

==Taxonomy==
The first description of ''D. cinnabari'' was made during a survey of Socotra led by [[James Raymond Wellsted|Lieutenant Wellsted]] of the [[East India Company]] in 1835. It was first named '''''Pterocarpus draco''''', but in 1880, the Scottish botanist [[Isaac Bayley Balfour]] made a formal [[wikt:description|description]] of the species and renamed it as ''Dracaena cinnabari''.<ref name=guptaBCT>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.jep.2007.10.018| pmid = 18060708| year = 2008| last1 = Gupta | first1 = D.| last2 = Bleakley | first2 = B.| last3 = Gupta | first3 = R.| title = Dragon's blood: botany, chemistry and therapeutic uses| volume = 115| issue = 3| pages = 361–380| journal = Journal of Ethnopharmacology}}</ref> Of between 60 and 100 ''Dracaena'' species, ''D. cinnabari'' is one of only 6 species which grow as a tree.<ref name=adoltage>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1007/s00468-003-0279-6| title = Age structure and growth of Dracaena cinnabari populations on Socotra| year = 2004| last1 = Adolt | first1 = R.| last2 = Pavlis | first2 = J.| journal = Trees - Structure and Function| volume = 18| pages = 43–53}}</ref>

===Evolution===
Along with other plants on Socotra, ''D. cinnabari'' is thought to have derived from the [[Tethyan flora]]. It is considered a remnant of the [[Miocene|Mio]]-[[Pliocene]] [[Laurasia]]n subtropical forests that are now almost extinct due to the extensive desertification of North Africa.<ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2007.05.009| title = Will dragonblood survive the next period of climate change? Current and future potential distribution of Dracaena cinnabari (Socotra, Yemen)| year = 2007| last1 = Attorre | first1 = F.| last2 = Francesconi | first2 = F.| last3 = Taleb | first3 = N.| last4 = Scholte | first4 = P.| last5 = Saed | first5 = A.| last6 = Alfo | first6 = M.| last7 = Bruno | first7 = F.| journal = Biological Conservation| volume = 138| issue = 3–4| pages = 430–439}}</ref>

==Conservation==

===Threats===
[[Image:Topographic map of Socotra-en.svg|right|500px|thumb|A map of the [[Socotra]] archipelago]]
Although most of its ecological habitats are still intact, there is an increasing population with industrial and tourism development. This is putting more pressure on the vegetation through the process of logging, overgrazing, woodcutting and infrastructure of development plans. Though the dragon’s blood tree is highly widespread, it has become fragmented due to the development that has occurred in its habitats. Many of its populations are suffering due to poor regeneration. Human activities have greatly reduced the dragon’s blood population through overgrazing, and feeding the flowers and fruits to the livestock of the island. One of the species' greatest threats is the gradual drying out of the Socotra Archipelago, which has been an ongoing process for the last few hundred years. This has resulted in non flourishing trees, and the duration of the mist and cloud around the area seems to also be decreasing. Increasing arid environments is predicted to cause a 45 percent reduction in the available habitat for ''D. cinnabari'' by the year 2080.

Additional threats to the dragon's blood tree include harvesting of its resin and use of the leaves to make rope. Presently some of the dragon’s blood trees have been used to make beehives. This was generally prohibited; this displays how the species may be threatened by a breakdown in the traditional practices of the island.

The best preserved and largest stand of ''D. cinnabari'' is on the limestone plateau named Rokeb di Firmihin. This approximately {{convert|540|ha}} forest has numerous rare and endemic species. Research shows that in coming decades the number of trees in this forest will decrease due to the lack of natural regeneration.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://mendelu.vedeckecasopisy.cz/publicFiles/00139.pdf |last=Hubalkova |first=I. |title=Prediction of Dragon's Blood Tree (Dracaena Cinnabari Balf.) Stand Sample Density on Soqotra Island. |journal=Journal of Landscape Ecology |date=2011 |volume=4 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140808065804/http://mendelu.vedeckecasopisy.cz/publicFiles/00139.pdf |archivedate=8 August 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref>

===Management===
The unique flora and fauna of the Socotra Archipelago is considered a World Heritage Site a Global 200 Ecoregion. It is a Center of Plant Diversity and an Endemic Bird Area. It also lies within the Horn of Africa biodiversity hotspot. There are multiple efforts that are being developed to help create and support a sustainable habitat and biodiversity management programs on Socotra. The dragon’s blood tree is considered as an important species for commodity and for conservation efforts on the island. The dragon’s blood falls under an umbrella species. This is a species selected for making conservation related decisions, typically because protecting these species indirectly protects the many other species that make up the ecological community of its habitat. Species conservation can be subjective because it is difficult to determine the status of many species. Thus, the dragons blood protection efforts would also benefit many other plants and animals within the area.

The dragon's blood tree is given some protection from international commercial trade under the listing of all ''Dracaena'' species on Appendix II of CITES (3), but if its populations are to be effectively preserved, a variety of measures will need to be taken. These include urgent monitoring of the species' natural regeneration and the expansion of Skund Nature Sanctuary to cover important areas of the habitats. Also, efforts to avoid road construction in the dragon blood’s habitat, and limit grazing need to be brought to attention. Additional conservation efforts for the tree involve fencing against livestock, watering of seedlings in open areas, and involving local communities in planting seedlings.

==Uses==
Dragon's blood is used as a stimulant and [[abortifacient]].<ref>Handbook of Medicinal Herbs https://books.google.com/books?id=8AJkBmPDRUUC&pg=PA256&lpg=PA256&dq=dragon's+blood+abortion&source=bl&ots=MKL2zg0nGD&sig=xEJSBCupdoOG_MUgMWJePePfYvY&hl=en&ei=-vX_TL7NItLSngf4r8zlDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=dragon's%20blood%20abortion&f=false</ref> The root yields a gum-resin, used in gargle water as a stimulant, [[astringent]] and in toothpaste. The root is used in [[rheumatism]], the leaves are a [[carminative]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gMwLwbUwtfkC Indian Medicinal Plants: An ... - Google Books<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

The trees can be harvested for their crimson red [[resin]], called [[dragon's blood]], which was highly prized in the ancient world and is still used today. Around the Mediterranean basin it is used as a [[dye]] and as a [[medicine]], Socotrans use it ornamentally as well as dying wool, gluing pottery, a breath freshener and [[lipstick]]. Because of the belief that it is the blood of the [[dragon]] it is also used in [[ritual magic]] and [[alchemy]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.alchemy-works.com/incense_dragons_blood.html | title=Dragon's Blood Resin from Alchemy Works | accessdate=May 12, 2014}}</ref> In 1883, the Scottish botanist Isaac Bayley Balfour identified three grades of resin; the most valuable were tear-like in appearance, then a mixture of small chips and fragments, with a mixture of fragments and debris being the cheapest.<ref name=guptaBCT/> The resin of ''D. cinnabari'' is thought to have been the original source of dragon's blood until during the mediaeval and renaissance periods when other plants were used instead.<ref name=Edwardsraman>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1039/b311072a | pmid = 14752556 | title = Raman spectroscopic analysis of dragon's blood resins?basis for distinguishing between Dracaena (Convallariaceae), Daemonorops (Palmae) and Croton (Euphorbiaceae) | year = 2004 | last1 = Edwards | first1 = H. G. M. | last2 = De Oliveira | first2 = L. F. C. | last3 = Prendergast | first3 = H. D. V. | journal = The Analyst | volume = 129 | issue = 2 | pages = 134–8|bibcode = 2004Ana...129..134E }}</ref>

The local inhabitants of the city in the Socotra Island use the dragon's blood resin as a cure-all. Greeks, Romans, and Arabs use it in general wound healing, as a coagulant, cure for diarrhea, for dysentery diseases, for lowering fevers. It is also taken for ulcers in the mouth, throat, intestines and stomach.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/5786935_Dragon's_blood_Botany_chemistry_and_therapeutic_uses|title=Dragon's blood: Botany, chemistry and therapeutic uses (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-04-20}}</ref>

Dragon's blood from ''D. cinnabari'' was used as a source of [[varnish]] for 18th-century Italian [[violin]]-makers. It was also used as tooth-paste in the 18th century. It is still used as varnish for violins and for photoengraving.



==References==
{{Reflist}}

==Sources==

'''''Dypsis''''' is a genus of [[flowering plant]]s in the [[Arecaceae]] [[family (biology)|family]]. They are slender, [[evergreen]] palms with yellow flowers carried in [[panicles]] amongst the [[pinnate]] leaves. Many ''Dypsis'' species have aerial branching (above the main trunk), a rare [[growth habit]] among palms.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Forestry Department|title=Introduction|url=http://www.fao.orgfao.org/docrep/x0451e/x0451e03.htm|website=Tropical Palms|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|year=1995}}</ref> Some have [[marcescent]] leaves that remain attached after death and trap litter for nutrients.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bramwell|first1=David|last2=Caujapé-Castells|first2=Juli|title=The Biology of Island Floras|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2fCYWrKJAu4C&pg=PA189|date=2011-07-21|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-49780-0|page=189}}</ref>

The [[etymology]] is obscure but may be related to the Greek ''{{transl|grc|dypto}}'' ‘I dive’ or ''{{transl|grc|dyptes}}'' ‘diver’.<ref>{{cite book|last=Quattrocchi|first=Umberto|title=CRC World Dictionary of Plant Names|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=esMPU5DHEGgC&pg=PA45|year=1999|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-0-8493-2675-2|page=45}}</ref> The species are native to [[Tanzania]], [[Madagascar]], and various islands in the [[Indian Ocean]] ([[Mauritius]] and [[Comoros]]). A few are naturalized in other regions, especially in the [[Caribbean]].<ref name=ijionjono7asdfh67bsdf79as45ewr>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=65391 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref>

'''''Ehretia cymosa''''' is a small tree belonging to the [[Boraginaceae]] or [[borage]] family. It occurs over a wide range of habitat throughout  of western, central and eastern [[Africa]], including [[Benin]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]], [[Cameroon]],<ref>[http://dzanga-sangha.myspecies.info/simpletaxonomy/term/2796 dzanga-sangha.myspecies.info]</ref> [[Ethiopia]], [[Kenya]],<ref>[http://larmat.uonbi.ac.ke/print/1951 Land Resource Management & Agricultural Technology (http://larmat.uonbi.ac.ke)]</ref> [[Comoros]], [[Madagascar]], [[Mascarenes]],<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=12&taxon_id=250069110 Madagascar catalogue]</ref> [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Mozambique]].

==Other names==
Local names for this plant include:  ''Mpelu'', ''Mnemvu'' (Tanzania), ''Murembu''(Meru), ''Shekutu'' (Luhya), ''Yambu'' (Chagga), ''Mororwet'' (Nandy), ''Alébé'' (Baoulé), ''Bélékou'', ''Blikou'' (Gouro), ''Grakou'' (Shien), ''Labassa'' (Ewé), ''Zomena'', ''Zomali'' (Adja), ''Zoma'', ''Zozoma'', ''Myonma'' (Fon), ''Myoma'' (Sahouè) and ''Ulaagaa'' (Arsi).<ref>[http://www.africamuseum.be/collections/external/prelude/view_plant?pi=05230 www.africamuseum.be]</ref>

Leaves & roots are used for medical uses in traditional medicine.

75.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Ensete ventricosum'' |image = Ensete ventricosum02.jpg |image_caption = ''Ensete ventricosum'', by [[Walter Hood Fitch]] (1861) |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Monocots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]] |ordo = [[Zingiberales]] |familia = [[Musaceae]] |genus = ''[[Ensete (genus)|Ensete]]'' |species = '''''E. ventricosum''''' |binomial = ''Ensete ventricosum'' |binomial_authority = ([[Friedrich Welwitsch|Welw.]]) [[Ernest Entwistle Cheesman|Cheesman]] |synonyms = * ''Ensete arnoldianum'' (De Wild.) Cheesman * ''Ensete bagshawei'' (Rendle & Greves) Cheesman * ''Ensete buchananii'' (Baker) Cheesman * ''Ensete davyae'' (Stapf) Cheesman * ''Ensete edule'' Bruce ex Horan. * ''Ensete fecundum'' (Stapf) Cheesman * ''Ensete holstii'' (K.Schum.) Cheesman * ''Ensete laurentii'' (De Wild.) Cheesman * ''Ensete proboscideum'' (Oliv.) Cheesman * ''Ensete ruandense'' (De Wild.) Cheesman * ''Ensete rubronervatum'' (De Wild.) Cheesman * ''Ensete schweinfurthii'' (K.Schum. & Warb.) Cheesman * ''Ensete ulugurense'' (Warb. & Moritz) Cheesman * ''Ensete ventricosum'' var. ''montbeliardii'' (Bois) Cufod. * ''Mnasium theophrasti'' Pritz. [Invalid] * ''Musa arnoldiana'' De Wild. * ''Musa bagshawei'' Rendle & Greves * ''Musa buchananii'' Baker * ''Musa davyae'' Stapf * ''Musa ensete'' J.F.Gmel. * ''Musa fecunda'' Stapf * ''Musa holstii'' K.Schum. * ''Musa kaguna'' Chiov. * ''Musa laurentii'' De Wild. * ''Musa martretiana'' A.Chev. * ''Musa proboscidea'' Oliv. * ''Musa ruandensis'' De Wild. * ''Musa rubronervata'' De Wild. * ''Musa schweinfurthii'' K.Schum. & Warb. * ''Musa ulugurensis'' Warb. & Moritz * ''Musa ventricosa'' Welw. |synonyms_ref = {{cite web|url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-243317|title=The Plant List: A Working List of all Plant Species}} |}} '''''Ensete ventricosum''''', commonly known as the '''Ethiopian banana''', '''Abyssinian banana''',{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?15184|title=USDA GRIN Taxonomy}} '''false banana''', '''enset''' or '''ensete''', is an herbaceous [[species]] of [[flowering plant]] in the [[banana]] family [[Musaceae]]. The name ''Ensete ventricosum'' was first published in 1948 in the [[Kew Bulletin]], 1947, p. 101. Its synonyms include ''Musa arnoldiana'' De Wild., ''Musa ventricosa'' Welw. and ''Musa ensete'' [[Johann Friedrich Gmelin|J.F.Gmel]].[[:de:Zierbanane|Wikipedia DE]]{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=September 2015}} It is [[native plant|native]] to the eastern edge of the [[Geography of Africa#Plateau region|Great African Plateau]], extending northwards from the Transvaal through Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Malawi, Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania to Ethiopia, and west to the Congo, being found in high rainfall forests on mountains, and along forested ravines and streams. ==Description== Like bananas, ''Ensete ventricosum'' is a large non-woody plant — a gigantic [[monocarpic]] [[evergreen]] [[perennial plant|perennial]] herb (not a tree) — up to {{convert|6|m|0|abbr=on}} tall. It has a stout pseudostem of tightly overlapping leaf bases, and large banana-like leaf blades of up to {{convert|5|m|0|abbr=on}} tall by {{convert|1|m|0|abbr=on}} wide, with a salmon-pink midrib. The flowers, which only occur once from the centre of the plant at the end of that plant's life, are in massive pendant [[thyrse]]s covered by large pink [[bract]]s. The fruits are inedible (''insipid'', flavorless)http://ecocrop.fao.org/ecocrop/srv/en/cropView?id=5700 and have hard, black, rounded seeds. After flowering, the plant dies. ==Use as a foodcrop== "Enset provides more amount of foodstuff per unit area than most cereals. It is estimated that 40 to 60 enset plants occupying 250-375 sq. meters can provide enough food for a family of 5 to 6 people." – Country Information Brief, [[FAO]] June 1995. Enset (''E. ventricosum'') is Ethiopia's most important [[root crop]], a traditional staple in the densely populated south and southwestern parts of Ethiopia.[[Richard Pankhurst (academic)|Richard Pankhurst]], ''Economic History of Ethiopia'' (Addis Ababa: Haile Selassie I University, 1968), p. 194. Pankhurst uses the taxononym ''Musa ensete''. Its importance to the diet and economy of the Gurage and Sidama peoples was first recorded by [[Jerónimo Lobo]].Jerónimo Lobo, ''The Itinerário of Jerónimo Lobo'', translated by Donald M. Lockhart (London: Hakluyt Society, 1984), pp. 245f The root is the main edible portion as its fruit is insipid. Each plant takes four to five years to mature, at which time a single root will give 40 kg of food. Due to the long period of time from planting to harvest, plantings need to be staggered over time, to ensure that there is enset available for harvest in every season. Enset will tolerate [[drought]] better than most [[cereal crop]]s. Wild enset plants are produced from [[seed]]s, while most domesticated plants are propagated from [[basal shoot|suckers]]. Up to 400 suckers can be produced from just one mother plant. In 1994 3,000 km² of enset were grown in Ethiopia, with a harvest estimated to be almost 10 tonnes per hectare. Enset is often intercropped with [[sorghum]], although the practice amongst the Gedeo is to intercrop it with [[Coffea|coffee]].Kippie Kanshie, T. [http://www.treemail.nl/download/treebook5.pdf "Five thousand years of sustainability? A case study on Gedeo land use"] (PhD dissertation: May 2002), p. 38 It is a major crop, although often supplemented with cereal crops.Kippie Kanshie, T. "Five thousand years", p. 19 However its value as a [[famine food]] has fallen due to a number of causes, as detailed in the April 2003 issue of the UN-OCHA Ethiopia unit's ''Focus on Ethiopia'':
Apart from an Enset plant disease epidemic in 1984-85 which wiped out large parts of the plantations and created the green famine, in the past 10 years major factors were recurrent drought and food shortage together with acute land shortage that forced farmers more and more into consumption of immature plants. Hence farmers were overexploiting their Enset reserves thereby causing gradual losses and disappearance of the false banana as an important household food security reserve. Even though not all the plant losses can be attributed to drought and land shortage and hence early consumption of immature crops, estimations go as far as more than 60% of the false banana crop stands have been lost in some areas in [[SNNPR]] during the last 10 years. This basically means that a great many people who used to close the food gap with false banana consumption are not able to do so any more, and lacking a viable alternative, have become food insecure and highly vulnerable to climatic and economic disruptions of their agricultural system.[http://www.ocha-eth.org/Archive/2003ArchiveFOE.htm "Enset as staple food not valuable anymore to bridge food gap", ''Focus on Ethiopia'', April 2003], UN-OCHA-Ethiopia (accessed 3 March 2009)
The young and tender tissues in the centre or heart of the plant (the [[apical meristem|growing point]]) are cooked and eaten, being tasty and nutritious and very like the core of palms and cycads. In Ethiopia, more than 150 000 ha are cultivated for the starchy staple food prepared from the pulverised trunk and inflorescence stalk. Fermenting these pulverised parts results in a food called ''kocho''. ''Bulla'' is made from the liquid squeezed out of the mixture and sometimes eaten as a porridge, while the remaining solids are suitable for consumption after a settling period of some days. Mixed kocho and bulla can be kneaded into dough, then flattened and baked over a fire. Kocho is in places regarded as a delicacy, suitable for serving at feasts and ceremonies such as weddings, when wheat flour is added. The fresh [[corm]] is cooked like potatoes before eating. Dry kocho and bulla are energy-rich and produce from 1400 to 2000[[Kilojoule|kJ]] per 100g. ==Other uses== The plant is quick-growing and often cultivated as an ornamental plant. In frost-prone areas it requires winter protection under glass.{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|pages=1136}} It has gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].{{cite web|title=''Ensete ventricosum''|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=698|publisher=Royal Horticultural Society|accessdate=25 July 2013}} A good quality fibre, suitable for ropes, twine, baskets, and general weaving, is obtained from the leaves. Dried leaf-sheaths are used as packing material, serving the same function as Western foam plastic and polystyrene. The entire plant but the roots is used to feed livestock.[http://database.prota.org/PROTAhtml/Ensete%20ventricosum_En.htm Plant Resources of Tropical Africa]Heuzé V., Thiollet H., Tran G., Hassoun P., Lebas F., 2016. Enset (Ensete ventricosum) corms and pseudostems. Feedipedia, a programme by INRA, CIRAD, AFZ and FAO. http://www.feedipedia.org/node/21251 Fresh leaves are a common fodder for cattle during the dry season,Heuzé V., Thiollet H., Tran G., Hassoun P., Lebas F., 2016. Enset (Ensete ventricosum) leaves. Feedipedia, a programme by INRA, CIRAD, AFZ and FAO. http://www.feedipedia.org/node/21254 and a lot of farmers feed their animals with residues of enset harvest or processing. ==History== In 1769 the celebrated Scottish traveller [[James Bruce]] first sent a description and quite accurate drawings of a plant common in the marshes around Gondar in Abyssinia, confidently pronounced it to be "no species of Musa" and wrote that its local name was "ensete". In 1853 the British Consul at Mussowah sent some seeds to [[Kew Gardens]], mentioning that their native name was ''ansett''. Kew, quite understandably, did not make the connection, especially as they had never before seen such seeds. However, when the seeds had germinated and the plants had rapidly gained size, their relationship to the true banana became obvious. Bruce also discussed the plant's place in the mythology of Egypt and pointed out that some Egyptian statue carvings depict the goddess Isis sitting among the leaves of what was thought to be a banana plant, a plant native to Southeast Asia and not known in Ancient Egypt.''Curtis's Botanical Magazine'' vol. 87 (1861)[https://books.google.com/books?id=cthTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA469&lpg=PA469&dq=Maitsha+Ethiopia&source=bl&ots=ZY5-pU7-SQ&sig=6NOWqrkgNCBSnEC-JHmr5iUHwBA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=AN5wT6GHHKP80QX8zOSOAg&sqi=2&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Maitsha%20Ethiopia&f=false Encyclopædia Britannica] Sir [[John Kirk (explorer)|John Kirk]] felt that in habit ''[[Ensete livingstonianum]]'' is indistinguishable from ''E. ventricosum'' and noted that both are found in the mountains of equatorial Africa. ==Known variants and hybrids== * ''Ensete ventricosum 'Atropurpureum' * ''Ensete ventricosum 'Green Stripe' * Red false banana (''Ensete ventricosum'' 'Maurelii', syn. ''Musa maurelii'') * ''Ensete ventricosum'' 'Montbeliardii' * ''Ensete ventricosum'' 'Tandarra Red' (syn. ''Musa'' 'Tandarra Red') * ''Ensete ventricosum'' 'Red Stripe' (syn. ''Musa'' 'Red Stripe') * ''Ensete ventricosum'' 'Rubra' (syn. ''Musa ensete'' 'Rubra') ==References== {{Commons category}} {{Wikispecies}} {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{AfricanPlants|Ensete ventricosum}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} [[Category:Musaceae]] [[Category:Afromontane flora]] [[Category:Flora of East Tropical Africa]] [[Category:Flora of Northeast Tropical Africa]] [[Category:Flora of South Tropical Africa]] [[Category:Flora of West-Central Tropical Africa]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]] [[Category:Plants described in 1859]] [[Category:Ethiopian cuisine]] [[Category:Garden plants of Africa]] [[Category:Tropical fruit]]
75.title: Ensete ventricosum

76.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Erythrina fusca'' |image = Erythrina fusca.jpg |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fabales]] |familia = [[Fabaceae]] |genus = ''[[Erythrina]]'' |species = '''''E. fusca''''' |binomial = ''Erythrina fusca'' |binomial_authority = [[João de Loureiro|Lour.]] |synonyms = ''Erythrina caffra'' Blanco
''Erythrina glauca'' Willd.
''Erythrina viarum'' |}} '''''Erythrina fusca''''' is a species of [[Flowering plant|flowering]] [[tree]] in the [[legume]] family, [[Fabaceae]]. It is known by many common names, including '''purple coraltree''', '''gallito''', '''bois immortelle''', '''bucayo''', and the more ambiguous '''"bucare"''' and '''"coral bean"'''. ''E. fusca'' has the widest distribution of any ''Erythrina'' species; it is the only one found in both the [[New World|New]] and [[Old World]]. It grows on coasts and along rivers in tropical [[Asia]], [[Oceania]], the [[Mascarene Islands]], [[Madagascar]], [[Africa]], and the [[Neotropic ecozone|Neotropics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rngr.net/Publications/ttsm/Folder.2003-07-11.4726/PDF.2004-03-03.5508/file |format=[[PDF]] |first=Nancy Barrera |last=Marín |title=''Erythrina fusca'' Lour. |work=Tropical Tree Seed Manual |publisher=Reforestation, Nurseries & Genetics Resources |date=2003-01-01 |accessdate=2009-03-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116103644/http://www.rngr.net/Publications/ttsm/Folder.2003-07-11.4726/PDF.2004-03-03.5508/file |archivedate=January 16, 2009 }} The easy-to-grow and attractive flowering tree is cultivated as an ornamental shade and hedge plant. It is a common shade tree in [[cacao plantation]]s. It attracts [[hummingbirds]], which [[Pollinator|pollinate]] its flowers. ''E. fusca'' is the official flower of the [[Venezuela]]n state of [[Trujillo (state)|Trujillo]]. ==Description== ''E. fusca'' is a [[deciduous]] tree with spiny [[bark]] and light orange [[flower]]s. Its legume pods reach {{convert|20|cm|in}} in length and contain dark brown [[seed]]s. The seeds are [[Buoyancy|buoyant]], allowing them [[Drift seed|disperse across oceans]].{{cite journal |url=http://www.seabean.com/newsletters/vol07-1.pdf |title=Notes On The Ocean Dispersal of Coral Beans |first=Wayne P. |last=Armstrong |journal=The Drifting Seed |date=May 2001 |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=5–6}} The tree is highly adapted to coastal conditions, tolerant of both flooding and [[Halophyte|salinity]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fao.org/ag/AGP/AGPC/doc/Publicat/Gutt-shel/x5556e0b.htm |title=Erythrina Species - Pantropical Multipurpose Tree Legumes |first=D.L. |last=Kass |work=Forage Tree Legumes in Tropical Agriculture |publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]] |accessdate=2009-03-29}} Like many other species in the genus ''[[Erythrina]]'', ''E. fusca'' contains [[Toxin|toxic]] [[alkaloid]]s which have been utilized for medicinal value but are [[poison]]ous in larger amounts. The most common alkaloid is [[erythraline]], which is named for the genus. ==As food== The new buds and leaves are eaten as a vegetable. In [[Thailand]] fresh ''Erythrina fusca'' ({{lang-th|ทองหลาง}}) leaves are often eaten in [[Miang kham]] ({{lang-th|ทองหลาง}}).[ftp://smc.ssk.ac.th/intranet/Research_AntioxidativeThaiVegetable/www/Native_veg/v142.html ทองหลาง] ==In culture== In [[Sri Lanka]], the blossoming flowers of the tree are associated with the advent of the [[Sinhalese New Year|Sri Lankan New Year]]. The plant is known as ''yak-erabadu'' in [[Sinhalese language|Sinhalese]].[http://archives.dailynews.lk/2004/04/09/fea03.html Erabadu - bright red harbingers of Avurudu] ==See also== *[[List of Thai ingredients]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Erythrina fusca}} *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=ERFU2 USDA Plants Profile] *[http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/duke_energy/Erythrina_fusca.html New Crops Info Page] *[http://www.fao.org/ag/AGP/AGPC/doc/Publicat/Gutt-shel/x5556e0b.htm Genus ''Erythrina''] *[http://www.cipav.org.co/lrrd/lrrd8/1/cuellar.htm Study: ''E. fusca'' as a protein supplement for cattle] *[http://waynesword.palomar.edu/coraltr1.htm Flowers, Pollination & Ocean Dispersal In Coral Trees (Erythrina)] [[Category:Erythrina|fusca]] [[Category:Trees of the Amazon]] [[Category:Pantropical flora]] [[Category:Flora of Tanzania]] [[Category:Flora of the Western Indian Ocean]] [[Category:Trees of India]] [[Category:Trees of Sri Lanka]] [[Category:Trees of Indo-China]] [[Category:Trees of Malesia]] [[Category:Trees of Central America]] [[Category:Trees of the Caribbean]] [[Category:Trees of northern South America]] [[Category:Trees of Brazil]] [[Category:Trees of western South America]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]] [[Category:Trees of the Pacific]] [[Category:Trees of Thailand]]

77.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Gardenology.org-IMG 0334 rbgs10dec.jpg
|image_caption = Very large, ovate leaflets
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Erythrina]]''
|species = '''''E. latissima'''''
|binomial = ''Erythrina latissima''
|binomial_authority = [[Ernst Heinrich Friedrich Meyer|E.Mey.]]
|synonyms = 
* ''Chirocalyx mollissimus'' <small>Meisn.</small>
* ''Erythrina gibbsae'' <small>Baker</small>
* ''Erythrina sandersoni'' <small>Harv.</small>
|}}
The '''Broad-leaved coral tree''' (''Erythrina latissima'') is a [[deciduous]] [[tree]] from southern Africa growing 5 to 8 m tall.<ref name=plantz>{{cite web|last=Tarr |first=B.B. |title=Erythrina latissima |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantefg/erythrinlatis.htm |work=plantzafrica.com |publisher=South African National Biodiversity Institute |accessdate=17 October 2012}}</ref> It is a member of the [[Fabaceae]] and occurs naturally in the Afrotemperate mist-belt of [[South Africa]] and [[Swaziland]] to the uplands of [[Mozambique]], [[Zimbabwe]] and adjacent [[Botswana]].<ref name=flzim>{{cite web|last=Hyde|first=Mark|title=Erythrina latissima |url=http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/species.php?species_id=131480 |work=Flora of Zimbabwe |publisher=zimbabweflora.co.zw |accessdate=17 October 2012|display-authors=etal}}</ref> It is often cultivated as a tree for gardens and parks.<ref name=vwyk>{{cite book|last=Van Wyk |first=Braam|title=Field Guide to the Trees of Southern Africa |year=1997 |publisher=Struik |location=Cape Town |isbn=1-86825-922-6 |pages=391|display-authors=etal}}</ref> In Zimbabwe its range overlaps with the similar ''[[Erythrina abyssinica]]''.

It has [[Pubescent (botany)|pubescent]] branchlets and fissured, corky bark. The foliage is soft and initially woolly in texture, with some prickles and prominently raised venation below.<ref name=vwyk/><ref name=flzim/> Their scarlet flowers with red, densely velvety [[Sepal|calyxes]] may appear from winter to early summer,<ref name=flzim/> usually before new foliage is produced. The fruit is a cylindrical articulated pod, bearing orange to red seeds with a black spot.<ref name=vwyk/>

File:Erythrina latissima, blaarondersy, a, Uniegeboutuine.jpg|<center>Venation of single leaflet</center>

78.text:
{{italictitle}}{{taxobox
|name = Blue guarri
|image = Euclea crispa, habitus, b, Uniegeboutuine.jpg
|status = LC
|status_system = IUCN2.3
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Ericales]]
|familia = [[Ebenaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Euclea]]''
|species = '''''E. crispa'''''<ref group=note>''crispa'' = "curled", referring to the leaf margins that may be rolled under or wavy</ref>
|binomial = ''Euclea crispa''
|binomial_authority = ([[Carl Peter Thunberg|Thunb.]]) [[Robert Louis August Maximilian Gürke|Gürke]]
|synonyms = 
* ''Euclea lanceolata'' <small>E.Mey. ex A.DC</small><ref name=tpl>{{cite web|title=''Euclea crispa'' (Thunb.) Gürke|url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-2802651|work=The Plant List 2010|accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref>  	
|}}
'''''Euclea crispa''''', commonly known as the '''blue guarri''',<ref group=note>The [[Khwe language|Khwe]] appelation "Gwarri" is also the origin of the [[Afrikaans]] and [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]] loan words, "Ghwarrie" and "umGwali", respectively.</ref> is an [[Afrotropic ecozone|Afrotropical]] plant species of the family [[Ebenaceae]]. The hardy and evergreen plants may form a dense stand of shrubs,<ref name=kcp/> or grow to tree size. It is widespread and common in the interior regions of southern Africa,<ref name = palmer>{{cite book |last=Palmer |first=Eve |authorlink=Eve Palmer |title=A Field Guide to the Trees of Southern Africa |pages = 282-284 | year=1977 |publisher=Collins |location=London, Johannesburg |isbn=0-620-05468-9}}</ref> and occurs northward to the tropics. Though some are present near the South African south and east coasts,<ref name=elsa/> they generally occur at middle to high altitudes.<ref name=fzim/> It is readily recognizable from its much-branched structure and dull bluish foliage colour. Those bearing lanceolate leaves may however resemble the [[Olea europaea subsp. cuspidata|Wild olive]],<ref name = palmer/> another common species of the interior plateaus.

==Range and habitat==
It is native to central [[South Africa]] (where one of 35 native ebony species),<ref name=plantz/> [[Lesotho]], [[Swaziland]], the [[Zimbabwe]]an plateau and [[Eastern Highlands]],<ref name = palmer/> [[Angola]], [[Zambia]], [[Malawi]]<ref name=kcp/> and uplands of tropical Africa.<ref name=elsa/>

It is found in open or thick bush along stream banks,<ref name=wits/> woodland, kloofs, hillsides, open forest, along forest margins and regularly in sheltered rocky places.<ref name = palmer/><ref name=fzim>{{cite web|last=Hyde|first=Mark |title=Euclea crispa (Thunb.) Sond. ex Gürke subsp. crispa | url=http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/species.php?species_id=143850 |work=Flora of Zimbabwe |accessdate=18 November 2013|display-authors=etal}}</ref> It is rare in the lowveld where it is limited to rocky areas, or areas of higher rainfall.<ref name=piet>{{cite book|last=Van Wyk |first=Piet |title=Field Guide to the Trees of the Kruger National Park |year=1984 |publisher=C. Struik |location=Cape Town |isbn=0-86977-221-X |page=224}}</ref>

==Habit==
It is a rounded, dense and bushy shrub or tree,<ref name=wits>{{cite book|last=Tree Society of Southern Africa|title=Trees and Shrubs of the Witwatersrand|year=1974|publisher=Witwatersrand University Press|location=Johannesburg|isbn=0-85494-236-X|pages=134-135}}</ref> reaching a height of 2 to 6 metres<ref name=wits/> (rarely 8 to 20 metres),<ref name=kcp/><ref name = palmer/><ref name=elsa/> with a spreading, often symmetrical crown. It is slow-growing like its congeners, and becomes frost and drought resistant with age.<ref name=plantz>{{cite web |last=Stoll |first=Nicolette |title=Euclea crispa (Thunb.) Gürke subsp. crispa |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantefg/eucleacrispacrispa.htm |work=plantzafrica.org |date=Aug 2010 |publisher=SANBI |accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref> In Zimbabwe it is a shrub of 1 to 2 m tall,<ref name=kcp>{{cite book |last=Palgrave |first=Keith Coates |title=Trees of Southern Africa |year=1984 |publisher=Struik |location=Cape Town |isbn=0-86977-081-0 |pages=736-737}}</ref> forming small, dense colonies, or a small tree.<ref name=fzim/>

==Description==
===Bole and bark===
The bole is single or multi-stemmed and up to 30 cm in diameter.<ref name = palmer/> The wood is dark brown, hard and close-grained.<ref name=elsa/> The bark varies from grey<ref name=wits/> to brown or blackish,<ref name=palmer/> and is smooth in young trees, but rougher in older trees.<ref name=kcp/> 

===Foliage===
The plants carry a dense canopy of simple leaves of a dull grey-green colour and a rigid, leathery lineament.<ref name = palmer/> Variation in terms of colour, shape, texture and arrangement is however considerable.<ref name = palmer/> Foliage colour varies from a greyish green to distinctly blue, and the leaf shape varies from lanceolate to obovate.<ref name = palmer/> New branches and foliage are covered in rust-brown scales ([[gland]] [[Epidermis (botany)|granules]]),<ref name=kcp/><ref name=braam/> while mature leaves may be hairy or glabrous.<ref name=piet/> Leaves may be opposite, sub-opposite or rarely alternate.<ref name=kcp/> The slender petiole is 1.5 to 2 mm long,<ref name=kcp/> and the leaves measure up to 5 x 1.5 cm.<ref name=piet/> The leaf veins are clear and transparent against light, unlike the opaque venation of Wild olive trees.<ref name = palmer/><ref name=wits/> Leaves may also resemble those of the [[Euclea natalensis|Natal guarri]], a species of generally lower altitudes, but the latter's leaves have a finely hairy stalk.<ref name=elsa>{{cite book|last=Pooley |first=Elsa |title=Trees of Natal, Zululand and Transkei |year=1997 |publisher=Natal Flora Publications Trust |location=Durban |isbn=0-620-17697-0 |pages=398}}</ref> 

===Flowers===
The fragrant flowers are produced in summer, from October to February.<ref name=fzim/> They are small, waxy, pendulous, yellow<ref name=piet/> to greenish-white and borne in axillary pseudo-racemes,<ref name = palmer/><ref name=piet/> holding 3 to 10 flowers each.<ref name=kcp/> Their bell-shaped [[Corolla (flower)|corollas]] are deeply lobed,<ref name=kcp/><ref name=braam/> and the ovaries are densely covered in bristles.<ref name=kcp/>

===Fruit===
The roundish, pea-sized berries (4 to 5 mm in diameter)<ref name=piet/> are considered palatable when ripe.<ref name=wits/> They are single-seeded and borne on female trees only.<ref name=braam>{{cite book|last=Van Wyk|first=Braam|title=Field Guide to Trees of Southern Africa |year=1997 |publisher=Struik |location=Cape Town |isbn=1-86825-922-6 |pages=340|display-authors=etal}}</ref> As they ripen, they turn from green to reddish brown, and eventually to black.<ref name=kcp/><ref name=fzim/><ref name=wits/> They are somewhat or very hairy when green,<ref name=kcp/> but more or less glabrous when mature.<ref name=piet/> Saplings can be grown quite easily from fresh, plump seed, that is sown soon after harvesting.<ref name=plantz/>

==Subspecies==
'''var. ''crispa'''''
*Range: very widely distributed in southern Africa
*Description: leaves variable but hardly wavy, broadly tapering with rounded apex, or acute apex with rounded tip,<ref name = palmer/> margins entire, and generally smaller and narrower<ref name=kcp/> than the next
'''var. ''ovata''''' 
*Range: eastern [[Karoo|karroid]] regions (incl. [[Cradock, Eastern Cape|Cradock]] and [[Middelburg, Eastern Cape|Middelburg]]) to Northern Cape (incl. [[Kimberley, Northern Cape|Kimberley]] and [[Kuruman]]) and southern [[Free State (province)|Free State]]
*Description: leaves wavy, much more ovate and sharply tapering, densely hairy when young,<ref name = kcp/> sometimes minutely scalloped,<ref name = palmer/> and hardly distinguishable from the [[Euclea coriacea|Mountain guarri]] where they overlap<ref name=kcp/>

==Species interactions and uses==
Lichens often grow on older bark.<ref name=plantz/> Bees are attracted to the sweet scent of the summer flowers, and larvae of the moths ''[[Ectoedemia crispae]]'' and ''[[Graphiocephala barbitias]]'' feed on the leaves. The fruit are eaten by birds and mammals, including antelope, vervet monkeys,<ref name=plantz/> mongooses and rats,<ref name=elsa/> while the bark and leaves are browsed by [[Black rhinoceros|Black rhino]].<ref name=braam/> A dye extracted from the roots is used for baskets, mats and wool.<ref name=braam/> A medicinal infusion of the root is also used for various ailments,<ref name=plantz/> and the fruit or bark are used as a [[Laxative|purgative]].<ref name=palmer/> 

{{Gallery
|title=
|width=160 | height=170 | lines=1
|align=center
|footer=
|File:Euclea crispa00.jpg|alt1=|<center>Foliage and bell-like flowers</center>
|File:Euclea crispa, loof en vrugte, Nkwe.jpg|alt2=|<center>Green berries on female tree</center>
|File:Euclea crispa, habitus, Nkwe.jpg|alt3=|<center>A female tree</center>
}}

|synonyms = 
* ''Euclea multiflora'' <small>Hiern</small><ref name=tpl3>{{cite web|title=''Euclea multiflora'' Hiern |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2802683 |work=The Plant List 2010 |accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref>
* ''Royena macrophylla'' <small>E.Mey. ex A.DC.</small><ref name=tpl1>{{cite web|title=''Euclea natalensis'' A.DC.|url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2802685 |work=The Plant List 2010 |accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref>
|}}
The '''Natal guarri''' is a [[Dioecy|dioecious]] [[Africa]]n plant species of the family [[Ebenaceae]]. It occurs from [[Ethiopia]] and [[Somalia]] in the north, southwards to the [[Western Cape]], South Africa.<ref name=not>{{cite web |last1=Notten |first1=Alice |title=Euclea natalensis A.DC. |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantefg/eucleanatal.htm |website=plantzafrica.com |publisher=SANBI |date= February 2010|accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref> Its hirsute, leathery leaves have an opposite arrangement, and the flower sprays grow from the leaf axils. The spherical fruit appear from October to June.<ref name=tc>{{cite web |title=Euclea natalensis - Natal Guarri |date = 1 April 2009 |url=http://treeco-treeco.blogspot.com/2009/04/euclea-natalensis-natal-guarri.html |website=TreeCo |accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref>

==Races==
The three races are:<ref name=tpl2>{{cite web|title=''Euclea natalensis'' |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/search?q=Euclea+natalensis |work=The Plant List 2010 |accessdate=18 November 2014}}</ref>
* ''Euclea natalensis'' subsp. ''natalensis''
* ''Euclea natalensis'' subsp. ''angolensis'' <small>F.White</small>
* ''Euclea natalensis'' subsp. ''obovata'' <small>F.White</small>

80.text:
{{taxobox |image = Euclea racemosa - Sea Guarrie tree - Cape Town 1.JPG |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Ericales]] |familia = [[Ebenaceae]] |genus = ''[[Euclea]]'' |species = '''''E. racemosa''''' |binomial = ''Euclea racemosa'' |binomial_authority = L. |}} '''''Euclea racemosa''''' (the '''Sea Guarrie''' or '''Dune Guarrie''') is a small to medium-sized [[Evergreen|evergreen tree]] that is indigenous to the [[Indian Ocean]] coast of [[Africa]] from [[Egypt]] to [[South Africa]], as well as in [[Comoros]], [[Oman]] and [[Yemen]].[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=385345 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families] ''Euclea racemosa'' has leathery foliage that can be exceptionally even and dense - making it an ideal plant for hedges. A [[dioecious]] tree (male and female flowers on separate trees), it produces small white [[flower]]s, which are followed by red, purple and black [[fruit]]s that attract [[bird]]s.
The berries are used locally to make "Guarrie vinegar". [http://www.healingorchids.com/africantreeessences/seaguarrie.html International Flower Essence Repertoire, African tree essences, Sea Guarrie ''Euclea racemosa''] The name '''guarrie''' appears to derive from the local Khoe language, in which it is spelled '''gwarri'''. ==Pictures== File:Euclea racemosa - Sea Guarrie Tree - flowers 6.JPG|Detail of inflorescence. File:Euclea racemosa - Sea Guarrie Tree - berries 7.JPG|The characteristic multi-coloured berries of the Sea Guarrie tree. File:Euclea racemosa - Sea Guarrie Tree - berries 2.JPG|Detail of berries. File:Euclea racemosa - Dune Guarrie hedge - Cape Town 3.JPG|''Euclea racemosa'' used for roadside hedging. File:Euclea racemosa - Sea Guarrie hedge - Cape Town 2.JPG|Rough ''Euclea racemosa'' hedging. Cape Town. ==Classification== ;subspecies # ''Euclea racemosa'' subsp. ''bernardii'' F.White - [[Cape Province]] # ''Euclea racemosa'' subsp. ''daphnoides'' (Hiern) F.White - [[Cape Province]], [[KwaZulu-Natal]], [[Swaziland]], [[Mpumalanga]], [[Limpopo]] # ''Euclea racemosa'' subsp. ''macrophylla'' (E.Mey. ex A.DC.) F.White - [[Cape Province]], [[KwaZulu-Natal]] # ''Euclea racemosa'' subsp. ''racemosa'' - [[Cape Province]] # ''Euclea racemosa'' subsp. ''schimperi'' (A.DC.) F.White - most of species range # ''Euclea racemosa'' subsp. ''sinuata'' F.White - [[Mozambique]], [[KwaZulu-Natal]] # ''Euclea racemosa'' subsp. ''zuluensis'' F.White - [[Swaziland]], [[Mozambique]], [[KwaZulu-Natal]] {{commons category|Euclea racemosa}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Euclea|racemosa]] [[Category:Flora of Africa]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]] [[Category:Flora of the Comoros]] [[Category:Flora of Mozambique]] [[Category:Flora of Oman]] [[Category:Flora of South Africa]] [[Category:Flora of Yemen]] [[Category:Plants described in 1774]] {{Ericales-stub}}

'''''Eugenia tabouensis''''' is a small [[tree]] in the [[Myrtaceae]] family. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to the [[tropical rainforest]]s of [[Ivory Coast]].  It is threatened by [[habitat loss]].

82.text:
{{taxobox
|status = LC
|status_system = IUCN2.3
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Sapindales]]
|familia = [[Meliaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Entandrophragma]]''
|species = '''''E. excelsum'''''
|binomial = ''Entandrophragma excelsum''
|binomial_authority = (Dawe & Sprague) Sprague
|}}

'''''Entandrophragma excelsum''''', is a [[Africa]]’s tallest indigenous [[tree]] native to [[Tropics|tropical]] [[East Africa]] and occurs in eastern [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|D.R.of the Congo]], [[Rwanda]], [[Burundi]], [[Uganda]], [[Tanzania]], [[Malawi]] and [[Zambia]]. This species is scattered in areas of upland semi-deciduous forest, in mid-altitude and [[montane rainforest]], at (925 –) 1280 – 2150 altitude. It is locally also found in [[riverine forest]].

==Description==
''Entandrophragma excelsum'' [[deciduous]], [[dioecious]] large tree commonly up to 45 (–60) m tall. [[Bole (botany)|Bole]] branchless for up to 27 m, straight and cylindrical, up to 200 (–250) cm in diameter, with large buttresses up to 5 m high. In 2016 in a remote valley on the continent’s highest mountain [[Kilimanjaro]], northern Tanzania has been discovered Africa's tallest tree, it was measured at '''81.5''' meters tall. The ten known tallest individuals of Entandrophragma excelsum ranged from 59.2 to 81.5 m and 1.24 to 2.55 m diameter.<ref>springer.com / [http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10531-016-1226-3 Africa’s highest mountain harbours Africa’s tallest trees], First Online: 17 October 2016, Biodiversity and Conservation: January 2017, Volume 26, Issue 1, pp 103–113. Authors: Andreas Hemp, Reiner Zimmermann, Sabine Remmele, Ulf Pommer, Bernd Berauer, Claudia Hemp, Markus Fischer. DOI: 10.1007/s10531-016-1226-3</ref><ref>newscientist.com / [https://www.newscientist.com/article/2114073-africas-tallest-tree-measuring-81m-found-on-mount-kilimanjaro/ Africa’s tallest tree measuring 81m found on Mount Kilimanjaro], By Agata Blaszczak-Boxe, 24 November 2016</ref> 

[[Leaves]] pinnate on stalks to 60 cm or more with 8–16 large [[leaf]]lets, almost opposite, each one oblong, 8 – 18 (–30) cm long and 4.5 – 8 (–14) cm wide. [[Inflorescence]] 25 – 30 cm long and 10 – 15 cm wide. [[Flower]]s unisexual, tiny, white or pinkish white.

The [[wood]] is moderately lightweight, with a density of 460–530 kg/m³ at 12% moisture content.

==Uses==
The wood of Entandrophragma excelsum is not in much demand for local applications because it often warps and twists considerably upon drying. Moreover, it is not durable and not very attractively figured. Its occurrence in mountain regions often hampers commercial exploitation.<ref>prota4u.org / [http://www.prota4u.org/protav8.asp?en=1&p=Entandrophragma+excelsum Entandrophragma excelsum (Dawe & Sprague) Sprague]</ref>

The wood is suitable for the production of sliced and rotary veneer, and can be made into plywood of satisfactory quality. The wood is suitable for construction, flooring, joinery, interior trim, furniture, cabinet work, musical instruments, vehicle bodies, toys, novelties, boxes, crates, carvings, turnery, veneer and plywood. The wood is used for fuel and to make charcoal.<ref>tropical.theferns.info / [http://tropical.theferns.info/viewtropical.php?id=Entandrophragma+excelsum Entandrophragma excelsum]</ref>

==Synonyms==
All synonyms for ''Entandrophragma excelsum'' tree:<ref>theplantlist.org / [http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2789552 ''Entandrophragma excelsum'' (Dawe & Sprague) Sprague]</ref> 
* ''Entandrophragma deiningeri'' <small>[[Vernon Lee Harms|Harms]]</small>
* ''Entandrophragma gillardini'' <small>Ledoux</small>

83.text:
{{Italic title}}
{{taxobox
|image = Faidherbia albida.JPG
|image_caption = ''F. albida'' growing with [[Arecaceae|palms]] and [[maize]] crops
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = '''''Faidherbia'''''
|genus_authority = [[Auguste Chevalier|A.Chev.]]
|species = '''''F. albida'''''
|binomial = ''Faidherbia albida''
|binomial_authority = ([[Delile]]) [[A.Chev.]]
|range_map = Faidherbia alba Distribution Map.svg
|range_map_caption = The range of ''Faidherbia albida''.
|}}
[[File:Faidherbia albida_fleur_MHNT.jpg|thumb|''Faidherbia albida'' - [[MHNT]]]]

'''''Faidherbia''''' is a genus of [[Fabaceae|leguminous]] plants containing one species, '''''Faidherbia albida''''', native to [[Africa]] and the [[Middle East]]. The species was formerly widely included in the genus ''[[Acacia]]'' as ''Acacia albida''. It has also been introduced to [[Pakistan]] and [[India]]. Common names for it include '''apple-ring acacia''' (their circular, indehiscent seed pods resemble apple rings),<ref name=wpa1>{{cite web|last1=Armstrong |first1=W. P. |title=Unforgettable Acacias, A Large Genus Of Trees & Shrubs |url=http://waynesword.palomar.edu/plaug99.htm |website=Wayne's Word |accessdate=17 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151110064020/http://waynesword.palomar.edu:80/plaug99.htm |archivedate=10 November 2015 |df= }}</ref> '''ana tree''', '''balanzan tree''' and '''winter thorn'''.<ref name="ILDIS">[http://www.ildis.org/LegumeWeb?sciname=Faidherbia+albida ILDIS LegumeWeb]</ref>

It is a thorny [[tree]] growing up {{convert|6–30|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall and {{convert|2|m|ft|abbr=on}} in trunk diameter. Its deep-penetrating [[tap root]] makes it highly resistant to drought. The bark is grey, and fissured when old. There are 11,000 seeds/kg. ''Faidherbia albida'' is not listed as being a [[threatened species]].<ref name="ILDIS"/><ref name=apd>African Plants Database: [http://www.ville-ge.ch/cjb/bd/africa/details.php?langue=an&id=62154 ''Faidherbia albida'']</ref><ref name="fao">FAO: [http://www.fao.org/docrep/006/Q2190E/Q2190E10.htm Handbook on Seeds of Dry-Zone Acacias]</ref>

It grows in areas with {{convert|250–600|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rain per year.<ref name="fao"/>

''Faiderbia albida'' is known in the [[Bambara language]] as ''balanzan'' and is the official tree of the city of [[Segou]] on the [[Niger River]] in central [[Mali]]. According to legend, Segou is home to 4,444 ''balanzan'' trees, plus one mysterious "missing tree" the location of which cannot be identified.

In [[Serer language|Serer]] and some of the [[Cangin languages]], it is called ''Saas''. [[Serer creation myth#Saas|Saas]] figures prominently in the [[Serer creation myth|creation myth of the Serer people]]. According to their [[creation myth]], it is the [[tree of life]] and fertility.<ref name="Serer civilisation">{{fr icon}} [[Henry Gravrand|Gravrand, Henry]], "La civilisation [[Serer people|sereer]]", vol. II : Pangool, Nouvelles éditions africaines, [[Dakar]], 1990, pp. 125–127, ISBN 2-7236-1055-1</ref>

The northernmost natural populations are found in [[relict]] groves in [[Israel]] (in the [[Shimron]] nature reserve, near the [[community settlement (Israel)|community settlement]] of [[Timrat]]). All of the trees in a given grove are genetically identical and seem to have multiplied by [[vegetative reproduction]] only, for thousands of years.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}}

==Cultivation and uses==
''Faidherbia albida'' is important in the [[Sahel]] for raising [[bee]]s, since its flowers provide bee [[Forage (honeybee)|forage]] at the close of the rainy season, when most other local plants do not.<ref name="world">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928031700/http://www.worldagroforestry.org/Sites/TreeDBS/aft/speciesPrinterFriendly.asp?Id=1 World AgroForestry]  </ref>

The seed pods are important for raising [[livestock]], are used as [[camel]] [[fodder]] in [[Nigeria]],<ref name="world"/> and are relished by elephant, antelope, buffalo, baboons and various browsers and grazers, though strangely ignored by warthog and zebra.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Journal of Tropical Ecology | volume = 6  | issue = 04 | date = 1990 | pages = 445–457 | title = Fruit production by Acacia albida trees in Zambezi riverine woodlands | author = Kevin M. Dunham | doi = 10.1017/S0266467400004843}}</ref>

The wood is used for canoes, mortars, and pestles and the bark is pounded in Nigeria and used as a packing material on pack animals. The wood has a density of about 560 kg/m<sup>3</sup> at a water content of 12%.<ref name="fao2">FAO: [http://www.fao.org/docrep/V5360E/v5360e0f.htm Role of acacia species in the rural economy of dry Africa and the Near East]</ref> The energy value of the wood as fuel is 19.741 kJ/kg.<ref name="world"/>

Ashes of the wood are used in making soap and as a depilatory and tanning agent for hides. The wood is used for carving; the thorny branches useful for a natural barbed fence.<ref>VITA (1977) {{full citation needed|date=March 2016}}</ref>  Pods and foliage are highly regarded as livestock fodder. Some 90% of Senegalese farmers interviewed by Felker (1981) collected, stored, and rationed Acacia alba pods to livestock. Zimbabweans use the pods to stupefy fish. Humans eat the boiled seeds in times of scarcity in Zimbabwe.

It is also used for [[nitrogen fixation]], [[erosion control]] for crops, for food, drink and medicine. Unlike most other trees, it sheds its leaves in the rainy season; for this reason, it is highly valued in [[agroforestry]] as it can grow among field crops without shading them.<ref name="ILDIS"/>  The leaves from this legume tree are high in nitrogen, and can double yields in maize crops when added to the soil.<ref name="Evergreen Agriculture">http://www.evergreenagriculture.net/sites/default/files/Evergreen%20Agriculture%20Garrity%20et%20al%20Food%20Security.pdf</ref>

=== Medicinal uses ===
The extract is used to treat ocular infections in [[farm]] animals.<ref name="world"/>

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Large-leaved rock fig
|image = Ficus abutilifolia, habitus, Roodekrans.jpg
|image_caption = In [[Walter Sisulu National Botanical Garden|Walter Sisulu Botanical Garden]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Rosales]]
|familia = [[Moraceae]]
|genus = ''[[Ficus]]''
|species = '''''F. abutilifolia'''''
|binomial = ''Ficus abutilifolia''
|binomial_authority = ([[Friedrich Anton Wilhelm Miquel|Miq.]]) Miq.
|synonyms = 
* ''F. soldanella'' <small>Warb.</small>
* ''Urostigma abutilifolium'' <small>Miq.</small><ref name=tpl>{{cite web |title=''Ficus abutilifolia'' (Miq.) Miq., Synonyms |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2809367 |work=ThePlantList |publisher= |accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref> 
}}
The ''' Large-leaved rock fig''' (''Ficus abutilifolia'') is a species of [[Africa]]n rock-splitting<ref name=bur>{{cite web |last1=Burring |first1=Jan |title=Ficus abutilifolia (Miq.) Miq. |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantefg/ficusabuti.htm |website=plantzafrica.com |publisher=SANBI |accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref> [[Ficus|fig]] that occurs in two disjunct regions, one population north, and another south of the equator. The two populations are pollinated by different fig wasps, and are morphologically distinct.<ref name=vn>{{cite web|last1=van Noort |first1=S., Rasplus, J. |title=Ficus abutilifolia (Miquel) Miquel 1867 |url=http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Galoglychia/Subsection_Platyphyllae/Ficus_abutilifolia.htm |website=Figweb |publisher=Iziko Museums |accessdate=16 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129031414/http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Galoglychia/Subsection_Platyphyllae/Ficus_abutilifolia.htm |archivedate=29 November 2014 |df= }}</ref> It is named for the similarity of its broadly ovate leaves to that of ''[[Abutilon]]''.<ref name=bur/> It is virtually restricted to cliff faces and rock outcrops, and is easily recognized from its large, glabrous leaves and smooth, pale bark.

==Species associations==
''[[Nigeriella|Nigeriella fusciceps]]'' <small>Wiebes</small> is the pollinating wasp for the northern population, and ''[[Elisabethiella|Elisabethiella comptoni]]'' <small>Wiebes</small> pollinates the southern population.<ref name=bur/><ref name=vn/> ''[[Philocaenus|Philocaenus rotundus]]'' is an associated but non-pollinating wasp.<ref name=vn/>

|binomial = ''Ficus capreifolia''
|binomial_authority = [[Alire Raffeneau Delile|Delile]]
|synonyms = 
* ''F. antithetophylla'' <small>Steud. ex A.Rich.</small>
* ''F. palustris'' <small>Sim</small> 
* ''F. paolii'' <small>Pamp.</small><ref name=tpl>{{cite web |title=''Ficus capreifolia'' Delile, Synonyms |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-2809818 |work=ThePlantList |publisher= |accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref> 
}}
{{Other uses of|Sandpaper fig|Sandpaper fig}}
The '''River sandpaper fig''' (''Ficus capreifolia'') is a [[Ficus|fig]] shrub or small tree of the western and eastern [[Afrotropics]]. It is typically found around pans or flood plains, or along riparian fringes in tropical or subtropical savanna regions, but is absent from the tropical rainforest zone.<ref name=apd>{{cite web|title=''Ficus capreifolia'' Delile|url=http://www.ville-ge.ch/musinfo/bd/cjb/africa/details.php?langue=an&id=24115|work=African Plant Database|publisher=Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques & South African National Biodiversity Institute|accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref>  Despite its regular scrambling habit it may attain a height of 7 to 10 m.<ref name=apd/> 

The bark is pale and smooth, and the branches are slender.<ref name=ep>{{cite book |last=Pooley |first=Elsa |title=The complete guide to trees of Natal, Zululand & Transkei |year=1997 |publisher=Natal Flora Publications Trust |location=Durban |isbn=0-620-17697-0 |pages=72-73}}</ref> Their rough-textured, pear-shaped, yellowish green figs are up to 2 cm in diameter, and grow on short stalks from the leaf axils.<ref name=ep/> The elongate leaves are rough on both surfaces.

Image:Ficus capreifolia, blaar, Manie van der Schijff BT.jpg|<center>Leaf shape</center>
</gallery>

86.text:
{{italictitle}}{{taxobox
|name = Namaqua fig
|image = Ficus cordata IMG 8502.JPG
|image_caption = In the [[Fish River Canyon]], Namibia
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Rosales]]
|familia = [[Moraceae]]
|genus = ''[[Ficus]]''
|species = '''''F. cordata'''''
|binomial = ''Ficus cordata''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Peter Thunberg|Thunb.]]
}}
'''''Ficus cordata''''', the '''Namaqua fig''', is a species of [[Ficus|fig]] that occurs in two disjunct populations in [[Africa]], one in the arid southwest of the continent, and a second in the northern subtropics. In the south it is often the largest and most prominent tree,<ref name=moll>{{cite book |last1=Moll |first1=Eugene |title=Watter Boom is dit? |date=2013 |isbn=978-1-77007-832-1}}</ref> and is virtually restricted to cliff faces and rock outcrops,<ref name=vn1>{{cite web|last1=Van Noort |first1=S., Rasplus, J. |title=Ficus cordata cordata Thunberg 1786 |url=http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Urostigma/Subsection_Urostigma/Ficus_cordata_cordata.htm |website=Figweb |publisher=Iziko Museums |accessdate=18 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141105163920/http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Urostigma/Subsection_Urostigma/Ficus_cordata_cordata.htm |archivedate=5 November 2014 |df= }}</ref> where it has a rock-splitting habit.<ref name=bur>{{cite web |last1=Burring |first1=Jan |title=Ficus abutilifolia (Miq.) Miq. |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantefg/ficusabuti.htm |website=plantzafrica.com |publisher=SANBI |accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref>

==Races==
The races are:<ref name=tpl1>{{cite web |title=''Ficus cordata'' Thunb. |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2810033 |work=The Plant List (2013). Version 1.1 |publisher= |accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref> 
* ''F. c. cordata'' – southwestern Africa
* ''F. c. lecardii'' <small>(Warb.) C.C.Berg</small> – Senegal to central Africa<ref name=vn2>{{cite web|last1=Van Noort |first1=S., Rasplus, J. |title=Ficus cordata lecardii (Warburg) C.C. Berg 1988 |url=http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Urostigma/Subsection_Urostigma/Ficus_cordata_lecardii.htm |website=Figweb |publisher=Iziko Museums |accessdate=18 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129041521/http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Urostigma/Subsection_Urostigma/Ficus_cordata_lecardii.htm |archivedate=29 November 2014 |df= }}</ref>

==Range and habitat==
The nominate race is native to arid western [[South Africa]], [[Namibia]] and southwestern [[Angola]],<ref name=vn1/> while a second race is native to Africa's northern subtropics. The nominate race is found in [[fynbos]], [[succulent Karoo]] and [[Karoo#Nama Karoo biome|Nama Karoo]],<ref name=vn1/> while the northern race is found in savannah, up to 1,500 m above sea level.<ref name=vn2/>

==Species associations==
The nominate race is pollinated by the wasp ''[[Platyscapa|Platyscapa desertorum]]'' <small>Compton.</small>. The wasp ''[[Comptoniella|Comptoniella vannoorti]]'' <small>Wiebes.</small> is an associated non-pollinator that oviposits through the fig wall.<ref name=vn1/> The pollinator wasp of the northern race, ''F. c. lecardii'', is as yet unknown.<ref name=vn2/>  

==Similar species==
''[[Ficus salicifolia|F. salicifolia]]'',<ref name=tpl2>{{cite web |title=''Ficus salicifolia'' Vahl |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl/record/kew-2812165 |work=The Plant List (2013). Version 1.1 |publisher= |accessdate=6 November 2014}}</ref> the Wonderboom, is sometimes deemed a third race of ''Ficus cordata'', i.e. ''F. c.'' subsp. ''salicifolia'' <small>(Vahl) C.C.Berg</small>, but it lacks the yellowish sessile figs of ''F. cordata'', and its range is much to the east.
[[File:Ficus cordata IMG 8504.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Foliage]]

}} __NOTOC__
{{Other uses of|Strangler fig|Strangler fig}}
'''''Ficus craterostoma''''', a species of '''strangler fig''', is a [[Ficus|fig]] shrub or tree of the [[Afrotropics]] that may grow up to 20 m tall.<ref name=apd>{{cite web|title=''Ficus craterostoma'' Warb. ex Mildbr. & Burret |url=http://www.ville-ge.ch/musinfo/bd/cjb/africa/details.php?langue=an&id=24120 |work=African Plant Database |publisher=Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques & South African National Biodiversity Institute |accessdate=21 January 2013}}</ref> It is found in lowland tropical and swamp forests in the west, or in [[afromontane]] forests, including rocky situations, along Africa's eastern escarpments. The western and eastern populations may constitute separate species, as they occur at different altitudes where their ranges meet in central Africa, while they seem to have exclusive pollinating wasp species.<ref name=figweb>{{cite web|last=Rasplus |first=Jean-Yves & Simon van Noort |title=Ficus craterostoma Mildbraed & Burret 1911 |url=http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Galoglychia/Subsection_Chlamydodorae/Ficus_craterostoma.htm |work=figweb |publisher=Iziko Museums |accessdate=11 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121116001045/http://www.figweb.org:80/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Galoglychia/Subsection_Chlamydodorae/Ficus_craterostoma.htm |archivedate=16 November 2012 |df= }}</ref> 

==Foliage==
{{multiple image
| align     = left
| direction = vertical
| header    = 
| header_align = center

| image1    = Ficus craterostoma, Krantzkloof Natuurreservaat.jpg
| alt1      = 
| width1    = 200
| caption1  = <center>Spray with sessile, axillary figs on the terminal branchlets

| image2    = Ficus craterostoma, vye naby twygpunt, c, Manie van der Schijff BT.jpg
| alt2      = 
| width2    = 200
| caption2  = <center>Sessile, axillary figs
| background color=;border:none;
}} 
Their dark, small leaves are obovate to blunt-tipped (reverse triangular) or even concave at the tip.<ref name=vw>{{cite book|last=Van Wyk |first=Braam|title=Field Guide to the Trees of Southern Africa |year=1997 |publisher=Struik |location=Cape Town |isbn=1-86825-922-6 |page=72|display-authors=etal}}</ref>  The leaves of ''[[Ficus natalensis|F. natalensis]]'' are similar, though more rounded and never concave at the tip.<ref name=ep>{{cite book |last=Pooley |first=Elsa |title=The complete guide to trees of Natal, Zululand & Transkei |year=1997 |publisher=Natal Flora Publications Trust |location=Durban |isbn=0-620-17697-0 |pages=72–73}}</ref>

==Figs==
The small, stalkless figs grow in pairs in leaf axils. They measure from 0.5 to 1 cm in diameter and assume a yellowish red colour when ripe.<ref name=vw/><ref name=ep/> Without the presence of the pollinating wasp, the figs will abort and are dropped in large numbers.<ref name=vw/> The pollinating wasp of the western and eastern populations are ''[[Alfonsiella michaloudi]]'' and ''[[Alfonsiella pipithiensis]]'' respectively.<ref name=figweb/>

88.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Ficus cyathistipula
|image = Ficus cyathistipula kz2.JPG
|image_caption = Specimen in Maspalomas Botanical Garden, [[Gran Canaria]].
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Rosales]]
|familia = [[Moraceae]]
|genus = ''[[Ficus]]''
|species = '''''F. cyathistipula'''''
|binomial = ''Ficus cyathistipula''
|binomial_authority = [[Otto Warburg (botanist)|Warb.]]
|synonyms = 
* ''F. callescens'' <small>Hiern</small>
* ''F. nyanzensis'' <small>Hutch.</small>
* ''F. rederi'' <small>Hutch.</small>
* ''F. rhynchocarpa'' <small>Warb. ex Mildbr. & Burret</small><ref name=tpl>{{cite web |title=''Ficus cyathistipula'' Warb., Synonyms |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2810127 |work=The Plant List |publisher= |accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref> 
}}
'''''''Ficus cyathistipula''''''', the '''African fig tree''', is a species of [[Ficus|fig]] that is native to the [[Tropical Africa|tropical]] forest regions of [[Africa]].<ref name=vn1>{{cite web|last1=van Noort |first1=S., Rasplus, J. |title=Ficus cyathistipula cyathistipula Warburg 1894 |url=http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Galoglychia/Subsection_Cyathistipulae/Ficus_cyathistipula_cyathistipula.htm |website=Figweb |publisher=Iziko Museums |accessdate=16 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129033847/http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/Subgenus_Urostigma/Section_Galoglychia/Subsection_Cyathistipulae/Ficus_cyathistipula_cyathistipula.htm |archivedate=29 November 2014 |df= }}</ref> They may be small trees, shrubs or [[hemiepiphyte|hemi-epiphytic]] [[liana]]s, and are widespread in the moist tropics, where they may be found in Afromontane or rainforest, often overhanging pools.<ref name=zam/> The figs are reddish when ripe, and have thick, spongy walls that enable them to float on water.<ref name=bar>{{cite web |title=Ficus cyathistipula |url=http://mediambient.itineraris.bcn.cat/en/node/263/365 |website=Barcelona pel Medi Ambient: Green Spaces |accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> They are named for their cup-shaped (''cyathus''-) and persistent [[stipule]]s (''stipula'').<ref name=bar/>

==Range and habitat==
It ranges from the Ivory Coast in the west, to western Kenya and northern Malawi in the east. In the south it occurs in northern Angola, northern Zambia, and at [[Mount Namuli]] in [[Zambezia Province|Zambezia]], Mozambique.<ref name=vn3>{{cite journal |last1=Van Noort |first1=S. |last2=Gardiner |first2=A. J. |last3=Tolley |first3=K. A. |title=New records of Ficus (Moraceae) species emphasize the conservation significance of inselbergs in Mozambique |journal=South African Journal of Botany |date=November 2007 |volume=73 |issue=4 |pages=642–649 |doi=10.1016/j.sajb.2007.04.063 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0254629907003043 |accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> They grow beside forested streams or rivers, or in swamps where they overhang pools,<ref name=zam>{{cite web |last1=Bingham |first1=Mike |title=Ficus cyathistipula Warb. subsp. cyathistipula |url=http://www.zambiaflora.com/speciesdata/species.php?species_id=210790 |website=Flora of Zambia |publisher=zambiaflora.com |accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> and on inselbergs and rock outcrops, from sea level to 1,800 m.<ref name=vn1/>

==Description==
''Ficus cyathistipula'' is an evergreen tree, growing to {{convert|5|m|ft}} in height. It has dark and flaky bark. The trunk is thin and branches readily,<ref name=bar/> and may form [[Adventitiousness|adventitious]] roots for support.<ref name=zam/>

The dark, glabrous and leathery leaves are up to 7 cm wide and some 20 cm long.<ref name=vn1/> Their venation is limited to some 5 to 8 lateral nerves.<ref name=bar/> The leaves are ovoid to oblanceolate<ref name=vn1/> and blunt towards the tip, except near the leaf spine. They are arranged in a spiral, on petioles of up to 4 cm long.<ref name=bar/>

The globose syconia (i.e. figs) grow solitary or up to three together in leaf axils, on peduncles of up to 2.5 cm long, or may be [[Sessility (botany)|sessile]]. They measure up to 5 cm in diameter and are initially greenish yellow to whitish,<ref name=bar/> and flecked pale yellow, but ripen to a reddish colour.

===Subspecies===
[[Subspecies]] include:
* ''Ficus cyathistipula'' subsp. ''cyathistipula'' <small>Warburg 1894</small> — tropical Africa
* ''Ficus cyathistipula'' subsp. ''pringsheimiana'' <small>(Braun & K. Schum.) C.C. Berg 1988</small> — [[endemic]] to West African lowland rainforests. <ref>[http://www.gbif.org/species/118156098 Gbif.org: ''Ficus cyathistipula'' subsp. ''pringsheimiana']</ref> <ref name=vn2>{{cite web|last1=van Noort |first1=S., Rasplus, J. |title=Ficus cyathistipula pringsheimiana (Braun & K. Schum.) C.C. Berg 1988 |url=http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/subgenus_urostigma/section_galoglychia/subsection_cyathistipulae/Ficus_cyathistipula_pringsheimiana.htm |website=Figweb |publisher=Iziko Museums |accessdate=16 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129033852/http://www.figweb.org/Ficus/subgenus_urostigma/section_galoglychia/subsection_cyathistipulae/Ficus_cyathistipula_pringsheimiana.htm |archivedate=29 November 2014 |df= }}</ref>

==Species associations==
''Ficus cyathistipula'' subsp. ''cyathistipula'' is pollinated by ''[[Agaon]] fasciatum'' <small>Waterston.</small>. ''Ficus cyathistipula'' subsp. ''pringsheimiana'', which is endemic to [[West Africa]]an lowland rainforests in [[Cameroon]] and [[Gabon]], is pollinated by the wasp ''[[Agaon]] kiellandi'' <small>Wiebes.</small>.<ref name=vn2/>

==References==
{{reflist|25em}}

==External links==
{{Commons category-inline|Ficus cyathistipula|''Ficus cyathistipula''}}

89.text:
{{italic title}}
<!-- This article was auto-generated by [[User:Polbot]]. -->
{{taxobox
|name = ''Ficus faulkneriana''
|status = VU
|status_system = IUCN2.3
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]

|ordo = [[Rosales]]

|genus = ''[[Ficus]]''
|species = '''''F. faulkneriana'''''
|binomial = ''Ficus faulkneriana''
|binomial_authority = [[Cornelis Christiaan Berg|C.C.Berg]]
|}}
'''''Ficus faulkneriana''''' is a species of [[strangler fig]] in the family [[Moraceae]] native to Africa.  <ref name=iucn>[http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/34435/0 UCN SSC East African Plants Red List Authority; The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2013; e.T34435A2852642: Treatment of ''Ficus faulkneriana''] . accessed 28 January 2013.</ref>

==Distribution==
The tree is [[endemic]] to coastal [[Kenya]] and [[Tanzania]], and in the [[Usambara Mountains]] of Tanzania, in tropical [[East Africa]]. <ref name=iucn/>  It is found in coastal woodland and wooded grassland habitats. <ref name=iucn/>

==Description==
The ''Ficus faulkneriana'' grows up to {{convert|30|m|ft}} in height. <ref name=iucn/> 

It is an [[IUCN Red List]]ed [[Vulnerable species]], threatened by [[habitat loss]] from land use conversion to agriculture. <ref name=iucn/>   It is protected within [[Shimba Hills National Reserve]], [[Gongoni Forest Reserve]], and [[Amani Nature Reserve]]. <ref name=iucn/> 

==See also==
* {{C|Flora of East Tropical Africa}}
* {{C|Vulnerable flora of Africa}}

==References==

==External links==

* [http://www.iucnredlist.org IUCN Red List of All Threatened Species]

|image_caption = In Pretoria, South Africa
