{{italic title}}{{taxobox
|name = Lala palm
|image = Hyphaene coriacea kz1.JPG
|image_caption = In Maspalomas Botanical Garden, [[Gran Canaria]]
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Monocots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]]
|ordo = [[Arecales]]
|familia = [[Arecaceae]]
|genus = [[Hyphaene]]
|species = '''''H. coriacea'''''
|binomial = ''Hyphaene coriacea''
|binomial_authority = [[Joseph Gaertner|Gaertn.]], 1788
|synonyms = 
|synonyms_ref=
}}

The '''Lala palm''' (''Hyphaene coriacea'') is a species [[palm tree]] native to the eastern [[Afrotropical ecozone|Afrotropics]].<ref name=plantz>{{cite web |last1=Glen |first1=H.F. |last2=Reynolds |first2=Yvonne |title=Hyphaene coriacea Gaertn. |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/planthij/hyphaencor.htm |website=plantzafrica.com |publisher=SANBI |accessdate=16 March 2015}}</ref> It occurs in eastern Africa from [[Somalia]] to [[Kwazulu-Natal]], South Africa, and is also found in the coastal flats of [[Madagascar]] and on [[Juan de Nova Island]] in the [[Mozambique Channel]].

==See also==
* [[Fan palm]]

{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = Real fan palm
Makalani palm |image = Hyphaene petersiana MS 9966.jpg |image_caption = In northern Namibia |image2 = Hyphaene petersiana01.jpg |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Monocots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]] |ordo = [[Arecales]] |familia = [[Arecaceae]] |genus = [[Hyphaene]] |species = '''''H. petersiana''''' |binomial = ''Hyphaene petersiana'' |binomial_authority = [[Johann Friedrich Klotzsch|Klotzsch]] ex [[Carl Friedrich Philipp von Martius|Mart.]], 1845 |synonyms = *''Chamaeriphes benguelensis'' (Welw. ex H.Wendl.) Kuntze *''Chamaeriphes ventricosa'' (J.Kirk) Kuntze *''Hyphaene aurantiaca'' Dammer *''Hyphaene benguellensis'' Welw. ex H.Wendl. *''Hyphaene benguelensis'' var. ''ventricosa'' (J.Kirk) Furtado *''Hyphaene bussei'' Dammer *''Hyphaene goetzei'' Dammer *''Hyphaene obovata'' Furtado *''Hyphaene ovata'' Furtado *''Hyphaene plagiocarpa'' Dammer *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' J.Kirk *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''ambolandensis'' Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''anisopleura'' Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''aurantiaca'' (Dammer) Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''benguelensis'' (Welw. ex H.Wendl.) Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''bussei'' (Dammer) Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''goetzei'' (Dammer) Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''petersiana'' (Klotzsch ex Mart.) Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''plagiocarpa'' (Dammer) Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''russisiensis'' Becc. *''Hyphaene ventricosa'' subsp. ''useguhensis'' Becc. |synonyms_ref=[http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-101418 The Plant List, ''Hyphaene petersiana''] }} The '''Real fan palm''' (''[[:species:Hyphaene petersiana|Hyphaene petersiana]]''), locally known as the '''Makalani palm''', is a [[palm tree]] native to the subtropical, low-lying regions of south central [[Africa]]. Its habitat is open woodland, flood plains, banks of rivers and the fringes of pans and swamps. It is found in [[Burundi]], [[Rwanda]], the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], [[Tanzania]], [[Angola]], [[Mozambique]], [[Malawi]], [[Zambia]], [[Zimbabwe]], [[Botswana]], [[Namibia]] and the northern and north-eastern [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]].[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=101418 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, ''Hyphaene petersiana''] As with other ''Hyphaene'' species, ''H. petersiana'' is [[Monoicous|dioicous]] and the female plants produce copious fruit of some 60 mm diameter. Up to 2,000 fruit may be found on a tree,{{Cite book | last = Palgrave | first = Keith Coates | title = Trees of Southern Africa | publisher = C. Struik | location = Cape Town | year = 1984 | pages = 67–68 | isbn = 0-86977-081-0}} the combined yield of about four seasons.{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = The makalani palm | url = http://www.tourbrief.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3239 | publisher= tourbrief.com | accessdate = 29 December 2010}} The seeds germinate with difficulty but find saline conditions beneficial. They develop massive tap-roots which draw saline water deep underground. Though slow-growing, they may attain a maximum height of 18m.{{Cite book | last = van Wyk | first = Braam, Piet van Wyk| title = Trees of Southern Africa | publisher = Struik | location = Cape Town | year = 1997 | pages = 52–53 | isbn = 1-86825-922-6}} Typical adult plants are in the order of 5-7m high. The plants are utilized by humans and animals. Repeated cutting of the growth point to obtain sap for [[palm wine]] production may eventually destroy the trees. The stem pith is edible. Beneath the outer fibrous husk of the fruit is a core of white endosperm known as 'vegetable ivory', initially soft and edible and containing some liquid comparable to [[coconut milk]]. The [[Ovambo people]] call the fruit of the Makalani palm ''eendunga'' and use it to distill ''ombike'', their traditional liquor.{{cite news |url=http://www.newera.com.na/articles/48705/Ombike---a-potent-traditional-brew |title=Ombike – a potent traditional brew |last=Shaanika |first=Helvy |date=26 October 2012 |newspaper=[[New Era (Namibia)|New Era]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028101820/http://www.newera.com.na/articles/48705/Ombike---a-potent-traditional-brew |archivedate=28 October 2012 |df= }} The species is similar to ''[[Hyphaene natalensis|H. natalensis]]'', which occurs to the southeast. It is however distinguishable by the shape of the fruit–round rather than pear-shaped–and the shape of the stem, which regularly bulges out below the foliage. ''[[Borassus aethiopum|B. aethiopum]]'' has a comparable stem shape.[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/9918#page/86/mode/1up Martius, Carl Friedrich Philipp von. 1845. Historia Naturalis Palmarum 3: 227, ''Hyphaene Petersiana'']Kirk, James Tiberius. 1866. Journal of the Linnean Society. Botany. London, 9: 235, ''Hyphaene ventricosa'' [[African palm swift]]s and [[rufous-tailed palm-thrush]]es regionally depend on this species for breeding. ==See also== * [[Fan palm]] ==Gallery== Hyphaene petersiana_arbres_MHNT.jpg|Namutoni - Etosha - Namibia Hyphaene petersiana MHNT.BOT.2015.2.3.jpg|Namibia Hyphaene petersiana03.jpg|Shingwedzi, Kruger National Park Hyphaene petersiana00.jpg|Gorongosa Reserve, Mozambique ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{AfricanPlants|Hyphaene petersiana}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hyphaene Petersiana}} [[Category:Hyphaene|petersiana]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]] [[Category:Edible plants]] [[Category:Plants described in 1845]] {{Palm-stub}}
113.title: Hyphaene petersiana

114.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Hyphaene thebaica''
Doum palm |image = Hyphaene thebaica.JPG |image_caption = Doum Palm in Batticaloa, Sri Lanka |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Monocots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Commelinids]] |ordo = [[Arecales]] |familia = [[Arecaceae]] |genus = ''[[Hyphaene]]'' |species = '''''H. thebaica''''' |binomial = ''Hyphaene thebaica'' |binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) [[Carl Friedrich Philipp von Martius|Mart.]] |}} '''''Hyphaene thebaica''''', with common names '''doum palm''' (Ar: دوم) and '''gingerbread tree''' (also '''doom palm'''), is a type of [[palm tree]] with edible oval fruit. It is a native to the [[Arabian Peninsula]] and also to the northern half of [[Africa]][http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=101434 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families] where it is widely distributed and tends to grow in places where groundwater is present. It has been shown that dietary supplementation with doum palm [[extract]] has [[hypotensive]] and [[hypolipidemic]] effects. ==Description== The doum palm is a dioecious palm and grows up to {{convert|17|m|0|abbr=on}} high. The trunk, which can have a girth of up to {{convert|90|cm|0|abbr=on}}, branches [[Dichotomy|dichotomously]] and has tufts of large leaves at the ends of the branches. The bark is fairly smooth, dark grey and bears the scars of fallen leaves. The [[Petiole (botany)|petioles]] (leaf stalks) are about a metre long, sheathing the branch at the base and armed with stout upward-curving claws. The leaves are fan shaped and measure about {{convert|120|by|180|cm|0|abbr=on}}. Male and female flowers are produced on separate trees. The [[inflorescence]]s are similar in general appearance, up to about {{convert|1.2|m|0|abbr=on}} long, branching irregularly and with two or three spikes arising from each branchlet. Female trees produce large woody fruits, each containing a single seed, that remain on the tree for a long period.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldagroforestry.org/sea/Products/AFDbases/af/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=983 |title=Factsheet: ''Hyphaene thebaica'' |work=AgroForestryTree Database |publisher=World Agroforestry Centre |accessdate=2014-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302054303/http://www.worldagroforestry.org/sea/Products/AFDbases/af/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=983 |archivedate=2014-03-02 |df= }} ==Distribution and habitat== The doum palm is native to the northern half of Africa. It is widespread in the [[Sahel]] and grows from [[Mauritania]] and [[Senegal]] in the west, through [[Central Africa]], and east to [[Egypt]], [[Kenya]] and [[Tanzania]]. It tends to grow in areas where groundwater is present and is found along the [[Nile River]] in [[Egypt]] and [[Sudan]], in [[riverine]] areas of northwestern [[Kenya]], and along the Niger River in West Africa. It is also native to the [[Levant]] and the [[Arabian Peninsula]] ([[Israel]], [[Sinai]], [[Yemen]] and [[Saudi Arabia]]. and is reportedly naturalized in the [[Netherlands Antilles]] in the [[Caribbean]]http [http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=101434 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, ''Hyphaene thebaica'' ] It grows in [[wadis]] and at [[oases]], but sometimes occurs away from water and on rocky hillsides. It dislikes waterlogged soils and is very resistant to destruction by bushfires. ==Uses== [[File:Hyphaene thebaica MS 6652.JPG|thumb|150px|''Hyphaene thebaica'' - Doum palm]] [[File:Hyphaene thebaica Bild0917.jpg|thumb|150px|''Hyphaene thebaica'' - Doum palm]] [[File:Dum palm products.JPG|thumb|150px|Harvested by-products of the Doum palm]] The doum palm flourishes in hot dry regions where little else grows and the tree is appreciated for the shade it provides. All parts of the tree are useful, but probably the most important product is the leaves. The fibre and leaflets are used by people along the Niger and Nile Rivers to weave baskets, such as in the [[material culture of the Manasir]]. Other things made from the leaves are mats, coarse textiles, brooms, ropes, string and thatch. The timber is used for posts and poles, furniture manufacture and beehives, and the tree provides wood for fuel. The leaf stalks are used for fencing and the fibre is used for textiles. Other products include fishing rafts, brooms, hammocks, carpets, buttons and beads.{{cite web|url=http://www.infonet-biovision.org/default/ct/748/agroforestry |title=Doum palm |date=2011-08-08 |publisher=Infonet Biovision |accessdate=2014-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120919171821/http://www.infonet-biovision.org/default/ct/748/agroforestry |archivedate=2012-09-19 |df= }} ===Food=== The doum palm fruit-dates are also known in [[Eritrea]] as Akat, or Akaat in the [[Tigre language]]. The thin dried brown [[peel (fruit)|rind]] is made into [[molasses]], [[cakes]], and [[sweetmeats]]. The unripe kernels are edible. The shoots of the germinated seeds are also eaten as a vegetable.Facciola, S., ''Cornucopia, A Source Book of Edible Plants'' Kampong. In [[Egypt]], the fruit is sold in herbalist shops, and is popular among children, gnawing its sweet yet sour hard fibrous flesh beneath the shiny hard crust. In [[Diu, India|Diu]], [[Una, Gujarat|Una]] and [[Saurashtra (region)|Saurashtra]] region of [[Gujarat]] (India), the tree is known as ''Hoka Tree'' and the red ripe edible fruit is known as ''Hoka''. In northern part of Nigeria, among the [[Hausa people]], it's known as "Goruba". Apart from the use of the fruit as food, juice is extracted from the young fruit and palm wine is prepared from the sap. ===Medicinal uses=== The fruit of the doum palm has been used in folk medicine to treat hypertension. In a trial, a group of patients with raised blood pressure were all given an antihypertensive drug but in half the individuals, this was supplemented with doum fruit extract. It was found that those receiving the supplement had lower systolic and diastolic pressures and lower total cholesterol, and the blood lipids and lipoproteins were changed in such a way as to decrease the risk of cardiovascular disease.{{cite journal |author1=El-Gendy, A. |author2=El-Mileegy, A. |author3=Ghyaty, E. |author4=Malek, H. |author5=El-Hamid Mousa, A. |year=2008 |title=The Beneficial Dietary Hypotensive and Hypolipidaemic Effects of Hyphaene Thebaica ( Doum ) |journal=Internet Journal of Alternative Medicine |volume=7 |issue=1 |url=http://ispub.com/IJAM/7/1/5592 }} ===Egyptian tombs=== Doum palm was considered sacred by the [[Ancient Egypt]]ians, and the seed was found in many pharaoh's tombs. On September 24, 2007, it was announced that a team of Egyptian archaeologists led by [[Zahi Hawass]], discovered eight baskets of 3,000-year-old doum fruit in King [[Tutankhamun]]'s tomb. The fruit baskets were each 50 centimetres high, the [[antiquities]] department said. The fruit are traditionally offered at [[funerals]].[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2007/09/25/2042391.htm ABC story: Fruit hamper found in King Tut's tomb] == References == {{Reflist}} * [http://www.westafricanplants.senckenberg.de/root/index.php?page_id=14&id=849 Hyphaene thebaica] in Brunken, U., Schmidt, M., Dressler, S., Janssen, T., Thombiano, A. & Zizka, G. 2008. West African plants - A Photo Guide. Forschungsinstitut Senckenberg, Frankfurt/Main. ==External links== {{Commons category|Hyphaene thebaica}} {{Wikispecies|Hyphaene thebaica}} * [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=HYTH2 USDA profile - ''Hyphaene thebaica''] * [http://www.touregypt.net/featurestories/trees.htm Egypt: Trees in Egypt - ''Doom Tree''] {{Clear}} [[Category:Hyphaene|thebaica]] [[Category:Desert fruit]] [[Category:Flora of the Arabian Peninsula]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]] [[Category:Nile]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian culture]] [[Category:Plants described in 1753]]

115.text:
{{taxobox
|image = Illustration Ilex aquifolium0.jpg
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Aquifoliales]]
|familia = [[Aquifoliaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Holly|Ilex]]''
|species = '''''I. aquifolium'''''
|binomial = ''Ilex aquifolium''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
|range_map = Ilex aquifolium range.svg
|range_map_caption = Distribution map of ''Ilex aquifolium''
}}

'''''Ilex aquifolium''''' ('''holly''', '''common holly''', '''English holly''', '''European holly''', or occasionally '''Christmas holly'''), is a [[species]] of [[holly]] [[native plant|native]] to western and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia.<ref name=fe>Flora Europaea: [http://rbg-web2.rbge.org.uk/cgi-bin/nph-readbtree.pl/feout?FAMILY_XREF=&GENUS_XREF=Ilex&SPECIES_XREF=aquifolium&TAXON_NAME_XREF=&RANK= ''Ilex aquifolium'']</ref><ref name=mc>Med-Checklist: [http://ww2.bgbm.org/mcl/PTaxonDetail.asp?NameId=1263&PTRefFK=1273 ''Ilex aquifolium'']</ref><ref name=rushforth>Rushforth, K. (1999). ''Trees of Britain and Europe''. Collins ISBN 0-00-220013-9.</ref><ref name=fnwe>Flora of NW Europe: [http://ip30.eti.uva.nl/BIS/flora.php?selected=beschrijving&menuentry=soorten&id=3088 ''Ilex aquifolium'']</ref> ''I. aquifolium'' is the species familiar in [[Christmas decoration]], and is regarded as the [[type species]] of the genus ''[[Holly|Ilex]]'', which by association is also called "holly".  It is a [[evergreen]] [[tree]] or [[shrub]] found, for example, in shady areas of forests of [[oak]] and in [[beech]] [[hedge]]s. It has a great capacity to adapt to different conditions and is a pioneer species that repopulates the margins of forests or clearcuts.

As a tree, Christmas holly can exceed 10 m in height. It is usually found as a shrub or a small tree about 1 m tall with a straight [[Trunk (botany)|trunk]] and pyramidal [[crown (botany)|crown]], which branches from the base. It grows slowly and does not usually fully mature due to grazing, cutting, or fire. It can live 500 years, but usually does not reach 100.

==Description==
[[File:Acebo.jpg|thumb|European holly foliage with berries]]
[[File:Hollyflowers.jpg|thumb|European holly flowers; male above, female below (leaves cut to show flowers more clearly)]]
Holly is an [[evergreen]] tree growing to 10–25 m tall with a woody stem as large as 40–80 cm, rarely 1 m or more, in diameter The [[leaf|leaves]] are 5–12 cm long and 2–6 cm broad; they are evergreen, lasting about five years, and are dark green on the upper surface and lighter on the underside, oval, leathery, shiny, and about 5 to 9 cm long. In the young and in the lower limbs of mature trees, the leaves have three to five sharp spines on each side, pointing alternately upward and downward, while leaves of the upper branches in mature trees lack spines.<ref name=rushforth/><ref name=fnwe/>

The [[flower]]s are white, four-lobed, and pollinated by [[bee]]s. Holly is [[Glossary of botanical terms#dioecious|dioecious]], meaning that there are male plants and female plants. The sex cannot be determined until the plants begin flowering, usually between 4 and 12 years of age. In male specimens, the flowers are yellowish and appear in [[Axillary bud|axillary]] groups. In the female, flowers are isolated or in groups of three and are small and white or slightly pink, and consist of four petals and four sepals partially fused at the base.

The [[fruit]] is a red [[drupe]], about 6–10 mm in diameter, a bright red or bright yellow, which matures around October or November; at this time they are very bitter due to the [[ilicin]] content<ref name=Hoppe>{{cite book | first=Heinz, A. |last=Hoppe |date=1975 |title=Drogenkunde |publisher=W. de Gruyter |isbn=3-13-566001-X }}</ref> and so are rarely eaten until late winter after [[frost]] has made them softer and more palatable. They are eaten by rodents, birds and larger herbivores. Each fruit contains 3 to 4 [[seed]]s  which do not germinate until the second or third spring.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Peterken|first=G. F.|author2=Lloyd, P. S.|title=''Ilex aquifolium'' L.|journal=Journal of Ecology|date=November 1967|volume=55|issue=3|pages=841–858|doi=10.2307/2258429}}<!--|accessdate=4 March 2013--></ref>  The fruit only appears on female plants, which require male plants nearby to fertilise them.

==Distribution==
Today, holly is found in western Asia and Europe in the undergrowth of [[oak]] forest and [[beech]] forest in particular, although at times it can form a dense thicket as the dominant species. It requires moist, shady environments, found within forests or in shady slopes, cliffs, and mountain gorges.<ref name = fe/><ref name=mc/><ref name=rushforth/>

Along the west coast of the United States, from California to British Columbia, non-native English Holly has proved very invasive, quickly spreading into native forest habitat, where it thrives in shade and crowds out native species. It has been placed on the Washington State Noxious Weed Control Board's monitor list, and is a Class C invasive plant in Portland.<ref>http://www.nwcb.wa.gov/weeds/english-holly</ref><ref>http://bcinvasives.ca/invasive-species/identify/invasive-species/invasive-plants/english-holly/</ref><ref name="Cal-IPC">{{cite web| url=http://www.cal-ipc.org/ip/management/plant_profiles/Ilex_aquifolium.php |title=''Ilex aquifolium'' (English holly)| publisher=California Invasive Plant Council| accessdate=2016-10-02}}</ref><ref>https://www.portlandoregon.gov/auditor/34460?a=322280</ref>

During the [[Cenozoic Era]], the Mediterranean region, Europe, and northwest Africa had a wetter climate and were largely covered by [[laurel forest]]s. Holly was a typical representative species of this [[biome]], where many current species of the genus ''Ilex'' were present. With the [[Messinian salinity crisis|drying of the Mediterranean Basin]] during the [[Pliocene]], the laurel forests gradually retreated, replaced by more [[drought]]-tolerant [[sclerophyll]] plant communities. The modern ''Ilex aquifolium'' resulted from this change.{{clarification needed|reason=does this refer to the modern distribution or the modern species?|date=February 2017}}{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} Most of the last remaining laurel forests around the Mediterranean are believed to have died out approximately 10,000 years ago at the end of the [[Pleistocene]].

==Ecology==
Holly is a rugged pioneer species that prefers relatively moist areas, and tolerates frost as well as summer drought. The plant is common in the [[garrigue]] and [[maquis shrubland|maquis]] and is also found in deciduous forest and oak forest.

Pure stands of hollies can grow into a labyrinth of vaults in which [[thrush (bird)|thrushes]] and [[deer]] take refuge, while smaller birds are protected among their spiny leaves. After the first frost of the season, holly fruits become soft and fall to the ground serving as important food for winter birds at a time of scarce resources.

The flowers are attractive as nectar sources for insects such as bees, wasps, flies, and small butterflies.

It is an [[invasive species]] on the West Coast of the United States and Hawaii.<ref name="Cal-IPC"/><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.kingcounty.gov/environment/animalsAndPlants/noxious-weeds/weed-identification/english-holly.aspx| title=English Holly - ''Ilex aquifolium''| publisher=[[King County, Washington]]| accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>

==Cultivation==
[[File:2014-11-02 15 43 09 English Holly along Glen Mawr Drive in Ewing, New Jersey.JPG|thumb|Cultivated specimen in North America]]
[[File:2014-08-29 13 46 38 Variegated English Holly at the Pinelands Preservation Alliance headquarters in Southampton Township, New Jersey.JPG|thumb|One of several variegated cultivars]]
''Ilex aquifolium'', the familiar holly of Christmas cards and wreaths, is widely grown in parks and gardens in [[temperateness|temperate]] regions.  Both male and female specimens must be grown together to ensure berries (drupes), which are produced only by female plants.<ref>{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=1405332964|page=1136}}</ref>  Numerous cultivars have been selected, of which the following have gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]] (RHS AGM):-
{|
|- valign=top
|
*''I. aquifolium''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=6332 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Amber' (female)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1012 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Amber' (f) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Argentea Marginata'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1013 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Argentea Marginata' (f/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Ferox Argentea'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1014 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Ferox Argentea' (m/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
|
*'Golden Queen'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1015 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Golden Queen' (m/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Handsworth New Silver'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1016 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Handsworth New Silver' (f/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'J.C. van Tol'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1017 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'J.C. van Tol' (f) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Madame Briot'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1018 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Madame Briot' (f/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
|
*'Myrtifolia Aurea Maculata'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=3133 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Myrtifolia Aurea Maculata' (m/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Pyramidalis'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1019 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Pyramidalis' (f) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Silver Queen'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1020 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex aquifolium 'Silver Queen' (m/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
|}
The hybrid ''Ilex'' x ''altaclerensis'' was developed at [[Highclere Castle]] in 1835, a cross between ''I. aquifolium'' and the tender species ''[[Ilex perado|I. perado]]''.  The following cultivars have gained the RHS AGM:-
{|
|- valign=top
|
*'Belgica Aurea'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1023 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex × altaclerensis 'Belgica Aurea' (f/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Camelliifolia'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=5216 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex × altaclerensis 'Camelliifolia' (f) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
|
*'Golden King'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1024 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex × altaclerensis 'Golden King' (f/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
*'Lawsoniana'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=3135 |title=RHS Plant Selector Ilex × altaclerensis 'Lawsoniana' (f/v) AGM / RHS Gardening |publisher=Apps.rhs.org.uk |accessdate=2013-01-13}}</ref>
|}

==Chemistry and toxicity, medicinal and food uses==
Holly '''berries''' contain [[alkaloid]]s, [[caffeine]], and [[theobromine]] and are generally regarded as toxic to humans, though their poisonous properties are overstated and fatalities almost unknown. Accidental consumption may occur by children or pets attracted to the bright red berries. The berries are [[emetic]]. This is described as being due to the drug [[ilicin]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Kress|first=Henriette|title=Henriette's herbal|url=http://www.henriettes-herb.com/eclectic/usdisp/ilex.html|publisher=Henriette Kress|accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref> though caffeine and theobromine found throughout the plant are much more toxic, generally, to dogs and cats.  The '''leaves''' of related plants are used to make a caffeine-rich beverage, [[yerba mate]], which has caffeine in amounts equal to that of [[coffee]]. It is likely that ''I. aquifolium'' has equal amounts of caffeine in the leaves. It is described "The leaves of holly have been employed in the Black Forest as a substitute for tea"<ref name=Grieve>{{cite web|last=Grieve|title=Grieve Herbal|url=http://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/h/holly-28.html|work=Grieve Herbal|publisher=Grieve|accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref>

Holly is rarely used '''medicinally''', but is [[diuretic]], relieves fevers, and has a [[laxative]] action.<ref>Wren, R.C. (1988). ''Potter's New Cyclopedia of Botanical Drugs and Preparations''. C.W. Daniel ISBN 0-85207-197-3.</ref>

''Ilex aquifolium'' also contains [[saponins]], theobromine (a [[xanthine]]), ilicin, caffeine, [[caffeic acid]], and a yellow pigment, [[ilexanthin]].<ref name=Hoppe/><ref name=handbook>

{{cite book
  |last = Leikin
  |first = Jerrold Blair
  |author2=Frank P. Paloucek
  |title = Poisoning & Toxicology Handbook, Third Edition
  |publisher = Lexi-Comp Inc.
  |location = Hudson, Ohio USA
  |year = 2002
  |page = 80
  |isbn = 978-1-930598-77-5
  |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iXVqAAAAMAAJ
}}
</ref><ref name=guide>
{{cite book
  |last = Turner
  |first = Nancy J.
  |author2=P. von Aderkas
  |title = The North American Guide to Common Poisonous Plants and Mushrooms
  |publisher = [[Workman Publishing Company#Timber Press|Timberpress]]
  |year = 2009
  |page = 210
  |isbn = 978-0-88192-929-4
  |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=bmGY5APFfFQC&pg=RA1-PA210
}}
</ref>

==Other uses==
Many hundreds of [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] and [[cultivar]]s have been developed for garden use, among them the very popular "[[Highclere Castle|Highclere]] holly", ''Ilex × altaclerensis'' (''I. aquifolium'' × ''I. perado'') and the "blue holly", ''Ilex × meserveae'' (''I. aquifolium'' × ''I. rugosa'').<ref name=rhs>Huxley, A., ed. (1992). ''New RHS Dictionary of Gardening''. Macmillan ISBN 0-333-47494-5.</ref> Hollies are often used  for [[hedge (barrier)|hedges]]; the spiny leaves make them difficult to penetrate, and they take well to pruning and shaping.<ref>Northumbria Police: [http://ww2.northumbria.police.uk/ePolicing/Web/WMS.nsf/CrimeReductionContentDocs/CRD000301 Security starts at the Garden Gate]</ref>

Between the thirteenth and eighteenth centuries, before the introduction of [[turnip]]s, ''Ilex aquifolium'' was cultivated for use as winter [[fodder]] for cattle and sheep. Less spiny varieties of holly were preferred, and in practice the leaves growing near the top of the tree have far fewer spines making them more suitable for fodder.

''Ilex aquifolium'' was once among the traditional woods for Great Highland [[bagpipes]] before tastes turned to imported dense tropical woods such as cocuswood, ebony, and African blackwood.

{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Isoberlinia'' |image=Isoberlinia doka MS 4428.jpg |image_caption=[[Isoberlinia doka]] |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fabales]] |familia = [[Fabaceae]] |subfamilia = [[Detarioideae]] |genus = '''''Isoberlinia''''' |genus_authority = Craib & Stapf ex Holland |subdivision_ranks = [[Species]] |subdivision = ''[[Isoberlinia angolensis]]''
''[[Isoberlinia dalzielii]]''
''[[Isoberlinia doka]]''
''[[Isoberlinia scheffleri]]''
''[[Isoberlinia stolzii]]'' |}} '''''Isoberlinia''''' is a [[genus]] in the [[family]] [[Fabaceae]] ([[legume]] family) of five [[species]] of [[tree]] native to the hotter parts of tropical [[Africa]]. They are an important component of [[miombo]] woodlands. The [[leaf |leaves]] have three or four pairs of large [[leaflet (botany)|leaflets]] and stout [[seed]] pods. Local [[Malawi]] names include [[Sukwa]] ''mutondo'' for ''[[Isoberlinia angolensis]]'' and [[Tumbuka language|Tumbuka]] ''mbwerebwere'' for ''[[Isoberlinia stolzii]]''. Some species in this genus have been transferred to the genus ''[[Julbernardia]]''. == References == * Binns, Blodwen. (1972). ''Dictionary of Plant Names in Malawi''. Zomba, Malawi: The Government Printer. * Hutchinson, J. & Dalziel, J. M. (1958). ''Flora of West Tropical Africa'', Vol. 1, Part 2. London: Crown Agents for Oversea Govts. and Admins. * Mabberley, D. J. (1987). ''The Plant Book: A Portable Dictionary of the Higher Plants''. Cambridge: [[Cambridge University Press]]. ISBN 0-521-34060-8. [[Category:Detarioideae]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]]
117.title: Isoberlinia

119.text:
{{italictitle}}{{taxobox |name=Khaya anthotheca
East African mahogany |image=Khaya anthotheca.jpg |status = VU |status_system = IUCN2.3 |regnum = [[Plantae]] |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Sapindales]] |familia = [[Meliaceae]] |genus = ''[[Khaya]]'' |species = '''''K. anthotheca''''' |binomial = ''Khaya anthotheca'' |binomial_authority = ([[Friedrich Welwitsch|Welw.]]) [[Anne Casimir Pyrame de Candolle|C.DC.]] |synonyms = * ''Khaya nyasica'' Stapf ex Baker f. (1911){{cite web|last1=Maroyi |first1=A. |title=Khaya anthotheca (Welw.) C.DC. |url=http://database.prota.org/PROTAhtml/Khaya%20anthotheca_En.htm | website=Prota 7 (1): Timbers/Bois d’œuvre 1 |date=2008 | publisher=PROTA, Wageningen, Netherlands |accessdate=24 November 2014}} |}} '''''Khaya anthotheca''''', with the common name '''East African mahogany''', is a large tree species in the [[Meliaceae]] family, native to tropical [[Africa]]. The name ''anthotheca'' was taken from the Greek word ''anthos'', meaning flower, while ''theca'' refers to a capsule. It is known by a number of other common names, including '''Nyasaland''', '''Red''' or '''White mahogany'''. Oos-Afrikaanse mahonie is the [[Afrikaans]] name and Acaujo is its name in [[French language|French]]. ==Distribution== It is widespread, occurring from [[Guinea Bissau]] east to [[Uganda]] and [[Tanzania]], and south to [[Angola]], [[Zambia]], [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Mozambique]]. It is fairly widely grown in plantations within its natural area of distribution, but also in South Africa, tropical Asia and tropical America. It is easily confused with other ''Khaya'' species like ''[[Khaya grandifoliola|K. grandifoliola]]'', ''[[Khaya senegalensis|K. senegalensis]]'' or ''[[Khaya ivorensis|K. ivorensis]]'' in the north of its natural range. ===Habitat=== The East African mahogany grows in medium to low altitude areas in evergreen forests. They require damp lands in order to grow. The [[Big Tree in Chirinda Forest|Big Tree]] in [[Chirinda Forest Botanical Reserve|Chirinda Forest]] is the tallest native tree in [[Zimbabwe]]. ==Description== ''Khaya anthotheca'' trees may grow between {{convert|30|to|60|m}} tall. They have greyish-brown bark. On mature trees, white scented flowers are borne at the ends of the branches. ==Common uses== It is used for furniture, flooring, paneling and boat building. It is a very suitable tree for these projects because the bark weathers well, is resistant to [[woodboring beetles|borers]] and [[termite]]s, besides fungal decay, and is tough but saws well. The bark has a bitter taste which is often used as a medicine for common colds. The oil from the seeds can also be rubbed into a person's scalp to rid of insects and lice. ==Threats== It is often cut down and destroyed in East and West Africa. Planting new trees in these areas to make up for what was destroyed is very rare. [[Genetic erosion]] is thought to have occurred as well. Because of this, the species is listed as "vulnerable" on the [[IUCN Red List]]. Some of its populations have been offered protection, and some countries placed bans on its export. The foliage is eaten by the larvae of the moth ''[[Heteronygmia dissimilis]]''.{{cite book|author=Capinera, John L. |title=Encyclopedia of Entomology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i9ITMiiohVQC&pg=PA68 |year=2008 |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |isbn=978-1-4020-6242-1 |pages=68–70}} ==Sources== {{reflist}} * Hawthorne, W. 1998. [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32235/all ''Khaya anthotheca'']. [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] Downloaded on 22 August 2007. *Alec Naidoo Pretoria. National Botanical Garden. September 2007. [http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantklm/khayaantho.htm] Downloaded October 17 2012. *Forestry Department. [http://www.fao.org/docrep/X5327e/x5327e18.htm] Downloaded October 18 2012. *Mpingo Conservation and Development Initiative. [http://www.mpingoconservation.org/tax_khaya.html] Downloaded October 20 2012. ==External links== {{commonscategory|Khaya anthotheca|''Khaya anthotheca''}} * {{AfricanPlants|Khaya anthotheca}} [[Category:Khaya|anthotheca]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]] [[Category:Flora of East Tropical Africa]] [[Category:Flora of South Tropical Africa]] [[Category:Flora of West-Central Tropical Africa]] [[Category:Flora of Guinea-Bissau]] [[Category:Flora of Uganda]] [[Category:Flora of Tanzania]] [[Category:Flora of Angola]] [[Category:Flora of Zambia]] [[Category:Flora of Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Flora of Mozambique]]. [[Category:Plants used in traditional African medicine]] [[Category:Vulnerable flora of Africa]] {{-}} {{Meliaceae-stub}}

{{taxobox
|image = Kigelia africana compose.jpg
|image_caption = ''Kigelia africana'': habit, fruit, flower, seeds.
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Lamiales]]
|familia = [[Bignoniaceae]]
|tribus = [[Coleeae]]
|genus = '''''Kigelia'''''
|genus_authority = [[A. P. de Candolle|DC.]]
|species = '''''K. africana'''''
|binomial = ''Kigelia africana''
|binomial_authority = ([[Jean-Baptiste Lamarck|Lam.]]) [[George Bentham|Benth.]]

[[File:Kigelia-Africana-Serengeti.JPG|right|thumb|''K. africana'' habit, in [[Serengeti National Park]].]]

'''''Kigelia''''' is a genus of [[flowering plant]]s in the family [[Bignoniaceae]]. The genus comprises only one species, '''''Kigelia africana''''', which occurs throughout tropical [[Africa]] from [[Eritrea]] and [[Chad]] south to northern [[South Africa]], and west to [[Senegal]] and [[Namibia]]. The Kigelia grows a fruit that grows up to 2 feet long, weighs about 15 lbs, and looks like sausage.

==Etymology==
[[File:Leaves I IMG 4112.jpg|left|thumb|Leaf in [[Kolkata]], [[West Bengal]], [[India]]]]
[[File:Kigeliaflower.JPG|thumb|Flower]]
[[File:Kigelia-Africana-Fruit.JPG|thumb|Sausage tree fruit]]
[[File:Kigelia africana Bark.jpg|thumb|Bark in [[Kolkata]], [[West Bengal]], [[India]]]]
The genus name comes from the Mozambican [[Bantu language|Bantu]] name, ''kigeli-keia'', while the common names '''sausage tree'''<ref name=Saini>{{cite journal|url=http://nopr.niscair.res.in/bitstream/123456789/4043/1/NPR%208(2)%20190-197.pdf|title=''Kigelia africana'' (Lam.) Benth. — an overview|author=Sangita Saini, Harmeet Kaur, Bharat Verma, Ripudaman, and S. K. Singh|journal=Natural Product Radiance|volume=8|issue=2|year=2009|pages=190–197}}</ref> and '''cucumber tree'''<ref name=Saini/> refer to the long, [[sausage]]-like fruit. Its name in [[Afrikaans]] ''worsboom'' also means sausage tree, and its [[Arabic]] name means "the father of kit bags" (Roodt 1992).

==Growth==
It is a [[tree]] growing up to 20 m tall. The bark is grey and smooth at first, peeling on older trees. It can be as thick as 6 mm on a 15-cm branch (Roodt 1992). The wood is pale brown or yellowish, undifferentiated and not prone to cracking (Roodt 1992).

The tree is [[evergreen]] where rainfall occurs throughout the year, but [[deciduous]] where there is a long [[dry season]]. The [[leaf|leaves]] are opposite or in whorls of three, 30–50 cm long, [[pinnate]], with six to ten oval leaflets up to 20 cm long and 6 cm broad; the terminal leaflet can be either present or absent. The [[flower]]s (and later the fruit) hang down from branches on long flexible stems (2-6 metres long). Flowers are produced in [[panicle]]s; they are bell-shaped (similar to those of the [[Spathodea|African tulip tree]] but darker and more waxy), orange to reddish or purplish green, and about 10 cm wide. Individual flowers do not hang down but are oriented horizontally. Some birds are attracted to these flowers and the strong stems of each flower make ideal footholds. Their scent is most notable at night indicating that they are adapted to pollination by [[bat]]s, which visit them for pollen and nectar. They also remain open by day however, and are freely visited by many insect pollinators, particularly large species such as carpenter bees. 

The [[fruit]] is a woody [[berry (botany)|berry]] from 30–100 cm long and up to 18 cm broad; typically it weighs between 5 and 10 kg, and hangs down on long, rope-like [[peduncle (botany)|peduncles]]. The fruit pulp is fibrous and pulpy, and contains numerous [[seed]]s. It is eaten by several species of [[mammal]]s, including [[baboon]]s, [[bushpig]]s, [[savannah elephant]]s, [[giraffe]]s, [[hippopotamus]]es, [[monkey]]s, and [[Old World porcupine|porcupines]]. The seeds are dispersed in their dung. The seeds are also eaten by [[brown parrot]]s and [[brown-headed parrot]]s, and the foliage by elephants and [[greater kudu]] (Joffe 2003; del Hoyo et al. 1997). Introduced specimens in Australian parks are very popular with [[cockatoo]]s. The trees are also found in large numbers in Ingraham Institute NH-24 campus, Ghaziabad, Uttar Pradesh in India. Whether it is the same species has not yet been verified.

==Cultivation and uses==
An alcoholic beverage similar to [[beer]] is also made from it. The fresh fruit is [[poison]]ous and strongly [[purgative]]; fruit are prepared for consumption by drying, roasting or fermentation (Joffe 2003; McBurney 2004). In Botswana the timber is used for [[makoro]]s, yokes and oars (Roodt 1992). ''Kigelia'' is also used in a number of skin care products.

Planting sites should be selected carefully, as the falling fruit can cause serious injury to people, and damage vehicles parked under the trees.
The tree is widely grown as an [[Ornamental plant|ornamental tree]] in tropical regions for its decorative flowers and unusual fruit.

==Vernacular names==

In [[Kikuyu language|Kikuyu]]: ''muratina''; [[Swahili language|Swahili]]: ''mbungati'', ''mwegea'', ''mnyegea'', ''mvongonya'';<ref>''Standard Swahili Dictionary'' Oxford University Press, date unknown</ref> [[Hindi]] ''balam kheera'', ''hathi bailan''; [[Luo languages|Luo]] ''yago''; [[Malayalam]] ''shiva kundalam''; [[Tamil language|Tamil]] ''yaanai pudukan''; and [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]] ''pandoro''.
[[Tugen_people|Tugen]](kalenjin tribe): Rotinwo

{{italic title}}
{{taxobox

|image = Lasiodiscus mildbraedii, blare, Inhamitangabos.jpg

'''''Lasiodiscus''''', commonly known as '''red-hair bushes''', is a small plant genus in the family [[Rhamnaceae]]. It is endemic to Africa and its adjacent islands.

==Description==
The small trees have opposite, often asymmetric leaves. As with ''[[Colubrina]]'', the flower ovaries are surrounded by a nectariferous disc that fills the receptacle.

==Habitat==
They regularly occur in the understorey of tropical forests, or alternatively in swamp forest. One species, ''L. rozeirae'', is limited to mountain forest understorey.

==Relationships==
''Lasiodiscus'' is morphologically similar to ''[[Colubrina]]'', which occurs in the Neotropics, Asia and Afrotropics, but preliminary molecular analysis failed to group them as nearest relatives.<ref>A phylogenetic analysis of Rhamnaceae using RBCL and TRNL-F plastid DNA sequences, J.E. Richardson et al., American Journal of Botany, 87(9), 2000.</ref>

==Species==
There are 9 accepted species:
* ''[[Lasiodiscus chevalieri]]'' <small>Hutch.</small> – 
* ''[[Lasiodiscus fasciculiflorus]]'' <small>Engl.</small> – Sierra Leone to Nigeria, w Cameroon and D.R.C.
* ''[[Lasiodiscus holtzii]]'' <small>Engl.</small> – East Africa
* ''[[Lasiodiscus mannii]]'' <small>Hook.</small> – central Africa
* ''[[Lasiodiscus marmoratus]]'' <small>C.H. Wright</small> – Cameroon
* ''[[Lasiodiscus mildbraedii]]'' <small>Engl.</small> – African tropics and locally along east coast to [[South Africa]]
* ''[[Lasiodiscus pervillei]]'' <small>Baill.</small> – Africa, Madagascar, Mauritius, Réunion and Comores
: ''L. p. pervillei'' – widespread in Madagascar
: ''L. p. ferrugineus'' <small>(Verdc.) Figueiredo</small> – local and vulnerable in East Africa
* ''[[Lasiodiscus rozeirae]]'' <small>A.W. Exell</small> – São Tomé in Gulf of Guinea, vulnerable
* ''[[Lasiodiscus usambarensis]]'' <small>Engl.</small> – Usambara Mountains and locally to Zimbabwe

==Footnotes==
{{reflist}}

==External links==

* [http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=12&taxon_id=242443885 Madagascar Catalogue]
* [http://insidewood.lib.ncsu.edu/search/index.cfm?e=fulldescription&q=4328 Description of L. pervillei]

Note: The ''Lasiodiscidae'' belongs to the [[Foraminifera]] and Reichel (1945) described the genus ''Lasiodiscus''.

'''''Lasiodiscus fasciculiflorus''''' is a species of shrub or small tree in the family [[Rhamnaceae]] that is native to forests of the West African tropics.<ref name=burk>{{cite book |last1=Burkill |first1=H.M. |title=The useful plants of west tropical Africa | volume = 4 |date=1985 |publisher=Global Plants, Kew Gardens |url=http://plants.jstor.org/stable/10.5555/al.ap.upwta.4_772 |accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref> It occurs from [[Sierra Leone]] to [[Nigeria]] and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|D.R.C.]]. The bark is used in medicine to treat various ailments.<ref name=burk/>

'''''Lasiodiscus rozeirae''''' is a small tree in the family [[Rhamnaceae]]. It was discovered in 1954 in south-eastern [[São Tomé]] island in the [[Gulf of Guinea]] by Portuguese botanist [[Arnaldo Rozeira]]. No additional material has been obtained since, but remaining suitable habitat appears extensive.

==References==

* Figueiredo, E. 1996. Plant life: Lasiodiscus. Gulf of Guinea Conservation Newsletter 3: 6.

124.text:
{{About||the California Bay Laurel|Umbellularia|the Cherry Laurel|Prunus laurocerasus}}
{{Redirect|Laurels|the greyhound race|Laurels (greyhounds)}}
{{redirect|Sweet Bay|the town|Sweet Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador}}
{{speciesbox
| image = Bay leaf pair443.jpg
| image_caption = Bay laurel (''Laurus nobilis'') flower buds and leaves
| genus = Laurus
| species = nobilis
| authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}

'''''Laurus nobilis''''' is an aromatic [[evergreen]] [[tree]] or large [[shrub]] with green, [[Glossary of botanical terms#glabrous|glabrous]] [[leaves]], in the [[flowering plant]] family [[Lauraceae]]. It is native to the [[Mediterranean region]] and is used as [[bay leaf]] for seasoning in cooking. Its common names include  '''bay laurel''', '''sweet bay''', '''bay''' (esp. United Kingdom),<ref name=Stace>{{cite book|last=Stace|first=C. A.|authorlink = Stace, C. A.|year=2010|title=New Flora of the British Isles|edition=Third|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location = Cambridge, U.K.| isbn=9780521707725}}</ref>{{rp|84}} '''true laurel''', '''Grecian laurel''',<ref>{{cite book|author=Brown, R.W.|year=1956|title=Composition of scientific words: A manual of methods and a lexicon of materials for the practice of logotechnics|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> '''laurel tree''' or simply '''laurel'''. ''Laurus nobilis'' figures prominently in classical Greek, Roman, and Biblical culture.

Worldwide, many other kinds of plants in diverse families are also called "bay" or "laurel", generally due to similarity of foliage or aroma to ''Laurus nobilis'', and the full name is used for the California bay laurel (''[[Umbellularia]]''), also in the family Lauraceae.

==Description==
[[File:Laurus nobilis g1.jpg|thumb|left|160px|A laurel shrub]]
[[File:Laurus nobilis 111.JPG|thumb|left|160px|''Laurus nobilis'' in pot]]
The laurel is an [[evergreen]]  shrub or small tree, variable in size and sometimes reaching {{convert|7|–|18|m}} tall.<ref name=Stace/> The genus ''Laurus'' includes four accepted species,<ref name=TPL>{{cite web |title=The Plant List:''Laurus'' |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/search?q=Laurus |publisher=Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew and Missouri Botanic Garden |accessdate=20 March 2017 }}</ref> whose diagnostic key characters often overlap (Mabberley 1997).

The bay laurel is [[dioecy|dioecious]] ([[unisexual]]), with male and female [[flower]]s on separate plants.<ref name=Oxford /> Each flower is pale yellow-green, about 1 cm diameter, and they are borne in pairs beside a leaf. The leaves are glabrous, 6–12 cm long and 2–4 cm broad, with an [[entire leaf|entire]] (untoothed) margin. On some leaves the margin undulates.<ref name=Oxford /> The [[fruit]] is a small, shiny black berry-like [[drupe]] about 1 cm long<ref name=Oxford /> that contains one seed.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Konstantinidou, E. |author2=Takos, I. |author3=Merou, T. |year=2008|title=Desiccation and storage behavior of bay laurel (''Laurus nobilis'' L.) seeds|journal=European Journal of Forest Research|volume=127|issue=2|pages=125–131|doi=10.1007/s10342-007-0189-z}}</ref><ref name=Stace/>

A recent study found considerable genetic diversity within ''L. nobilis'', and that ''[[Laurus azorica|L. azorica]]'' is not genetically or morphologically distinct.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://link.springer.com/article/10.1023%2FA%3A1012654514381?LI=true|author=Arroyo–García, R., Martínez–Zapater, J. M.., Fernández Prieto, J. A., & Álvarez–Arbesú, R.|year=2001|title=AFLP evaluation of genetic similarity among laurel populations (''Laurus'' L.)|journal=Euphytica|volume=122|pages=155–164|doi=10.1023/A:1012654514381 }}</ref>

==Ecology==
{{further|Laurel forest}}
''Laurus nobilis'' is a widespread relic of the [[laurel forest]]s that originally covered much of the [[Mediterranean Basin]] when the climate of the region was more humid. With the drying of the Mediterranean during the [[Pliocene]] era, the laurel forests gradually retreated, and were replaced by the more drought-tolerant [[sclerophyll]] plant communities familiar today. Most of the last remaining laurel forests around the Mediterranean are believed to have disappeared approximately ten thousand years ago, although some remnants still persist in the mountains of southern Turkey, northern Syria, southern Spain, north-central Portugal, northern Morocco, Canary Islands and in [[Madeira]].

==Chemical constituents==
The most abundant component found in laurel [[essential oil]] is [[1,8-cineole]], also called eucalyptol. The leaves contain about 1.3% essential oils (''ol. lauri folii''), consisting of 45% eucalyptol, 12% other [[terpene]]s, 8-12% [[terpinyl acetate]], 3–4% [[sesquiterpene]]s, 3% [[methyleugenol]], and other α- and β-[[pinene]]s, [[phellandrene]], [[linalool]], [[geraniol]], and [[terpineol]], contains [[lauric acid]] also.<ref>AYBEN KILIC, HARZEMSAH HAFIZOGLU, HUBERT KOLLMANNSBERGER, AND SIEGFRIED NITZ (2004). Volatile Constituents and Key Odorants in Leaves, Buds, Flowers, and Fruits of Laurus nobilis L. Journal of Agricultural & Food Chemistry</ref>

Both essential and fatty oils are present in the fruit. The fruit is pressed and water-extracted to obtain these products.  The fruit contains up to 30% fatty oils and about 1% essential oils (terpenes, sesquiterpenes, [[alcohol]]s, and [[ketone]]s).

==Human uses==

===Food===
The plant is the source of several popular [[herbs]] and one [[spice]] used in a wide variety of recipes, particularly among Mediterranean cuisines.<ref name=Oxford>Vaughan, p.150.</ref> Most commonly, the aromatic [[Bay leaf|leaves]] are added whole to Italian pasta sauces.  They are typically removed from dishes before serving, unless used as a simple [[Garnish (food)|garnish]].<ref name=Green19>Green, p.19.</ref> 
Whole bay leaves have a long [[shelf life]] of about one year, under normal temperature and humidity.<ref name=Green19 /> Whole bay leaves are used almost exclusively as flavor agents during the food preparation stage.

Ground bay leaves, however, can be ingested safely and are often used in [[soup]]s and [[Stock (food)|stocks]], as well as being a common addition to a [[Bloody Mary (cocktail)|Bloody Mary]].<ref name=Green19 /> Dried laurel berries and pressed leaf oil can both be used as robust spices, and the wood can be burnt for strong [[smoking (food)|smoke flavoring]].<ref name=Green19 />

===Alternative medicine===
[[Image:LaurusNobilisEssOil.png|thumb|160px|''Laurus nobilis'' essential oil in clear glass vial]]
[[Aqueous solution|Aqueous]] [[extract]]s of bay laurel can also be used as [[astringent]]s and even as a reasonable salve for open wounds.<ref name=Nayak>Nayak, ''et al''. (2006).</ref>

In [[massage therapy]], the essential oil of bay laurel is reputed to alleviate arthritis and rheumatism, while in [[aromatherapy]], it is used to treat earaches and high blood pressure.<ref name=AllNat>{{cite web |url=http://www.allnatural.net/herbpages/bay-laurel.shtml |title=Bay Laurel: Laurus nobilis |author=Encyclopedia of Herbs |publisher=AllNatural.net |accessdate=2010-12-31 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101119205731/http://allnatural.net/herbpages/bay-laurel.shtml| archivedate= 19 November 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> A traditional [[folk medicine|folk remedy]] for rashes caused by [[poison ivy]], [[poison oak]], and [[stinging nettle]] is a [[poultice]] soaked in boiled bay leaves.<ref>Wood, p.43.</ref>

The chemical compound lauroside B isolated from ''Laurus nobilis'' is an inhibitor of human [[melanoma]] (skin cancer) cell proliferation at high concentrations in-vitro.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21188975 | year = 2011 | last1 = Panza | first1 = E | last2 = Tersigni | first2 = M | last3 = Iorizzi | first3 = M | last4 = Zollo | first4 = F | last5 = De Marino | first5 = S | last6 = Festa | first6 = C | last7 = Napolitano | first7 = M | last8 = Castello | first8 = G | last9 = Ialenti | first9 = A | displayauthors = 8| title = Lauroside B, a megastigmane glycoside from Laurus nobilis (bay laurel) leaves, induces apoptosis in human melanoma cell lines by inhibiting NF-κB activation | volume = 74 | issue = 2 | pages = 228–33 | doi = 10.1021/np100688g | journal = Journal of Natural Products}}</ref>

===Other uses===
Bay is widely cultivated as an [[ornamental plant]] in regions with [[Mediterranean climate|Mediterranean]] or [[oceanic climate]]s, and as a house plant or greenhouse plant in colder regions. It is used in [[topiary]] to create single erect stems with ball-shaped, box-shaped or twisted crowns; also for low hedges. Together with a gold form, ''L. nobilis'' 'Aurea',<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector – ''Laurus nobilis'' 'Aurea'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1124|publisher=Royal Horticultural Society|accessdate=21 May 2013}}</ref> it has gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector – ''Laurus nobilis''|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1123|publisher=Royal Horticultural Society|accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref>

Laurel oil is a main ingredient, and the distinguishing characteristic of [[Aleppo soap]].

===Symbolism===
[[File:Lorbeerkranz Zypern rem.jpg|thumb|A victor's golden laurel wreath, probably from Cyprus, 4th/3rd century BC]]

;Europe
Bay laurel was used to fashion the [[laurel wreath]] of [[ancient Greece]], a symbol of highest status. A wreath of bay laurels was given as the prize at the [[Pythian Games]] because the games were in honor of [[Apollo]], and the laurel was one of his symbols.

The symbolism carried over to [[Roman culture]], which held the laurel as a symbol of victory.<ref>De Cleene, p.129.</ref> It is also the source of the words ''[[bachelor's degree|baccalaureate]]'' and ''[[poet laureate]]'', as well as the expressions "assume the laurel" and "resting on one's laurels". [[Ovid]] tells the story in the ''[[Metamorphoses]]'' that laurel tree was first formed when the [[nymph]] [[Daphne (mythology)|Daphne]] was changed into a laurel tree because of [[Apollo and Daphne|Apollo's pursuit]] of her. ''Daphne'' is the Greek name for the tree.<ref>Edith Hamilton, Mythology: Timeless Tales of Gods and Heroes (1942)</ref>

;East Asia
An early Chinese [[etiological myth]] for the [[phases of the moon]] involved a great forest or tree which quickly grew and lost its leaves and flowers every month. After the [[Sui dynasty|Sui]] and [[Tang dynasty|Tang]] [[list of Chinese dynasties|dynasties]], this was sometimes connected to a woodsman named [[Wu Gang]], sentenced to cut at a self-repairing tree as a punishment for varying offenses. The tree was originally identified as a {{lang|zh|{{linktext|桂}}}} (''guì'') and described in the terms of the [[sweet osmanthus|osmanthus]]<!--sources at Wu Gang--> (''Osmanthus fragrans'', now known in Chinese as the {{lang|zh|{{linktext|桂花}}}} or "''gui'' flower"), whose blossoms are still used to flavor [[osmanthus wine|wine]] and confections for the [[Mid-Autumn Festival]]. However, in English, it is often associated with the more well-known [[Chinese cassia|cassia]] (''Cinnamomum cassia'', now known in Chinese as the {{lang|zh|{{linktext|肉桂}}}} or "meat ''gui''") while, in modern Chinese, it has instead become associated with the Mediterranean laurel. By the [[Qing dynasty]], the ''[[chengyu]]'' "pluck osmanthus in the [[moon toad|Toad]] Palace" ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|蟾宫折桂}}}}, ''Chángōng zhé guì'') meant passing the [[keju|imperial examination]]s,<ref name=moooon>Brendon, Juliet & al. ''The Moon Year: A Record of Chinese Customs and Festivals'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=3vUZMgM5bhQC&pg=PA410 p. 410]. Kelly & Walsh, 1927. Reprinted Routledge (Abingdon), 2011. Accessed 13 November 2013.</ref><ref>Zdic. "{{lang|zh|[http://www.zdic.net/c/e/a7/196726.htm 蟾宫折桂]}}". 2013. Accessed 13 November 2013. {{zh icon}}</ref><ref>{{lang|zh|杜近芳}} [Du Jinfang]. [http://tieba.baidu.com/p/84960300?pn=2 {{lang|zh|《红楼梦汉英习语词典》}}] ["A Dictionary of Chinese Idioms in the ''[[Dream of the Red Chamber]]''"]. 2003. Accessed 13 November 2013. {{en icon}} & {{zh icon}}</ref> which were held around the time of the lunar festival. The similar association in Europe of laurels with victory and success led to its translation into Chinese as the {{lang|zh|{{linktext|月桂}}}} or "Moon ''gui''".

'''''Livistona carinensis''''' is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the [[Arecaceae]] family. It is one of the [[List of Arecaceae genera#Tribe Corypheae|fan palms]]. Its [[leaf|leaves]] are distinguished by an armed petiole terminating in a rounded, costapalmate fan of numerous leaflets.
''Livistona carinensis'' is found in [[Djibouti]], [[Somalia]], and [[Yemen]], and is threatened by [[habitat loss]].

* ''Boscia caffra'' <small>Sond.</small>
* ''Niebuhria pedunculosa'' <small>Hochst.</small><ref name=sanbi>{{cite web |last1=Foden| first1= W., & Potter, L |title=Maerua racemulosa (A.DC.) Gilg & Gilg-Ben. |url=http://redlist.sanbi.org/species.php?species=1129-16 |website=Red List of South African Plants |date= |publisher=SANBI|accessdate=2 November 2014}}</ref>
}}
'''''Maerua racemulosa''''' is a species of [[plant]] in the [[Capparaceae]] family, which is almost endemic to South Africa's coastal regions,<ref name=kcp>{{cite book |last=Palgrave |first=K.C. |title=Trees of Southern Africa |year=1984 |publisher=Struik |location=Cape Town |isbn=0-86977-081-0 |pages=196–197}}</ref> where it is a constituent of shady forest [[understory]] and [[valley bushveld]]. They are shrubs or small trees, with mostly simple leaves, and entire margins.<ref name=kcp/> They flower profusely in mid-winter. Each flower bears numerous white filaments and a purple style, but no petals. The round fruit appear from August to October.<ref name=kcp/> These are yellow when ripe and 1 cm in diameter. It is a food plant for some species of ''[[Colotis]]'' butterfly.

The '''false assegai''' (''Maesa lanceolata'') is a tree species that is widespread in the [[Afrotropical ecozone|Afrotropics]], including [[Madagascar]].<ref name=apd>{{cite web |title=Maesa lanceolata Forssk. |url=http://www.ville-ge.ch/musinfo/bd/cjb/africa/details.php?langue=an&id=175679 |website=African Plant Database | publisher = Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques & SANBI |accessdate=25 November 2014}}</ref> It occurs from the southern [[Arabian Peninsula]], southwards to the [[Eastern Cape]], South Africa. It grows on stream verges, river banks and forest verges, where it is often a pioneer plant.

'''''Microberlinia''''' is a [[genus]] in the [[family]] [[Fabaceae]] ([[legume]] family). It includes two [[species]] of [[tree]] native to [[Cameroon]] and [[Gabon]] in [[West Africa]]. The common name is ''zingana'' or [[zebrawood]].

131.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Microberlinia brazzavillensis''
|status = VU
|status_system = iucn2.3
|status_ref = <ref name=IUCN>{{IUCN|id=33184|taxon=Microberlinia brazzavillensis|assessor=World Conservation Monitoring Centre|assessment_year=1998|version=2013.1|accessdate=10 September 2013}}</ref>
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Microberlinia]]''
|species = '''''M. brazzavillensis'''''
|binomial = ''Microberlinia brazzavillensis''
|binomial_authority = [[A.Chev.]]
}}

'''''Microberlinia brazzavillensis''''' is a tree in the family [[Fabaceae]], found in [[West Africa]]. It is also called '''zebrano''',{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} '''zingana''',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?401518 |title=USDA GRIN Taxonomy |accessdate=21 November 2014}}</ref> and '''allen ele''',{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} and is commonly sold in the US as [[zebrawood]]. The [[tree]] is tall and straight, growing up to 40 m in height with a diameter of up to 1 m. The [[flower]] has white petals and, as other legumes do, the tree produces pods.

Concern is expressed due to the tree's rarity in some areas of its native [[tropics|tropical]] habitat in [[Gabon]] and [[Cameroon]], typically less than one tree per square kilometre. It is listed on The [[IUCN Red List]] of Threatened Species as [[Vulnerable species|vulnerable]]<ref>http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/33184/0</ref>

The wood is pale yellow to almost white with dark streaks, and it takes a nice polish. The wood is valued by some for its striped figure and is used in furniture. The wood is very tough and durable, and it can be used for objects such as tool handles and sporting equipment. It is resistant to [[termite]]s and wood-rotting [[fungus|fungi]].

==External links==
*[http://www.iucnredlist.org/details/33184/0 IUCN Red List: ''Microberlinia brazzavillensis'']
*[http://www.wood-database.com/lumber-identification/hardwoods/zebrawood/ Woods of the World: Zebrawood, Zebrano]

132.text:
{{taxobox

|image_caption = Tree in flower

| status = EN | status_system = IUCN2.3

{{infobox color	
|title=Wenge
|textcolor=white	
|hex=645452
|r=100|g=84|b=82|	
|c=0.00|m=0.16|y=0.18|k=0.61
|h=7|s=18|v=39	
|source=[http://www.99colors.net/name/wenge]}}
[[File:Wenge01.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Quartersawn surface]]

'''''Millettia laurentii''''' is a [[Fabaceae|legume tree]] from Africa and native to the [[Republic of Congo]], the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]], [[Cameroon]], [[Gabon]] and [[Equatorial Guinea]]. The species is listed as "[[Endangered species|endangered]]" in the [[IUCN Red List endangered species (Plantae)|IUCN Red List]], principally due to destruction of its habitat and [[over-exploitation]] for timber.<ref name=IUCN>{{IUCN2014.3| id = 33219| title = Millettia laurentii| assessor = African Regional Workshop (Conservation| assessor2 = Sustainable Management of Trees, Zimbabwe, July 1996)| last-assessor-amp = yes| year = 1998| downloaded = 2 March 2015}}</ref> '''Wenge''', a dark colored wood, is the product of ''Millettia laurentii''. Other names sometimes used for wenge include '''African rosewood''' ([[African rosewood|ambiguous]]), '''faux ebony''', '''dikela''', '''mibotu''', '''bokonge''', and '''awong'''. The wood's distinctive color is standardized as a "wenge" color in many systems.

==Wood==
'''Wenge''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|w|ɛ|ŋ|ɡ|eɪ}} {{respell|WENG|gay}}) is a tropical timber, very dark in color with a distinctive figure and a strong [[Andira inermis|partridge wood]] pattern. The wood is heavy and hard, suitable for flooring and staircases.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}}

Several [[musical instrument]] makers employ wenge in their products. [[Alembic Inc.|Alembic Guitars]] have used this wood on numerous occasions for custom instruments. [[Mosrite]] used it for bodies of their Brass Rail models. [[Ibanez]] and Cort use it for the five-piece necks of some of their electric basses. [[Warwick (bass guitar)|Warwick]] electric basses use [[Forest Stewardship Council|FSC]] sourced wenge for fingerboards and necks as of 2013. [http://www.conklinguitars.com/index.html Conklin Guitars and Basses] makes use of wenge for bodies, fingerboards and necks. [http://crushdrum.com/drumsets/limited-reserve-birch/limited-reserve-wenge/ Crush drums] use it on their limited reserve wenge drum kit. It is also used by Yamaha as the center ply of their Absolute Hybrid Maple drums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://usa.yamaha.com/products/musical-instruments/drums/ac-drumsets/absolute_hm/ |title=Absolute Hybrid Maple - Acoustic Drum Sets - Drums - Musical Instruments - Products - Yamaha United States |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=Yamaha United States |publisher=Yamaha Corporation of America |access-date=25 August 2015 |quote=Hybrid Maple Shell (center Wenge ply) }}</ref>

The wood is popular in [[segmented turning|segmented woodturning]] because of its dimensional stability and color contrast when mixed with lighter woods such as [[maple]]. This makes it especially sought after in the manufacture of high-end wood [[Walking stick|canes]].

The wood is sometimes used in the making of [[archery]] [[Bow (weapon)|bow]]s, particularly as a laminate in the production of [[flatbow]]s. It can also be used in the making of rails or pin blocks on [[hammered dulcimer]]s.

==Health hazards==
The dust produced when cutting or sanding wenge can cause [[dermatitis]] similar to the effects of [[poison ivy]]  and is an irritant to the eyes. The dust also can cause respiratory problems and drowsiness.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}} Splinters are [[sepsis|septic]], similar to those of greenheart (the wood of ''[[Chlorocardium|Chlorocardium rodiei]]'').

==See also==
*[[Millettia leucantha]]
*[[Senna siamea]]

133.text:
{{italictitle}}{{Taxobox
| name = Panga panga
| status = 
| image = Millettia stuhlmannii in Foster BG, W Cutler, crop.jpg
| image_caption = 
| domain = 
| regnum = [[Plantae]]
| unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
| ordo = [[Fabales]]
| familia = [[Fabaceae]]
| genus = ''[[Millettia]]''
| species = '''''M. stuhlmannii'''''
| binomial = ''Millettia stuhlmannii''
| binomial_authority = [[Paul Hermann Wilhelm Taubert|Taub.]]
| range_map = 
| range_map_caption = 
| synonyms = 
}}
'''''Millettia stuhlmannii''''', commonly known as '''panga panga''', is a well-known species of timber tree<ref name=plantz>{{cite web |last1=Mutshinyalo |first1=Thompson |title=Millettia stuhlmannii Taub. |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantklm/milletstuhl.htm |website=plantzafrica.com |publisher=SANBI |date= June 2011 | accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> that is native to the southeastern [[Afrotropical ecozone|Afrotropics]]. The alternative name '''partridge wood''' refers to the light and dark patterns of its heartwood, which is said to form ‘partridge-breast’ figures.<ref name=prota/> The wood of the tropical species ''[[Millettia laurentii|M. laurentii]]'' has similar qualities and uses, but is slightly darker, and lacks the copious yellowish white [[resin]] of the heartwood vessels.<ref name=prota/> Its foliage is similar to that of ''[[Pterocarpus rotundifolius]]'', and it may be confused with the latter when observed from a distance.

==Range and status==
It is found in southern [[Tanzania]], eastern [[Zimbabwe]],  [[Mozambique]]<ref name=prota>{{cite web |last1=Lemmens |first1=R. H. M. J. |title=Millettia stuhlmannii Taub. |url=http://database.prota.org/PROTAhtml/Millettia%20stuhlmannii_En.htm |website=Prota 7(1): Timbers/Bois d’œuvre 1 |publisher=PROTA, Wageningen, Netherlands |accessdate=19 March 2015 |date=2008}}</ref> and very locally in the [[Venda]] region of South Africa.<ref>At Ha-Makhuvha (22°46'S 30°23'E) where 159 specimens were left in 2007. See: T. Mutshinyalo, 2011.</ref> Though locally common or even dominant, over-utilization may deplete many populations. Besides harvesting for timber, their numbers are also depleted by unsustainable harvesting of bark and roots, which are employed for medicinal and magical purposes.<ref name=plantz/> 

==Description==
The large compound leaves are greenish above and bluish green below, with one terminal and 7 to 9 pairs of opposite leaflets.<ref name=plantz/> It is deciduous, with the foliage emerging before flowering time. The large, lilac flowers<ref name=plantz/> appear from November to January as seasonal rains commence,<ref name=prota/> and are produced on long, pendulous racemes. The woody seed pods are flat and velvety, and release their seeds when they split open due to increasing torsion.<ref name=plantz/> The [[root nodule]]s have a symbiotic relationship with [[Rhizobia|rhizobial bacteria]].<ref name=prota/>

==Isolated chemicals==
The [[flavonoid]] [[robinetin]] has been isolated in the heartwood and the [[α-amino acid]] (''S'')-[[canavanine]] has been isolated from the seeds.<ref name=phyt>{{cite book |last1= ILDIS, International Legume Database and Information Service and CHCD, Chapman & Hall Chemical Database |first1=compiler, I.W. Southon; editors, F.A. Bisby, J. Buckingham, J.B. Harborne; botanical data, J.L. Zarucchi ... [et al.]; chemical data, Chapman & Hall Chemical Database; phytochemical database, R.J. White ... [et al.] | title=Phytochemical dictionary of the Leguminosae |date=1994 |publisher=Chapman & Hall |location=London |isbn=0412397706 |edition=1st |accessdate= }}</ref>

==Timber value and trade==
The highly priced and valued wood has a range of applications, including flooring, furniture, musical instruments and boat building. The heartwood is very durable, as it is not affected by [[fungus|fungi]], [[dry-wood borer]]s or [[termite]]s, but the sapwood is vulnerable to [[powderpost beetle]]s.<ref name=prota/> It is locally sawn, and exported legally from Tanzania and Mozambique, especially [[Zambezia Province]].<ref name=prota/> It accounts for some 45% of timber legally exported from Tanzania, and much of it is bought by Chinese buyers, who in turn re-export a portion to the [[Western World|West]].<ref name=prota/>

==References==
{{reflist}}

[[Category:Millettia|stuhlmannii]]
133.title: Millettia stuhlmannii

'''''Moringa ovalifolia''''' is an [[endemic]] tree of [[Namibia]] and southwestern [[Angola]].<ref>[http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantklm/moringoval.htm]</ref>

It is a succulent-stemmed, erect tree found in [[desert]] and semi-desert areas. It occurs on rocky escarpment passes leading to the [[Namib Desert]]. The 'Sprokieswoud' of [[Etosha National Park]] is made up of dense stands of these trees.

137.text:
{{Speciesbox
| taxon = Moringa stenopetala
| image     = Moringa stenopetala.jpg
| authority = ([[Edmund Gilbert Baker|Baker f.]]) [[Georg Cufodontis|Cufod.]]<ref name="grin1"> Under its current treatment of ''Moringa stenopetala'' (from its basionym, ''Donaldsonia stenopetala''), this species was published in ''Senckenbergiana Biologica'' 38: 407. 1957. {{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?312850 |title=''Moringa stenopetala'' information from NPGS/GRIN |author=[[Germplasm Resources Information Network|GRIN]] |work=Taxonomy for Plants |publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]], [[Agricultural Research Service|ARS]], National Genetic Resources Program |location=National Germplasm Resources Laboratory, [[Beltsville, Maryland]] |date=May 22, 1997 |accessdate=January 1, 2012}}</ref>
| synonyms  = *''Donaldsonia stenopetala'' <small>Baker f.</small> ([[basionym]])
* ''Moringa streptocarpa'' <small>[[Emilio Chiovenda|Chiov.]]</small>
|synonyms_ref = <ref name=grin1/><ref name="grin2"> The basionym of ''Moringa stenopetala'', ''Donaldsonia stenopetala'', was first described and published in ''Journal of Botany, British and Foreign'' 1896: 53. 1896. {{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?424400 |title=''Donaldsonia stenopetala'' information from NPGS/GRIN |author=GRIN |work=Taxonomy for Plants |publisher=USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program |location=National Germplasm Resources Laboratory, Beltsville, Maryland |date=June 28, 2002 |accessdate=January 1, 2012}}</ref>
}}

'''''Moringa stenopetala''''', commonly called the '''cabbage-tree'''<ref name=grin1/> (along with a number of other species), is a tree in the ''[[Moringa]]'' genus of flowering plants, native to [[Kenya]] and [[Ethiopia]].<ref name="AAA2015">{{cite journal | vauthors = Leone A, Spada A, Battezzati A, Schiraldi A, Aristil J, Bertoli S | title = Cultivation, Genetic, Ethnopharmacology, Phytochemistry and Pharmacology of ''Moringa oleifera'' Leaves: An Overview | journal = International Journal of Molecular Sciences | volume = 16 | pages = 12791–12835 | year = 2015 | doi = 10.3390/ijms160612791 | pmid=26057747 | pmc=4490473}}</ref>  It is now extirpated in the wild in Ethiopia, though still grown there as a crop on the terraces built to conserve water high up the mountains.<ref name=grin1/> It is a multipurpose tree producing edible leaves, seeds used for the purification of water, and traditional medicinal products.

==History==
The cabbage-tree was planted by agriculturalists on the complex system of terraces built high up in the [[Ethiopian Highlands]], where they became domesticated and were bred to improve productivity, the taste of their leaves, and the size of their seeds. Since then, the improved trees have been introduced into other areas such as the [[Great Rift Valley, Kenya|Rift Valley]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Samia Al Azharia Jahn |year=1991 |title=The Traditional Domestication of a Multipurpose Tree ''Moringa stenopetala'' (Bak.f.) Cuf. in the Ethiopian Rift Valley |journal=Ambio |volume=20 |issue=6 |pages=244–247 |jstor=4313833 }}</ref>

==Description==
The cabbage-tree is a small tree up to {{convert|12|m|0|abbr=on}}, with a many-branched crown and sometimes with multiple trunks. The leaves are bipinnate or tripinnate, with about five pairs of pinnae and three to nine elliptic or ovate leaflets on each pinna. The fragrant flowers have creamy-pink sepals, white or  yellow petals, and white stamens. The fruits are long reddish pods with a greyish bloom.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.seedvendor.com/50--seeds-moringa-stenopetala--african-moringa-cabbage--tr50.html |title=''Moringa stenopetala'': African Moringa |publisher=Seed People |accessdate=2013-12-17}}</ref>

==Uses==
''M. stenopetala'' is mostly known for its importance as a nutritious [[vegetable]] food crop in the [[terrace (agriculture)|terraced]] fields of [[Konso]], [[Ethiopia]]. In this way, it is similar to its Indian relative, ''[[Moringa oleifera]]''.<ref>[http://www.birdlife.org/datazone/sitefactsheet.php?id=6297 "Birdlife Data Zone: Konso - Segen"], Birdlife International website . Retrieved 15 January 2011.</ref><ref name="TreesforLife">{{cite web |url=http://www.treesforlife.org/documents/moringa/presentation/Moringa%20Presentation%20%28General%29%20screen.pdf |title=The Moringa Tree ''Moringa oleifera'' |publisher=Trees for Life International |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref> It is also used for shading of ''[[Capsicum]]'' and ''[[Sorghum]]'' crops, as a [[companion planting|companion plant]];<ref name=grin1/> and additionally in [[folk medicine]].<ref name=grin1/>

Another use is the clarification and purification of water to make it potable. A powder made by grinding the seeds is found to be more effective at coagulating substances in suspension than the seeds of the closely related [[Moringa oleifera|horseradish tree]] (''M. oleifera''), which is used for this purpose in India.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.3362/0262-8104.1985.019 |title=Water purification with ''Moringa'' seeds |year=1985 |last1=Desa |first1=Dian |journal=Waterlines |volume=3 |issue=4 |pages=22–3}}</ref>

138.text:
{{taxobox
|image= Mayombe-parasolier.JPG
|image_caption=''Musanga cecropioides'' tree in the [[Mayombe]] region
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Rosales]]
|familia = [[Urticaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Musanga]]''
|species = '''''M. cecropioides'''''
|binomial = ''Musanga cecropioides''
|binomial_authority = [[Robert Brown (Scottish botanist from Montrose)|R.Br.]] & [[Henry Tedlie|Tedlie]]
|}}

'''''Musanga cecropioides''''', the '''African corkwood tree''' or '''umbrella tree''', is found in [[tropical Africa]] from [[Sierra Leone]] south to [[Angola]] and east to [[Uganda]]. It is typical in [[secondary forest]]s.

This tree is also known as ''Parasolier'', ''N'Govoge'', ''Govwi'', ''Doe'', ''kombo-kombo'', ''musanga'', and ''musanda''.

==Description==
''Musanga cecropioides'' can reach a height of {{convert|100|ft|m|0}} with a diameter of {{convert|1|-|3|ft|m}}. Its trunk has a pale whitish/yellow tone with a rough, granular texture.

==Ecology==
''Musanga cecropioides'' is a pioneer species and readily springs up in newly cleared patches of forest. In Nigeria it is joined in these locations by the [[Rauvolfia vomitoria|poison devil's-pepper]] (''Rauvolfia vomitoria''), the [[Terminalia ivorensis|Ivory Coast almond]] (''Terminalia ivorensis'') and the [[Harungana|dragon's blood tree]] (''Harungana madagascariensis''). Five years later, ''M. cecropioides'' has become dominant, with a closed canopy at {{convert|10|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}<ref name=Aweto>{{cite book|author=Aweto, Albert O. |title=Shifting Cultivation and Secondary Succession in the Tropics |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HNEqOpRnmkkC&pg=PA78 |year=2013 |publisher=CABI |isbn=978-1-78064-043-3 |page=78}}</ref>

==Uses==
Uses of the wood from the African corkwood tree range from flotation devices, such as rafts, to toys. The wood of the African corkwood tree has a frail concreteness and has a tendency to mold and tarnish easily. The tree has traditional medical uses among the [[Bantu peoples]] of the Central African Republic, Gabon and Equatorial Guinea.<ref>{{cite book|author=Atta-ur- Rahman|title=Studies in Natural Products Chemistry: Bioactive Natural Products (Part L)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BURF2WXdVzEC&pg=PA803 |year=2011|publisher=Gulf Professional Publishing |isbn=978-0-08-045847-2 |pages=803–805}}</ref>

{{taxobox
