|}}
'''''Podococcus''''' is a genus of [[Arecaceae|palms]] found in tropical [[Africa]].  It includes two recognized species:<ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/qsearch.do;jsessionid=62AC7885FED0FFC2887245D7698C4AB8 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families]</ref><ref>van Valkenburg, J.L.C.H. & Sunderland, T.C.H. (2008). A revision of the genus ''Podococcus'' (Arecaceae). Kew Bulletin 63: 251-260.</ref><ref>Sosef, M.S.M. & al. (2006). Check-list des plantes vasculaires du Gabon. Scripta Botanica Belgica 35: 1-438.</ref>

#''[[Podococcus acaulis]]'' <small>Hua</small> - Gabon, Congo-Brazzaville
#''[[Podococcus barteri]]''<small>G. Mann & H. Wendl.</small> - Gabon, Congo-Brazzaville, Nigeria, Cameroon, Equatorial Guinea, Cabinda, Zaire

146.text:
{{Speciesbox
| image = Prunus_sappling.jpg
| status = VU
| status_system = IUCN3.1
| display_parents = 2
| parent = Prunus sect. Laurocerasus
| taxon = Prunus africana
| authority = ([[Joseph Dalton Hooker|Hook.f.]]) [[Cornelis Kalkman|Kalkman]]
| synonyms = ''Pygeum africanum'' <small>Hook.f.</small>
| synonyms_ref = <ref name="mmpnd">{{Cite web | url = http://www.ars-grin.gov/misc/mmpnd/Prunus_Pt1.html | title = Sorting ''Prunus'' Names | work = Multilingual Multiscript Plant Name Database | accessdate = November 3, 2010 }}</ref>
}}

'''''Prunus africana''''', the African cherry, has a wide distribution in Africa, occurring in montane regions of central and southern Africa and on the islands of Bioko, São-Tomé, and Grande Comore (Kalkman, 1965).<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Kalkman, C., 1965. The Old-World species of Prunus subg. Laurocerasus including those formerly referred to Pygeum.|journal=Blumea|volume=13|pages= 1–174}}</ref> It can be found at {{convert|900–3400|m|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} above sea level. It is a canopy tree 30–40 m in height. Large-diameter trees have impressive, spreading crowns. It requires a moist climate, {{convert|900–3400|mm|in|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} annual rainfall, and is moderately frost-tolerant.<ref name=prunafr>{{cite web | title=Prunus africana (Hook.f.) Kalkman |  work=Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN) Taxonomy for Plants | author=U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) | url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?29828 }}</ref><ref name=pygafr>{{cite web | title=Pygeum africanum Hook.f. |  work=Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN) Taxonomy for Plants | author=U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) | url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?30392 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | first=Najma | last=Dharani | title=Field Guide to Common Trees and Shrubs of East Africa | publisher=New Holland | year=2002 |page=150 | isbn=1-86872-640-1}} Previewable Google Books.</ref><ref name=sustain>{{cite web | last=Cunningham | first=A.B. |author2=Mbenkum, F.T.  | title=Sustainability of harvesting Prunus africana bark in Cameroon: A medicinal plant in international trade | work=People and Plants working papers | publisher=Division of Ecological Sciences, UNESCO | date=May 1993 | url=http://peopleandplants.org/whatweproduce/Workingpapers/pdf/wp2.pdf | format=pdf }}</ref><ref name=who>{{cite book |author1=World Health Organization |author2=Inc. NetLibrary | title=WHO Monographs on Selected Medicinal Plants: Volume 2 | publisher=World Health Organization | year=2002 | location=Geneva | isbn=92-4-154537-2 |page=246 }} Previewable Google Books.</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Nonjinge | first=Siyabulela | title=Prunus africana (Hook.f.) Kalkman | work=PlantZAfrica.com | publisher=South African National Biodiversity Institute | date=October 2006 | url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantnop/prunusafri.htm }}</ref> ''P. africana'' appears to be a light-demanding, secondary-forest species.

The bark is black to brown, corrugated or fissured, and scaly, fissuring in a characteristic rectangular pattern. The [[leaf|leaves]] are alternate, simple, {{convert|8-20|cm|abbr=on}} long, elliptical, bluntly or acutely pointed, [[glabrous]], and dark green above, pale green below, with mildly serrated margins. A central vein is depressed on top, prominent on the bottom. The {{convert|2|cm|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} [[Petiole (botany)|petiole]] is pink or red. The [[flower]]s are androgynous, 10-20 [[stamen]]s, insect-pollinated, {{convert|3–8|cm|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}, greenish white or buff, and are distributed in {{convert|70|mm|abbr=on}} [[Axillary bud|axillary]] [[raceme]]s. The plant flowers October through May. The [[fruit]] is a drupe, red to brown, {{convert|7–13|mm|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}, wider than long, two-lobed, with a seed in each lobe. It grows in bunches ripening September through November, several months after pollination.

==Ecology==
[[File:Prunus africana nectaries.jpg|thumb|left|Extrafloral nectaries along the leaf margin]]
As with other members of the genus ''[[Prunus]]'', ''Prunus africana'' possesses [[extrafloral nectaries]] that provide antiherbivore insects with a nutrient source in return for protecting the foliage.

In addition to its value for its timber and its medicinal uses, ''Prunus africana'' is an important food source for frugivorous birds and mammals  [[Dian Fossey]] reports of the [[mountain gorilla]]:<ref>{{cite book | first=Dian | last=Fossey | authorlink=Dian Fossey | title=Gorillas in the Mist | publisher=Houghton Mifflin Books | year=2000 |page=146 | isbn=0-618-08360-X }}</ref> "The northwestern slopes of [[Visoke]] offered several ridges of ''Pygeum africanum'' .... The fruits of this tree are highly favored by gorillas." ''East African Mammals'' reports that stands of ''Pygeum'' are the habitat of the rare [[Carruther's mountain squirrel]] and asserts, "This forest type tends to have a rather broken canopy with many trees smothered in climbers and dense tangles of undergrowth."<ref>{{cite book | first=Jonathan | last=Kingdon | title=East African Mammals: an Atlas of Evolution in Africa: Volume IIB | publisher=University of Chicago Press | place=Chicago | year=1984 |page=389 | isbn=0-226-43718-3 }}</ref> 
It is currently protected under appendix II of [[CITES]]<ref>http://www.cites.org/eng/app/e-appendices.pdf</ref>[https://cites.org/eng/prog/african_cherry.php] since 16 February 1995 and in South Africa under the National Forest Act (Act 84) of 1998.<ref name="dwaf">{{cite web
|url=http://www2.dwaf.gov.za/dwaf/cmsdocs/4116___poster%20protected%20trees.pdf
|title=Protected Trees
|date=30 June 2013
|publisher=Department of Water Affairs and Forestry, Republic of South Africa}}</ref>

Large numbers of trees are harvested its bark to meet the international demand for its medicinal qualities. Early studies on the effects of bark harvest showed that the harvest affected population structure, increased mortality and decreased fecundity (Parrott and Parrott, 1989;<ref>Parrott J., Parrott, H., 1989. Report on the conservation of ''Prunus'' (''Pygeum africanum'') in Cameroon. Unpublished report prepared for the International Council for Bird Preservation (now Birdlife International).</ref> Cunningham and Mbenkum, 1993;<ref name="sustain" /> Ewusi et al., 1992;<ref>Ewusi, B.N., Eben-Ebai, S., Asanga, C.A., Nkongo, J.B.N., 1992. An evaluation of the quantity and distribution of ''Pygeum africanum'' on the slopes of Mount Cameroon. Unpublished report prepared for Plantecam-Medicam.</ref> Walter and Rakotonirina, 1995<ref>Walter, S., Rakotonorina, J.C.R., 1995. L’exploitation of ''Prunus africana'' à Madagascar. Rapportt à P. Zahemena et au Département de l’Eau and des Forêts, Antannarivo, Madagascar.</ref>). However, quantitative studies to examine specific life history parameters and possible sustainable harvesting practices were begun only recently (Stewart, 2001<ref>Stewart, K.M., 2001. The commercial bark harvest of ''Prunus africana'' on Mount Oku, Cameroon: effects on traditional uses and population dynamics. Ph.D. Dissertation, Florida International University.</ref> and 2009<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Stewart, K. M.  2009.  Effects of bark harvest and other human activity on populations of the African cherry (Prunus africana) on Mount Oku, Cameroon.|journal=Forest Ecology and Management|volume=258| pages = 1121–1128}}</ref>). In these later studies, the combined factors of mortalities of a large percentage of reproductive trees (especially the largest ones), highly reduced fruit production and poor seedling survival seem to suggest a bleak prognosis for future regeneration and long-term persistence of the species in harvested populations.

==Uses==

===Traditional medicine===
[[File:Prunus africana MS 3588.jpg|thumb|right|''P. africana'' with stripped bark]]
The species has a long history of traditional uses. The bark is used for fevers, malaria, wound dressing, arrow poison, stomach pain, purgative, kidney disease, appetite stimulant, gonorrhoea, and insanity.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Stewart | first1 = KM | year = 2003 | title = "The African cherry (Prunus africana): can lessons be learned from an over-exploited medicinal tree?." [Review] | url = | journal = [[Journal of Ethnopharmacology]] | volume = 89 | issue = 1| pages = 3–13 | doi=10.1016/j.jep.2003.08.002}}</ref> The pharmacology and traditional uses of the species is reviewed in Stewart (2003a and 2003 b) <ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|author=Stewart K.M. |year=  2003|title=  The African cherry (Prunus africana): can lessons be learned from an over-exploited medicinal tree?|journal=Journal of Ethnopharmacology|volume=89| pages = 3–13|doi=10.1016/j.jep.2003.08.002}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title=Stewart, K. M.  2003.  The African cherry (Prunus africana):  from hoe handles to the international herb trade.|journal=Economic Botany|volume=57| pages = 559–569}}</ref>

The extract [[Pygeum (herbal remedy)|Pygeum]], an herbal remedy prepared from the bark of ''P. africana'', is used as an [[alternative medicine]] for [[benign prostatic hyperplasia]] (BPH).<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17397059 | year = 2007 | last1 = Edgar | first1 = AD | last2 = Levin | first2 = R | last3 = Constantinou | first3 = CE | last4 = Denis | first4 = L | title = A critical review of the pharmacology of the plant extract of Pygeum africanum in the treatment of LUTS | volume = 26 | issue = 4 | pages = 458–63; discussion 464 | doi = 10.1002/nau.20136 | journal = Neurourology and urodynamics}}</ref>   In the 1960s, bark extracts were found to be effective in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia and has reached the international trade. A large number of clinical trials have been conducted to investigate the effectiveness of ''Pygeum'' in treating BPH, comparing it to a [[placebo]] rather than any [[pharmaceutical drug]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=Cochrane >{{cite journal | journal = Cochrane Database Syst Rev | date = 2002 | volume = 1 | id = CD001044 | title = Pygeum africanum for benign prostatic hyperplasia |vauthors=Wilt T, Ishani A, Mac Donald R, Rutks I, Stark G }}</ref>

=== Other uses===
The timber is a hardwood employed in the manufacture of axe and hoe handles, utensils, wagons, floors, chopping blocks, carving, bridge decks, and furniture. The wood is tough, heavy, straight-grained, and pink, with a pungent bitter-almond smell when first cut, turning mahogony and odorless later.<ref name=who/><ref name=":1" />

==Conservation status==
The collection of mature bark for its use in traditional medicine and other uses has resulted in the species becoming endangered.<ref>http://www.iucnredlist.org/apps/redlist/details/33631/0</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.voanews.com/english/news/a-13-2006-05-22-voa24.html | newspaper = VOANews | date = 22 May 2006 | accessdate = 20 January 2011 | title = Africa's Medicine Tree Facing Extinction From Greed, Corruption}}</ref>  ''P. africana'' continues to be taken from the wild. However, quotas have been awarded by the South African Forestry Department without adequate forest inventories due to some harvesters, spurred on by the high prices, removing too much of the bark in an unsustainable manner.<ref>http://www.peopleandplants.org/storage/working-papers/wp2.pdf</ref> In the 1990s, an estimated 35,000 debarked trees were being processed annually. The growing demand for the bark has led to the cultivation of the tree for its medicinal uses.<ref name=sustain/>

==Discovery and classification==
The name of the remedy, pygeum, comes from the name of the plant, which was discovered to botany by [[Gustav Mann]] during his now-famous first European exploration of the [[Cameroon line|Cameroon Range]], with [[Richard Francis Burton]] and [[Alfred Saker]], in 1861. A letter from Mann to the [[Linnean Society of London]], read by [[William Jackson Hooker]], then Director of the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]], on June 5, 1862, describes the naming of the peaks of the Cameroon Range (such as Mount Victoria, later Mount Cameroon<ref>The British names did not survive the transfer of Cameroon to Germany in 1884 and now are nearly unknown.</ref>) and the collection of specimens there.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Hooker | first=Sir W.J. | authorlink=William Jackson Hooker | title=Letter from Mr. G. Mann, Government Botanist, describing his Expedition to the Cameroon Mountains | journal=Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society | volume=VII | pages=1–13 | year=1864 | url=http://www.botanicus.org/page/166680 | doi=10.1111/j.1095-8312.1863.tb01054.x }}</ref> The latter were shipped back to Kew for classification, which was duly performed by Hooker and his son, [[Joseph Dalton Hooker]], who had the responsibility of publishing them, as William died in 1865.

When the publication came out<ref>{{cite journal | last=Hooker | first=J.D. | authorlink=Joseph Dalton Hooker | title=On the Plants of the Temperate Regions of the Cameroons Mountains and Islands in the Bight of Benin; collected by Mr. Gustav Mann, Government Botanist | journal=Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society | volume=VII | pages=191–192 | year=1864 | url=http://www.botanicus.org/page/166680 | doi=10.1111/j.1095-8312.1864.tb01067c.x}} The article occupies pages 171–240. The botanical abbreviation for this publication is J. Proc. Linn. Soc., Bot.</ref> the Hookers had named the plant ''Pygeum africanum'', followed by the designation "n. sp.", an abbreviation for ''nova species''. The habitat is listed as "Cameroons Mountains, alt. 7000-7500 feet", which was above the tropical forest and in the alpine grasslands. Hooker notes that another specimen had been "gathered in tropical Eastern Africa" at 3000 feet by Dr. Kirk on an expedition of [[David Livingstone]].

The first publication of the synonym in 1864 had been preceded by publication of the bare name in 1863 in a book by [[Richard Francis Burton]].<ref>{{Cite book | first=J.D. | last=Hooker | author-link=Joseph Dalton Hooker | contribution=Enumeration of the Mountain Flowering Plants and Ferns Collected by M. Gustav Mann, Government Botanist, during his various ascents of the Cameroons Mountains, of Clarence Peak, Fernando Po, and of the Peak of San thomé | title=Abeokuta and the Camaroons Mountains: An Exploration: Appendix III | year=1863 | pages=270–277 | place=London | publisher=Tonsley Brothers }}</ref> Evidently Hooker had already made the contents of J. Proc. Linn. Soc., Bot. 7 for 1864 available to some, as Burton mentions the volume and Mann's letter in 1863.<ref>Page 47, first note.</ref>

Hooker gives scant hint of why he chose "pygeum"; however, what he does say indicates it was common knowledge among botanists. Kirk's specimen fruit was "a much depressed sphere". By this, he undoubtedly meant to reference [[Joseph Gaertner]]'s genus, ''Pygeum'' Gaertn.,<ref>{{cite web | title=Pygeum Gaertn. |  work=Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN) Taxonomy for Plants | author=U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) | url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/genus.pl?16198 }}</ref> which innovates pygeum<ref>See under [[De Fructibus et Seminibus Plantarum]]. The edition is the 1788.</ref> from a Greek word, πυγή, "rump, buttock", because the two lobes of the fruit resemble the human [[gluteus maximus]] muscles.<ref>{{cite book | first=Umberto | last=Quattrocchi | title=CRC World Dictionary of Plant Names: Common Names, Scientific Names, Eponyms: Volume III M-Q | publisher=CRC Press | year=2000 | isbn=0-8493-2673-7}} Previewable Google Books.</ref>

In 1965, [[Cornelis Kalkman]] moved ''Pygeum'' to ''Prunus'', and this classification has the authority for now.<ref>{{cite journal | first=Cornelis | last=Kalkman | authorlink=Cornelis Kalkman | title=The Old World Species of ''Prunus'' subg. Laurocerasus including those formerly referred to as Pygeum | journal=Blumea | volume=13 | pages=1–115 }} The specification is Blumea 13:33.</ref> However, a recent cladistic study notes of ''Pygeum'': "its relationships to ''Prunus'' remain to be tested by molecular cladistics."<ref>{{cite journal | last=Bortiri | first=Esteban |author2=Oh, Sang-Hun |author3=Gao, Fang-You |author4= Potter, Dan  | title=The Phylogenetic Utility Of Nucleotide Sequences Of SORBITOL 6-PHOSPHATE DEHYDROGENASE In Prunus (Rosaceae) | journal=American Journal of Botany | volume=89 | issue=11 | pages=1697–1708 | year=2002 | url=http://www.amjbot.org/cgi/reprint/89/10/1697.pdf | doi=10.3732/ajb.89.10.1697 | pmid=21665596}}</ref>

==Names==
''Prunus africana'' is known by the common names African cherry, pygeum (from its former scientific name, ''Pygeum africanum''), iron wood, red stinkwood, African plum, African prune, and bitter almond. In other languages spoken where it grows, it is known as ''tikur inchet'' in [[Amharic]], ''mkonde-konde'' in [[Chaga language|Chagga]], ''muiri'' in [[Gikuyu language|Kikuyu]], ''entasesa'' or ''ngwabuzito'' in [[Luganda|Ganda]], ''uMkakase'' in [[Xhosa language|Xhosa]], ''inyazangoma-elimnyama'' or ''umdumezulu'' in [[Zulu language|Zulu]],Tendwet in Nandi(Kalenjin) and ''rooi-stinkhout'' in [[Afrikaans]].<ref name="dwaf"/>

==Palaeobotanic evidence==
A 1994/1995 study published in 1997 by Marchant and Taylor did a pollen analysis on and [[Radiocarbon dating|radiocarbon-dated]] two core samples from montane Mubindi Swamp in [[Uganda]].<ref>{{cite journal | first=Robert | last=Marchant |author2=Taylor, David  | title=Late Pleistocene and Holocene History at Mubwindi Swamp, Southwest Uganda | journal=Quaternary Research | volume=47 | pages=316–328 | year=1997 | url=http://www.york.ac.uk/res/kite/people/marchant/RAM%20PDFs/QR%201997.pdf | doi=10.1006/qres.1997.1887 | issue=3 }}</ref> The swamp is a catchment at 2100 m altitude between mountain ridges. It is a "moist lower montane forest" in [[Bwindi Impenetrable National Park|Bwindi Forest National Park]]. The investigators found montane ''Prunus'', represented by currently growing ''P. africana'', has been in the catchment continuously since their Pollen Zone MB6.1, dated about 43000–33000 years ago.

The '''Green-twigs quar''' (''Psydrax livida'') is an [[Afrotropic ecozone|Afrotropical]] shrub or small tree<ref name=owf>{{cite web |title=''Psydrax livida'' | url=http://www.operationwildflower.org.za/index.php/plant-records/trees/207-psydrax-livida | work=Category: Trees |publisher=Operation Wildflower|accessdate=23 January 2013}}</ref>  in the [[Rubiaceae]] [[Family (biology)|family]]. It occurs in  eastern and southern Africa, including Burundi, Kenya, the DRC, Tanzania, Malawi, Mozambique, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Angola, Botswana, northern Namibia and northern South Africa.<ref name=owf/><ref name=fz>{{cite web |last=Bridson |first=D. |title=''Psydrax livida'' (Hiern) Bridson |url=http://apps.kew.org/efloras/namedetail.do?flora=fz&taxon=4661&nameid=11233 |work=Flora Zambesiaca, volume:5 part:2 (1998) Rubiaceae|publisher=Kew RBG|accessdate=23 January 2013}}</ref> It is deciduous or evergreen, and its green branches have an opposite and horizontal arrangement.<ref name=zim>{{cite web |last=Hyde |first=M.A.|title=''Psydrax livida'' (Hiern) Bridson |url=http://www.zimbabweflora.co.zw/speciesdata/species.php?species_id=155990 |work=Flora of Zimbabwe |accessdate=23 January 2013|display-authors=etal}}</ref>

148.text:
'''Ptaeroxylaceae''' [[Antoine Laurent de Jussieu|Juss.]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/family.pl?979 |title=''Rutaceae'' Juss., nom. cons. |work=[[Germplasm Resources Information Network]] |publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]] |date=2003-01-17 |accessdate=2009-04-11}} are a small family of [[List of Southern African indigenous trees and woody lianes|Southern African indigenous trees and woody lianes]], most of them from [[Madagascar]], comprising only two genera.[http://apps.kew.org/efloras/namedetail.do;jsessionid=31710071B5ED723A9568D9C32298EC12?flora=fz&treeid=162&qry=browse&taxon=1796 e-flora] Ptaeroxylaceae by F. White and B. T. Styles Such a family was not recognized by the [[APG II system]] of classification (2003), which noted that it was a synonym of [[Rutaceae]].Angiosperm Phylogeny Group (2003). [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x/abstract An update of the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group classification for the orders and families of flowering plants: APG II.] ''[[Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society]]'' 141(4): 399-436. [[doi: 10.1046/j.1095-8339.2003.t01-1-00158.x]] The [[APG III system]] of 2009,{{Citation |last=Angiosperm Phylogeny Group |year=2009 |title=An update of the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group classification for the orders and families of flowering plants: APG III |journal=Botanical Journal of the Linnean Society |volume=161 |issue=2 |pages=105–121 |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/122630309/abstract |accessdate=2010-12-10 |doi=10.1111/j.1095-8339.2009.00996.x }} an updated version of the last system, did not mention the family. All species within this family are included within Rutaceae. The family Ptaeroxylaceae was recognized by the [[Thorne system (1992)]], [[Dahlgren system]], and [[Reveal system]] and placed in the [[Rutales]]. Genus: ''[[Cedrelopsis]]'' [http://www.ajol.info/index.php/njnpm/article/viewFile/11751/14923 www.ajol.info] The chemistry of the Ptaeroxylaceae [[Baill.]] Species:
{{col-begin|width=70%}} {{col-1-of-2}} * ''[[Cedrelopsis ambanjensis]]'' J.F. Leroy * ''[[Cedrelopsis gracilis]]'' J.F. Leroy * ''[[Cedrelopsis grevei]]'' Baill. & Courchet * ''[[Cedrelopsis longibracteata]]'' J.F. Leroy {{col-2-of-2}} * ''[[Cedrelopsis microfoliolata]]'' J.F. Leroy * ''[[Cedrelopsis procera]]'' J.F. Leroy * ''[[Cedrelopsis rakotozafyi]]'' Cheek & M. Lescot * ''[[Cedrelopsis trivalvis]]'' J.F. Leroy {{col-end}}
Genus: ''[[Ptaeroxylon]]'' Ecklon & Zeyher, 1834 [http://taxonomicon.taxonomy.nl/TaxonName.aspx?id=8136&tree=0.1 taxonomicon.taxonomy.nl] *''[[Ptaeroxylon obliquum]]'' (Thunb.) Radlk. 149.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}}
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
| name = Sneeze-wood
| image = Ptaeroxylon obliquum, habitus, Walter Sisulu NBT.jpg
| regnum = [[Plant]]ae
| unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
| ordo = [[Sapindales]]
| familia = [[Rutaceae]]
| subfamilia = [[Spathelioideae]]
| genus = '''''Ptaeroxylon'''''
| species = '''''P. obliquum'''''
| binomial = ''Ptaeroxylon obliquum''
| binomial_authority =  ([[Thunb.]]) [[Radlk.]]
| synonyms = ''Ptaeroxylon utile'' <small>[[Eckl.]] & [[Zeyh.]]</small>
}}
'''''Ptaeroxylon obliquum''''' is the botanical name for the '''sneezewood tree'''. It is native to [[Southern Africa]], including [[South Africa]], [[Zimbabwe]], and [[Mozambique]]. It is the only species in the genus '''''Ptaeroxylon'''''.

== Background ==
''Ptaeroxylon obliquum'' is a species from the Rutaceae family which are most abundant in South Africa and Australia.<ref name="CEE 2009"/> The term ''ptaeroxylon'' is Greek for sneeze and wood,<ref name="Plantz Afrika"/> while ''obliquum'' denotes the oblique shape of the leaflets. The wood produces oils containing [[nieshoutol]], which causes violent [[sneeze]] attacks by workers who are exposed to the tree.<ref name="Plantz Afrika"/> Though sneezewood is not [[poisonous]], it has been known to cause respiratory complications. It has been linked to [[asthma]], [[rhinitis]] and mucosal inflammation.<ref name="Anderson 2000"/>

== Description ==
[[image:Ptaeroxylon obliquum, stam en lower, Manie van der Schijff BT.jpg|thumb|left|200px|foliage]]
[[image:Ptaeroxylon obliquum, blomme, Manie van der Schijff BT, c.jpg|thumb|left|200px|male flowers]]
''Ptaeroxylon obliquum'' is a shrub or medium deciduous tree that stands up to {{convert|15|m|ft}} tall.<ref name="Roux 2003"/>
The bark is whitish-grey and smooth when young, but fissured with age. Leaflets are 2.5 x 1.3 cm marked asymmetrically. They are blue-green to dark green in color and crowd near the ends of the rachis in three to seven pairs of leaflets. The flowers on the tree are white to creamy yellow and fragrant.<ref name="Flora... 2009"/>

Sneezewood is very dense having a [[specific gravity]] of 1040 kg/m<sup>3</sup>

== Uses ==

===Lumber===
Sneezewood is an extremely hard and durable [[timber]] wood. It often lasts longer than [[brass]] or [[iron]] when used for machine [[bearing (mechanical)|bearing]]s.<ref name="Roux 2003"/>

In the past, sneezewood was used extensively for [[Railroad tie|railway sleepers]]. It can also be used to make [[furniture]]. In [[Mozambique]] it is used to make [[xylophone]] keys.<ref name="Plantz Afrika"/>

Sneezewood is a very attractive wood with golden [[heartwood]] with light orange figures and is a favorite amongst [[woodturning|woodturners]].

Its scarcity today is due in part of its past use as [[fuel]] for [[steamboat|steam]] [[tugboat|tug]]s.<ref name="Plantz Afrika"/>
It has been used extensively for [[fence]] and [[telegraph pole]]s as well.<ref name="Roux 2003"/>

===Medicinal===
Sneezewood is used for medicinal and ritual purposes. The bark can be used to repel moths or as snuff. The resin has been used to get rid of warts and cattle ticks.<ref name="Plantz Afrika"/>

The [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]] have traditionally made [[snuff (tobacco)|snuff]] from sneeze-wood to relieve [[headaches]].<ref name="Schirmer 1980"/>

==See also==
*[[Southern African Sand Forest]]

150.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Pterocarpus erinaceus''
|image = Pterocarpus erinaceus MS 4178.JPG
|status = NT
|status_system = iucn3.1
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|subfamilia = [[Faboideae]]
|tribus = [[Dalbergieae]]
|genus = ''[[Pterocarpus]]''
|species = '''''P. erinaceus'''''
|binomial = ''Pterocarpus erinaceus''
|binomial_authority = [[Jean Louis Marie Poiret|Poir.]]
|}}

The tree '''''Pterocarpus erinaceus''''' is native to [[Sahel]]ian region of [[West Africa]] and is used for fuel wood, for medicinal purposes, as a [[woodworking]] material, and that is useful as a [[Nitrogen fixation|nitrogen-fixing]] plant that helps to improve nutrient-depleted farming land. It has several common names, including '''barwood''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=PTER|taxon=Pterocarpus erinaceus|accessdate=15 October 2015}}</ref> '''muninga''', '''''vène''''', and '''''mukwa'''''; is used for this species as well as other ''[[Pterocarpus]]''. Groves of the tree can be found on the savannahs of West Africa, but it is becoming increasingly rare and is sometimes cultivated. The tree also grows in forests of [[Comoé National Park]] in [[Côte d'Ivoire]], a region geographically close to the Sahel but with a higher moisture regime due to its location between two large rivers. The tree grows to about 11 meters in height on average, and bears dark, scaly bark and yellow flowers. The fruits are winged pods. ''P. erinaceus'' grows well on sunny, hot African plains with long dry seasons and frequent fires.

The wood, which varies from yellowish to rosy reds and rich browns, is valued for woodworking, and makes good [[charcoal]] and fuel wood. The tree exudes a red sap called ''[[kino (gum)|kino]]'', which is used as a dye in [[Tanning (leather)|tanning]] and cloth-making. As a legume, the tree harbors [[rhizobia]] that return nitrogen to the soil, making it more fertile. Such plants are desirable on farmland. In addition, the foliage is a nutritious [[fodder]] for farm animals. [[Mali]] has an active market for ''P. erinaceus'' foliage, which is in high demand by sheep farmers for fodder. The tree has several [[Herbalism|medicinal uses]], including reduction of fever and cough suppression.<ref>[http://www.winrock.org/fnrm/factnet/factpub/FACTSH/P_erinaceus.html ''Pterocarpus erinaceus'': An important legume tree in African savannas]</ref>

''Pterocarpus erinaceus'' is one of the traditional [[Djembe#Shell|djembe]] woods.

''Pterocarpus erinaceus'' was brought to Europe in the 19th century by the Scottish explorer [[Mungo Park (explorer)|Mungo Park]]. Currently, it is a threatened due to [[overexploitation]], [[environmental degradation]], and [[climatic change]]s. However, the tree is somewhat prolific and easy to cultivate, so reforestation efforts have shown some success.

Other names for the tree include '''''bani''''' in [[Fula language|Fulfulde]], '''''tolo''''' in [[Zarma language|Djerma]], and '''''ban''''' in [[Serer language|Serer]].<ref>[http://www.fao.org/ag/aGp/agpc/doc/Gbase/DATA/PF000396.HTM FAO Species Profile]</ref>

'''''Pterocarpus rotundifolius''''', the '''round-leaved bloodwood''', is a species of [[Fabaceae|fabaceous]] tree that is native to mesic and well-watered woodlands of [[Africa]] south of the equator. 

==Subspecies==
Up to three subspecies are recognized,<ref name=plantz>{{cite web |last1=Mutshinyalo |first1=Thompson |title = Pterocarpus rotundifolius (Sond.) Druce |url=http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantnop/pterocarprotund.htm |website=plantzafrica.com |publisher=SANBI |date= March 2003 | accessdate=18 March 2015}}</ref> but specimens with intermediate characteristics are common.<ref name=prota>{{cite web |last1=Lemmens |first1=R. H. M. J. |title=Pterocarpus rotundifolius (Sond.) Druce |url=http://database.prota.org/PROTAhtml/Pterocarpus%20rotundifolius_En.htm |website=Prota 7(1): Timbers/Bois d’œuvre 1 |publisher=PROTA, Wageningen, Netherlands |accessdate=19 March 2015 |date=2008}}</ref>
* ''P. r.'' subsp. ''rotundifolius''
* ''P. r.'' subsp. ''martinii'' <small>(Dunkley) Mend. & Sousa</small><ref name=tpl>Also considered synonymous with the nominate subspecies, see: {{cite web |title=Pterocarpus rotundifolius var. martinii |url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/tro-13056166 |website=The Plant List (2013). Version 1.1 |publisher=theplantlist.org |accessdate=23 March 2015}}</ref>
* ''P. r.'' subsp. ''polyanthus'' <small>(Harms) Mendonca & Sousa</small>

152.text:
{{Speciesbox
|genus = Pycnanthus
|species = angolensis
|authority = (Welw.) Warb.
|synonyms =
    {{Plainlist | style = margin-left: 1em; text-indent: -1em; |
*''Myristica angolensis'' <small>Welw.</small>
*''Myristica kombo'' <small>Baill.</small>
*''Myristica microcephala'' <small>Benth. & Hook. f.</small>
*''Pycnanthus kombo'' <small>(Baill.) Warb.</small>
*''Pycnanthus mechowi'' <small>Warb.</small>
*''Pycnanthus microcephalus'' <small>(Benth. & Hook. f.) Warb.</small>
*''Pycnanthus schweinfurthii'' <small>Warb.</small>
    }}
|synonyms_ref = <ref>{{citation
|url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/kew-2552687
|title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species
|accessdate=1 October 2015}}</ref>
}}

'''''Pycnanthus angolensis''''' is a species of [[tree]] in the [[nutmeg]] family, [[Myristicaceae]]. It is native to [[Tropical Africa]].<ref name=grin>[http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?401833 ''Pycnanthus angolensis'' (Welw.) Warb.] Germplasm Resources Information Network (GRIN).</ref> Its English language common names include '''African nutmeg''', '''false nutmeg''', '''boxboard''', and '''cardboard'''.<ref name=waf>[http://www.worldagroforestrycentre.org/sea/products/afdbases/af/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=1397 ''Pycnanthus angolensis''.] AgroForestryTree Database. World Agroforestry Centre.</ref> In Africa it is widely known as '''''ilomba'''''.<ref name=ric>Richter, H. G. and M. J. Dallwitz. 2000 onwards. [ftp://delta-intkey.com/wood/en/www/myspyang.htm ''Pycnanthus angolensis''.] Commercial timbers: descriptions, illustrations, identification, and information retrieval. DELTA – DEscription Language for TAxonomy. June, 2009.</ref>
==Description==
This [[evergreen]] tree grows up to 40 meters tall and usually up to a meter wide, sometimes up to 1.5 meters or more. The [[Trunk (botany)|trunk]] is straight and cylindrical with fissures and flaking [[bark]]. The [[plant sap|sap]] is honey-colored and turns red in time. The branches are in whorls. The leathery leaves are up to 31 centimeters long by 9 wide. The blades have pointed tips, heart-shaped bases, and thick midribs. They are hairless on top and coated with [[rust (color)|rusty]], [[felt|feltlike]] hairs on the undersides. The leaves usually bear signs of insect damage, a feature so common it is considered characteristic of the species. The flowers are arranged in dense, rusty [[panicle]]s up to 15 centimeters long. The individual flowers are difficult to see in the tight panicle until the [[stamen]]s develop,<ref name=waf/> being only about a millimeter long. The flowers are hairy and fragrant.<ref name=kew>[http://apps.kew.org/efloras/namedetail.do?flora=fz&taxon=6751&nameid=17150 ''Pycnanthus angolensis'' (Welw.) Warb.] In: Stannard, B. L. ''Flora Zambesiaca'' Vol. 9, Part 2: Myristicaceae. 1997. Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew.</ref> The fruit is a rounded [[drupe]] reaching over 3 centimeters long and wide, borne in clusters.<ref name=waf/> It is hairy brown when new, turning yellow-orange, and has cartilaginous flesh that dries woody.<ref name=kew/> It contains a black seed with a red [[aril]]<ref name=waf/> which resembles that of [[nutmeg]].<ref name=prota>[http://www.prota4u.org/protav8.asp?h=M4&t=Pycnanthus,angolensis&p=Pycnanthus+angolensis ''Pycnanthus angolensis''.] PROTA.</ref> The fruit ripens over a long period continuing into the next flowering season, which begins around October.<ref name=waf/>
==Ecology==
The tree grows in moist [[rainforest]]s up to about 1200 meters in elevation among other evergreens and semideciduous trees. It occurs in [[secondary forest]], sometimes taking hold in new canopy gaps or clearings. It thrives in sunny locations.<ref name=waf/> It grows in [[riparian zone|riparian]] forests such as [[gallery forest]]s, and in some regions it can be found in [[swamp]]s.<ref name=prota/> It occurs in areas receiving between about 1300 and 1800 millimeters of rain per year,<ref name=waf/> but the optimal seems to be about 2000 millimeters.<ref name=prota/>

Many animals feed on the fruits, such as [[hornbill]]s.<ref name=rbg>[http://congotrees.rbge.org.uk/species/details/pycnanthus-angolensis ''Pycnanthus angolensis''.] An Introduction to the Trees from the North of the Republic of Congo. Royal Botanic Garden, Edinburgh.</ref>

==Uses==
This species has a wide variety of human uses.

It is harvested for its [[wood]], which is light, soft, and whitish gray or pink-tinged in color.<ref name=waf/> Its popularity rose after [[World War II]] when [[plywood]] was in demand, and during the mid-20th century it was one of the more valuable timbers in Central Africa.<ref name=prota/> It is not very durable and tends to [[Wood warping|warp]], but it is easy to cut and work and can be used for many purposes. It is suitable for [[furniture]], and in house construction as [[panelling]],<ref name=waf/> [[siding]], [[roof shingle]]s, and framing. It is used for [[wood fuel|fuel]] and [[Pulp (paper)|paper pulp]]. The wood can be vulnerable to [[termites]], [[powderpost beetle]]s, and other [[pest (organism)|pests]].<ref name=prota/>

The yellowish or reddish [[vegetable oil|fat]] from the aromatic seed is called "kombo butter" or "Angola tallow". A seed can be up to 70% fat. It is used as a [[Biofuel|fuel]] for lighting and is made into [[soap]]. Seed remnants are used in [[compost]].<ref name=prota/> When ignited, the oily seed burns slowly and can be used as a [[candle]].<ref name=waf/>

In [[Uganda]] the tree is grown in [[Banana plantation|banana]], [[Coffea|coffee]], and [[Theobroma cacao|cocoa]] plantations to shade the crops.<ref name=waf/>

Most parts of the tree have been used in [[traditional African medicine]]. The sap has been used to [[Antihemorrhagic|control bleeding]].<ref name=waf/> It is made into an eyewash to treat [[cataracts]] and [[filariasis]] of the eye.<ref name=ono>Onocha, P. A. and E. O. Otunla. (2010). [http://scholarsresearchlibrary.com/aasr-vol2-iss4/AASR-2010-2-4-186-190.pdf Biological activities of extracts of ''Pycnanthus angolensis'' (Welw.) Warb.] ''Archives of Applied Science Research'' 2(4) 186-90.</ref> The bark has been used as a poison [[antidote]] and a treatment for [[leprosy]], [[anemia]],<ref name=waf/><ref name=prota/> [[infertility]], [[gonorrhea]], and [[malaria]].<ref name=prota/> Leaf extracts are consumed or used in an [[enema]] to treat [[edema]]. Root extracts are used to treat parasitic infections,<ref name=waf/> such as [[schistosomiasis]].<ref name=prota/> The seed oil is used to treat [[Oral candidiasis|thrush]].<ref name=waf/>

Like the fat of nutmeg, kombo butter is mostly [[myristic acid]], with a high amount of [[myristoleic acid]], as well. It contains the unique compound kombic acid, which was named for the tree under its nomenclatural synonym, ''P. kombo''.<ref name=lok>Lok, C. M., et al. (1983). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0031942283800260 Kombic acid, a hydroquinone polyisoprenoic carboxylic acid from ''Pycnanthus kombo'' seed fat.] ''Phytochemistry'' 22(9) 1973-76.</ref>
==Cultivation==
This tree is [[horticulture|cultivated]] for its products. Seeds are sown in the field,<ref name=prota/> and seedlings are grown in [[plant nursery|plant nurseries]] until they have large [[taproot]]s.<ref name=waf/> They cannot tolerate [[drought]].<ref name=prota/> After a year the tree is about half a meter tall, and within 4 years it can reach 4 meters. A 20-year-old tree can be 25 meters tall. Stands of cultivated trees are pruned and thinned periodically.<ref name=waf/>

Pest insects such as ''[[Monochamus scabiosus]]'' and ''[[Mallodon downesi]]'' and [[fungus|fungi]] such as ''[[Ophiostoma]]'' sp. have been observed, but they are not severe problems.<ref name=prota/> The freshly harvested wood may become discolored due to [[bacteria]]l growth, the light-colored wood developing dark brown staining.<ref name=yaz>Yazaki, Y., et al. (1985). [http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF02607902#page-1 Extractive components responsible for the discoloration of ilomba wood (''Pycnanthus angolensis'' Exell).] ''Holz als Roh-und Werkstoff'' 43(9) 359-63.</ref>

Trees can be cut when they reach a diameter of 50 centimeters, at around 30 years old.<ref name=prota/>

[[Agricultural cooperative]]s in Ghana cultivate the trees for the kombo butter.<ref name=gus>Gustafson, K., et al. (2012). [https://www.thieme-connect.com/ejournals/abstract/10.1055/s-0032-1320385 Antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective activities of plastoquinones from the seed fat of ''Pycnanthus angolensis''.] ''Planta Medica'' 78(11) PD27.</ref>

==Common names==
There are [[common name]]s for the plant in many languages. It is called '''''mkungu mwitu''''' in [[Swahili language|Swahili]],<ref name=grin/> '''''akwa-mili''''' and '''''oje''''' in [[Igbo language|Igbo]], '''''lunaba''''' and '''''munaba''''' in [[Luganda]], '''''akomu''''' in [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]], '''''calabo''''' in Spanish,<ref name=waf/> and '''''arbre à suif''''' and '''''faux muscadier''''' in French.<ref name=grin/> Local names include '''''pó casson''''' in [[São Tomé and Príncipe]],<ref name=do>do Céu de Madureira, M., et al. (2002). [https://estudogeral.sib.uc.pt/bitstream/10316/5791/1/fileca12fee15fc842cd9c635f3e18ca8c08.pdf Antimalarial activity of medicinal plants used in traditional medicine in S. Tomé and Prıncipe Islands.] ''Journal of Ethnopharmacology'' 81(1) 23-29.</ref> '''''gboyei''''' in [[Sierra Leone]] and [[Liberia]], '''''otie''''' in [[Ghana]], '''''eteng''''' in [[Cameroon]], '''''lolako''''' in [[Zaire]],<ref name=usda>[http://www.fpl.fs.fed.us/documnts/TechSheets/Chudnoff/African/htmlDocs_africa/Pycnanthusangolensis.html ''Pycnanthus angolensis''.] Wood Technical Fact Sheet. Forest Products Laboratory. Forest Service, USDA.</ref> and '''''adria''''', '''''effoi''''', '''''hétéré''''', '''''qualélé''''', and '''''walélé''''' in [[Ivory Coast]].<ref name=ric/>

==References==
{{reflist}}

'''''Quercus robur''''', commonly known as '''pedunculate oak''' or '''English oak''', is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the beech and oak family [[Fagaceae]]. It is [[native plant|native]] to most of [[Europe]] west of the [[Caucasus]]. The tree is widely cultivated in temperate regions and has escaped into the wild in scattered parts of China and North America.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=210001863 Flora of North America, ''Quercus robur'' Linnaeus, 1753.  English oak, pedunculate oak, chêne pédoncule ]</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=2&taxon_id=210001863 Flora of China, ''Quercus robur'' Linnaeus, 1753.  夏栎 xia li ]</ref>

==Taxonomy==
[[Image:Wistman's Wood in winter.jpg|thumb|left|Ancient pedunculate oaks at [[Wistman's Wood]] in Devon, England]]
''Quercus robur'' ([[Latin]] ''quercus'', "oak" + ''robur'' "strength, hard timber") is the type species of the genus (the species by which the [[oak]] genus ''Quercus'' is defined), and a member of the [[Lepidobalanus|white oak section]] ''Quercus'' section ''Quercus''. The populations in Italy, southeast Europe, and Asia Minor and the Caucasus are sometimes treated as separate species, ''Q. brutia'' Tenore, ''Q. pedunculiflora'' K. Koch and ''Q. haas'' Kotschy respectively.

A close relative is the [[sessile oak]] (''Q. petraea''), which shares much of its range. ''Q. robur'' is distinguished from this species by its leaves having only a very short stalk {{convert|3|-|8|mm|abbr=on}} long, and by its pedunculate (stalked) [[acorn]]s. The two often [[Hybrid (biology)|hybridise]] in the wild, the hybrid being known as ''Quercus'' × ''rosacea''.

''Q. robur'' should not be confused with ''Q. rubra'', the [[Quercus rubra|red oak]], which is a native of North America and only distantly related.

==Description==
[[Image:Baginton oak tree july06.JPG|thumb|left|An old English oak in [[Baginton]], England]]
[[File:Quercus robur - sprouting acorn.jpg|thumb|Seedling sprouting from its acorn]]
[[File:Oaksprout.jpg|thumb|An oak sprout in a glass container]]

''Quercus robur'' is a large [[deciduous]] tree, with circumference of grand oaks from {{convert|4|m|abbr=on}} to exceptional {{convert|12|m|abbr=on}}.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} The Majesty Oak with a circumference of {{convert|12.2|m|abbr=on}} is the thickest tree in [[Great Britain]],{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} and the [[Kaive Oak]] in [[Latvia]] with a circumference of {{convert|10.2|m|abbr=on}} is the thickest tree in [[Northern Europe]].{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} ''Quercus robur'' has lobed and nearly sessile (very short-stalked) leaves {{convert|7|-|14|cm|abbr=on}} long. Flowering takes place in mid spring, and their fruit, called [[acorn]]s, ripen by the following autumn. The acorns are {{convert|2|-|2.5|cm|abbr=on}} long, pedunculate (having a peduncle or acorn-stalk, {{convert|3|-|7|cm|abbr=on}} long) with one to four acorns on each peduncle.

''Q. robur'' is very tolerant to soil conditions and the [[continental climate]] but it prefers fertile and well-watered soils. Mature trees tolerate flooding.<ref>{{citation |last1=Ducousso, A. & Bordacs, S. |title=Pedunculate and sessile oaks - ''Quercus robur''/''Quercus petraea'': Technical guidelines for genetic conservation and use|date=2004|pages=6 |url=http://www.euforgen.org/fileadmin//templates/euforgen.org/upload/Publications/Technical_guidelines/1038_Technical_guidelines_for_genetic_conservation_and_use_for_Pedunculate_and_sessile_oaks__Quercus_robur__and__Quercus_petraea_.pdf |publisher=[[European Forest Genetic Resources Programme]]}}</ref>

It is a long-lived tree, with a large wide spreading crown of rugged branches. While it may naturally live to an age of a few centuries, many of the oldest trees are [[pollarding|pollarded]] or [[coppice]]d, both pruning techniques that extend the tree's potential lifespan, if not its health. Two individuals of notable longevity are the [[Stelmužė Oak]] in [[Lithuania]] and the [[Granit Oak]] in [[Bulgaria]], which are believed to be more than 1,500 years old, possibly making them the oldest oaks in Europe; another specimen, called the 'Kongeegen' ('Kings Oak'), estimated to be about 1,200 years old, grows in [[Jaegerspris]], [[Denmark]].{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} Yet another can be found in [[Rumskulla oak|Kvilleken]], [[Sweden]], that is over 1,000 years old and {{convert|14|m}} around.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.naturvardsverket.se/Nerladdningssida/?fileType=pdf&downloadUrl=/Documents/publikationer/620-5617-4.pdf | title= The Oak Tree, from Peasant Torment to a Unifying Concept of Landscape Management | first= Jerker |last= Moström | publisher= National Heritage Board of Sweden | work= The Oak – History, Ecology Management and Planning | location= Linköping, Sweden| date= May 2006 }}</ref> Of maiden (not pollarded) specimens, one of the oldest is the great oak of [[Ivenack]], [[Germany]]. [[Dendrochronology|Tree-ring research]] of this tree and other oaks nearby gives an estimated age of 700 to 800 years. Also the [[Bowthorpe Oak]] in [[Lincolnshire]], [[England]] is estimated to be 1,000 years old, making it the oldest in the UK, although there is [[Knightwood Oak]] in the [[New Forest]] which is also said to be as old. Highest density of the grand oak trees [[Q. robur]] with a circumference {{convert|4|m}} and more is in Latvia.<ref>Eniņš, Guntis (2008). [http://www.jr.lv/lv/veikals/prece/?shop_id=296940 ''100 dižākie un svētākie''], AS Lauku Avīze, p. 25. ISBN 978-9984-827-15-5</ref>

==Ecological importance==
[[File:Holz der Stieleiche.jpg|thumb|bark and wood]]
[[File:Quercus robur MHNT.BOT.2010.6.75.jpg|thumb|''Quercus robur'' - [[MHNT]]]]
[[Image:Juhász Gyula memorial tree.JPG|thumb|The [[Gyula Juhász (poet)|Gyula Juhász]] memorial tree in [[Makó]]]]
[[File:Q-robur-concordia.jpg|thumb|''Q. robur'' 'Concordia']]

Within its native range ''Q. robur'' is valued for its importance to [[insect]]s and other wildlife. Numerous insects live on the leaves, buds, and in the acorns. ''Q. robur'' supports the highest biodiversity of insect herbivores of any British plant (>400 spp).  The acorns form a valuable food resource for several small [[mammal]]s and some birds, notably [[Eurasian jay]]s ''Garrulus glandarius''. Jays were overwhelmingly the primary propagators<ref>{{cite book |page= 131 |title=Forest and Woodland Trees in Britain |first= John |last=White |year=1995 |publisher=Oxford University Press |ISBN= 0-19-854883-4}}</ref> of oaks before humans began planting them commercially, because of their habit of taking acorns from the umbra of its parent tree and burying them undamaged elsewhere. Mammals, notably [[squirrel]]s who tend to hoard acorns and other nuts most often leave them too abused to grow in the action of moving or storing them.

==Commercial forestry==
''Quercus robur'' is planted for [[forestry]], and produces a long-lasting and durable [[heartwood]], much in demand for interior and furniture work. The wood of ''Q. robur'' is identified by a close examination of a [[cross section (geometry)|cross-section]] perpendicular to fibres. The wood is characterised by its distinct (often wide) dark and light brown growth rings. The earlywood displays a vast number of large vessels (~{{convert|0.5|mm|abbr=on}} diameter). There are rays of thin (~{{convert|0.1|mm|abbr=on}}) yellow or light brown lines running across the growth rings. The timber is around {{convert|720|kg|abbr=on}} per cubic meter in density.<ref>[http://www.nichetimbers.co.uk/native-hardwood/british-oak/ British Oak]. Niche Timbers. Accessed 19-08-2009.</ref>

==Cultivation==
A number of [[cultivar]]s are grown in [[garden]]s and [[park]]s and in [[Arboretum|arboreta]] and botanical gardens.  The most common cultivar is ''Quercus robur'' 'Fastigiata', and is the exception among ''Q. robur'' cultivars which are generally smaller than the standard tree,  growing to between 10–15 m and exhibit unusual leaf or crown shape characteristics.

;In Australia
English oak is one of the most common park trees in south-eastern Australia, noted for its vigorous, luxuriant growth. In [[Australia]], it grows very quickly{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} to a tree of {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} tall by up to {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} broad, with a low-branching canopy. Its trunk and secondary branches are very thick and solid and covered with deep-fissured blackish-grey bark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metrotrees.com.au/treehandbook/page-listings/quercus-robur.html |title=Quercus robur |publisher=Metrotrees.com.au |date= |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref>
The largest example in Australia is in [[Donnybrook, Western Australia|Donnybrook]], [[Western Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Nina Smith |url=http://www.donnybrookmail.com.au/news/local/news/general/australias-biggest-oak-tree/1701700.aspx |title=Australia's Biggest Oak Tree |publisher=Donnybrookmail.com.au |date=2009-12-10 |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref> Native Australian oaks are quite unrelated to the European oaks.

===Cultivars===
*''Quercus robur'' 'Fastigiata' ("Cypress Oak"), probably the most common cultivated form, it grows to a large imposing tree with a narrow columnar habit. The fastigiate oak was originally propagated from an upright tree that was found in central Europe.
*''Quercus robur'' 'Concordia' ("Golden Oak"), a small very slow-growing tree, eventually reaching {{convert|10|m|abbr=on}}, with bright golden-yellow leaves throughout spring and summer.  It was originally raised in Van Geert's nursery at [[Ghent]] in 1843.
*''Quercus robur'' 'Pendula' ("Weeping Oak"), a small to medium-sized tree with pendulous branches, reaching up to 15 m.
*''Quercus robur'' 'Purpurea' is another cultivar growing to {{convert|10|m|abbr=on}}, but with purple coloured leaves.
*''Quercus robur'' 'Filicifolia' ("Cut-leaved Oak") is a cultivar where the leaf is pinnately divided into fine forward pointing segments.

===Hybrids===
Along with the naturally occurring  ''Q.'' × ''rosacea'', several [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] with other white oak species have also been produced in cultivation, including Turner's Oak ''Q.'' × ''turnerii'', Heritage Oak ''Q.'' × ''macdanielli'', and Two Worlds Oak ''Q.'' × ''bimundorum'', the latter two developed by nurseries in the [[United States]].
*''Q.'' × ''bimundorum'' ([[Quercus alba|''Q. alba'']] × ''Q. robur'') (Two Worlds Oak)
*''Q.'' × ''macdanielli'' ([[Bur oak|''Q. macrocarpa'']] × ''Q. robur'') (Heritage Oak)
*''Q.'' × ''rosacea'' [[Johann Matthäus Bechstein|Bechst.]] ([[Sessile oak|''Q. petraea'']] x ''Q. robur''), a hybrid of the sessile oak and English oak.  It is usually of intermediate character between its parents, however it does occasionally exhibit more pronounced characteristics of one or the other parent.
*''Q.'' × ''turnerii'' [[Carl Ludwig Willdenow|Willd.]] ([[Holm oak|''Q. ilex'']] × ''Q. robur'') (Turner's Oak), a semi-evergreen tree of small to medium size with a rounded crown; it was originally raised at Mr. Turner's nursery, Essex, UK, in 1783. An early specimen is at the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rbgkew.org.uk/plants/trees/turnersoak.html |title=Kew: Plants: Turner’s Oak, Quercus x turneri |publisher=Rbgkew.org.uk |date=1987-10-16 |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref>
*[[Quercus × warei|''Q.'' × ''warei'']] (''Q. robur fastigiata'' x [[Swamp white oak|''Q. bicolor'']]), a hybrid between Upright English Oak and the swamp white oak. The selections within this hybrid include the (Regal Prince) 'Long'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://buckeyegardening.com/potm0406.html |title=Plant of the Month |publisher=Buckeyegardening.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref> cultivar and the (Kindred Spirit) 'Nadler' cultivar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oaknames.org/search/index.asp |title=''International Oak Society Link'' |publisher=Oaknames.org |date= |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref>

===Diseases===
*[[Acute oak decline]]
*[[Powdery mildew]] caused by ''[[Erysiphe alphitoides]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forestry.gov.uk/fr/infd-7b3d24|accessdate=13 April 2013|title=Oak mildew|publisher=[[Forestry Commission]]|year=2013}}</ref>

==Symbolism==

===Basque Country===
In the [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque Country]] (Spain and France) the oak symbolises the traditional [[Fuero|basque liberties]]. This is based on the '[[Gernikako Arbola|tree of Gernika]]', an ancient oak tree located in [[Gernika]], below which since at least the 13th century the [[Lords of Biscay]] first, and afterwards their successors the [[Kings of Castile]] and the [[Kings of Spain]] solemnly swore to uphold the [[Fuero|charter of Biscay]], which secured widespread rights to the inhabitants of [[Biscay]]. Since the 14th century, the [[Juntas Generales]] (the parliament of Biscay) gathers in a building next to the oak tree, and symbolically passes its laws under the tree as well. Nowadays, the [[Lehendakari]] (Basque prime minister) swears his oath of office under the tree.

===Bulgaria===
The national [[coat of arms of Bulgaria]] includes two crossed oak branches with fruits - as shield ([[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]]) [[Compartment (heraldry)|compartment]].

===Croatia===
Oak leaves with acorns are depicted on the [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] of the Croatian 5 [[Croatian kuna|lipa]] coin, minted since 1993.<ref>[http://www.hnb.hr Croatian National Bank] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506012028/http://www.hnb.hr |date=6 May 2009 }}. [http://www.hnb.hr/novcan/ekovanic.htm?tsfsg=a89719a221b101407a7b882421d5f621 Kuna and Lipa, Coins of Croatia] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622012116/http://www.hnb.hr/novcan/ekovanic.htm?tsfsg=a89719a221b101407a7b882421d5f621 |date=22 June 2009 }}: [http://www.hnb.hr/novcan/kovanice/e5lipa.htm?tsfsg=a5ee4c0e86800b7a3ae0a4fb87366071 5 Lipa Coin] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604014510/http://www.hnb.hr/novcan/kovanice/e5lipa.htm?tsfsg=a5ee4c0e86800b7a3ae0a4fb87366071 |date=4 June 2011 }}. – Retrieved on 31 March 2009.</ref> The pedunculate oak of the Croatian region of [[Slavonia]] (considered a separate subspecies - ''Slavonian oak'') is a regional symbol of [[Slavonia]] and a national symbol of [[Croatia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kwintessential.co.uk/articles/croatia/croatian-national-symbols/10872 |title=Croatian National Symbols  |publisher=www.kwintessential.co.uk/ |accessdate=2013-04-23}}</ref>

===England===
In England, the English oak has assumed the status of a national emblem. This has its origins in the oak tree at [[Boscobel House]], where the future [[Charles II of England|King Charles II]] hid from his [[Roundhead|Parliamentarian]] pursuers in 1650 during the [[English Civil War]]; the tree has since been known as the [[Royal Oak]]. This event was celebrated nationally on 29 May as [[Oak Apple Day]], which is continued to this day in some communities.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/wiltshire/moonraking/folklore_oak_apple.shtml |title=Wiltshire - Moonraking - Oak Apple Day |publisher=BBC |date=1931-05-29 |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref> ‘The Royal Oak’ is the third most popular [[pub name]] in Britain (541 in 2007)<ref>{{cite web| title=Real Ale and Pub News Features Archive |url= http://www.solihullcamra.org.uk/features_archive.htm |publisher=Solihullcamra.org.uk |date=2007-11-15 |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref> and has been the name of eight major [[Royal Navy]] [[HMS Royal Oak|warships]]. The naval associations are strengthened by the fact that oak was the main construction material for sailing warships. The Royal Navy was often described as ‘The Wooden Walls of Old England’<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nmm.ac.uk/collections/explore/object.cfm?ID=MEC1924 |title=National Maritime Museum |publisher=Nmm.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-05-02}}</ref> (a paraphrase of the [[Wooden Walls#Classical Period|Delphic Oracle]]) and the Navy’s official quick march is "[[Heart of Oak]]". Furthermore, the oak is the most common woodland tree in England.<ref>{{cite web| first= Steve | last= Smith | url= http://www.forestry.gov.uk/pdf/frnationalinventory0001.pdf/$FILE/frnationalinventory0001.pdf |agency= Table 1 | page= 52 |title= The National Inventory of Woodland and Trees - England | publisher= Forestry Commission | location= UK}}</ref> An oak tree has been depicted on the reverse of the [[British one pound coin#Designs|pound coin]] (the 1987 and 1992 issues) and a sprig of oak leaves and acorns is the emblem of the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]].

===Germany===
In Germany, the oak tree is used as a typical object and symbol in romanticism. It can be found in several paintings of Caspar David Friedrich and in "Of the life of a Good-For-Nothing" written by Joseph Freiherr von Eichendorff as a symbol of the state protecting every man. In those works the oak is shown in different situations, with leaves and flowers or dead without any of its previous beauty. Those conditions are mostly symbols for the conditions Germany is in or going through. Furthermore, the oak's stem is a symbol for Germany's strength and stability. Oak branches were displayed on the reverse of the small coins of the old [[Deutsche Mark]] currency (1 through 10 Pfennigs; the 50 Pfennigs coin showed a woman planting an oak seedling), and are now also displayed on the reverse of the small German-issue [[Euro]] currency coins (1 through 5 cents).

===Ireland===
In Ireland, at [[Birr Castle]], an example, over 400 years old has a girth of 6.5 m. It is known as the Carroll Oak, referring to the local Chieftains, [[Ely O'Carroll]] who ruled prior to Norman occupation.<ref>Fifty Trees of Distinction by Prof. D.A. Webb and the Earl of Ross. Booklet, published by Birr Castle Demesne, 2000.</ref>

===Romania===
The [[Romania national rugby union team|Romanian]] [[Rugby Union]] side are also known as ''The Oaks.''

== Chemistry ==
[[Grandinin]]/[[roburin E]], [[castalagin]]/[[vescalagin]], [[gallic acid]], monogalloyl glucose ([[glucogallin]]) and [[valoneic acid dilactone]], monogalloyl glucose, [[digalloyl glucose]], [[trigalloyl glucose]], [[rhamnose]], [[quercitrin]] and [[ellagic acid]] are phenolic compounds found in ''Q. robur''.<ref>Analysis of oak tannins by liquid chromatography-electrospray ionisation mass spectrometry. Pirjo Mämmelä, Heikki Savolainenb, Lasse Lindroosa, Juhani Kangasd and Terttu Vartiainen, Journal of Chromatography A, Volume 891, Issue 1, 1 September 2000, Pages 75-83, {{doi|10.1016/S0021-9673(00)00624-5}}</ref> The heartwood contains [[triterpene saponin]]s.<ref>Identification of triterpene saponins in Quercus robur L. and Q. petraea Liebl. Heartwood by LC-ESI/MS and NMR. Arramon G, Saucier C, Colombani D and Glories Y, Phytochem Anal., November-DEcember 2002, volume 13, issue 6, pages 305-310, {{PMID|12494747}}</ref>

154.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Salvadora persica''
|image = Salvadora persica.jpg
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_subclassis = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Brassicales]]
|familia = [[Salvadoraceae]]
|genus = ''[[Salvadora (plant)|Salvadora]]''
|species = '''''S. persica'''''
|binomial = ''Salvadora persica''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
}}

'''''Salvadora persica''''' ('''Arak''', '''''Galenia asiatica''''', '''Meswak''', '''Peelu''', '''Pīlu''', '''''Salvadora indica''''', or '''toothbrush tree''', '''mustard tree''',  '''mustard bush'''), is a species of ''[[Salvadora (plant)|Salvadora]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldagroforestrycentre.org/Sea/Products/AFDbases/AF/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=1477 |title=Salvadora persica |publisher=[[World Agroforestry Centre]]|accessdate=2009-02-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/x5327e/x5327e1j.htm |title=Salvadora persica |accessdate=2009-02-16 |publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations]] }}</ref>
''Salvadora persica'' has [[kidney stones|antiurolithiatic]] properties.<ref>Geetha K, Manavalan R, Venkappayya D.,"Control of urinary risk factors of stone formation by Salvadora persica in experimental hyperoxaluria."   ''Exp Clin Pharmacol''. 2010 Nov;32(9):623-9</ref>
Used for centuries as a [[miswak|natural toothbrush]], its fibrous branches have been promoted by the [[World Health Organization]] for [[oral hygiene]] use.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}} Research suggests that it contains a number of medically beneficial properties including [[abrasive]]s, [[antiseptic]]s, [[astringent]], [[detergent]]s, [[enzyme inhibitor]]s, and [[fluoride]].<ref name='almas'>{{cite journal|title=Miswak Stick: The All Natural Toothbrush|url=http://arthurglosmandds.com/miswak-stick-natural-toothbrush/}}</ref><ref name='cdj'>{{ cite journal|title=Miswak Stick: The All Natural Toothbrush|url=http://arthurglosmandds.com/miswak-stick-natural-toothbrush/}}</ref><ref name="cdj"/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Significance of chewing sticks (miswak) in oral hygiene from a pharmacological view-point.|journal=Saudi Dental Journal|date=2006|first=Mohammed|last=Batwa|author2=Jan Bergström |author3=Sarah Batwa |author4=Meshari F. Al-Otaibi |volume=18|issue=3|pages=125–133|id= |url=http://www.sdsjournal.org/2006/volume-18-number-3/2006-18-3-125-133-full.html|accessdate=2009-02-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Contribution of Trees for Oral Hygiene in East Africa|journal=Ethnobotanical Leaflets|date=2008-04-15|first=Yoseph|last=Araya|volume=11|issue=|pages=38–44|id= |url=http://www.siu.edu/~ebl/leaflets/araya.htm|accessdate=2009-02-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Toothbrushes - the Miswak Tree|journal=University at Buffalo Reporter|date=1994-04-28|first=Mary|last=Spina|volume=25|issue=26|pages=|id= |url=http://www.buffalo.edu/ubreporter/archives/vol25/vol25n26/10b.txt|format=TXT|accessdate=2009-02-16 }}</ref>

==Distribution==
Native to: Algeria, Angola, Botswana, Cameroon, Chad, Egypt, Eritrea, Ethiopia, India, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kenya, Libya, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Niger, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Palestine, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Syria, Tanzania, Uganda, Yemen, Zambia, Zimbabwe<ref>http://www.worldagroforestrycentre.org/Sea/Products/AFDbases/AF/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=1477</ref> Also occurs in Namibia.<ref name=drought>{{cite news
|url=http://www.namibian.com.na/indexx.php?id=9793&page_type=story_detail&category_id=1|title=Staying afloat during a drought|last=Rothauge|first=Axel|date=25 February 2014|work=[[The Namibian]]}}</ref>

==Appearance==
[[File:Salvadora persica (Peelu) W IMG_6940.jpg|thumb|left|Leaves & flowers in [[Krishna Wildlife Sanctuary]], [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[India]]. ]]
''Salvadora persica'' is a small [[tree]] or [[shrub]] with a crooked trunk, seldom more than one foot in diameter. Its [[bark]] is scabrous and cracked, whitish with pendulous extremities. The root bark of the tree is similar to sand, and the inner surfaces are an even lighter shade of brown. It has a pleasant fragrance, of cress or mustard, as well as a warm and pungent taste. The leaves break with a fine crisp crackle when trodden on. The tree grows to a maximum height of three meters.<ref name="heritage">{{cite journal | author = Ra'ed I. Al Sadhan, Khalid Almas | year = 1999 | title = Miswak (chewing Stick): A Cultural And Scientific Heritage. | journal = Saudi Dental Journal | volume = 11 | issue = 2 | pages = 80–88 }}</ref> In Pakistan, these ancient, majestic and sturdy trees are more closely associated with graveyards, like the cypress tree in English culture.<ref>S. Abid Hussain, Associate Professor of English, Govt.Degree College No.1, Dera Ismail Khan/Pakistan</ref> {{clear left}}

==History and use==
''Salvadora persica'' is a popular teeth cleaning stick throughout the [[Arabian Peninsula]], as well as the wider Muslim world.<ref>{{cite book | last = National Institute of Industrial Research | first = | authorlink = | title = Herbs Cultivation & Their Utilization | publisher = Asia Pacific Business Press | date = 2003 | location = Delhi | pages = chapter 2 | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-81-7833-064-8 }}</ref> Also commonly referred to as [[miswak]], it is often mentioned that the [[Prophets of Islam|Islamic Prophet]] [[Muhammad]] recommended its use. He is quoted in various [[Hadith]] advising the use of the siwak.<ref name="IslamKotob">IslamKotob, ''Muslims and Science'', (Islamic Books), p.30.</ref> Use of the stick dates back to the Babylonians some 7000 years ago. They were also used by the Greeks, Romans, Jews and the Egyptians.

The fresh leaves can be eaten as part of a salad and are used in traditional medicine for
cough, asthma, scurvy, rheumatism, piles and other diseases.<ref name="heritage"/> The flowers are small and fragrant and
are used as a stimulant and are mildly purgative.<ref name="heritage"/>  The berries are small and barely noticeable; they are
eaten both fresh and dried.<ref name="heritage"/>

In [[Namibia]] the mustard bush is used as a drought-resistant fodder plant for cattle. The [[Topnaar people]] that still live on the [[Kuiseb River]] use it to feed their goats. The plant's seeds can be used to extract a detergent oil.<ref name=drought/>

As of 2009, [[Botanic Gardens Conservation International]] has a total of eight ''Salvadora persica'' plants in conservation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bgci.org/plant_search.php?action=Find&ftrGenus=Salvadora&ftrRedList=&ftrSpecies=persica&ftrRedList1997=&ftrEpithet=&ftrCWR=&x=0&y=0|title=Botanic Gardens Conservation International - PlantSearch database|}}</ref>

==Scientific analysis==
According to chemical and [[phytochemical]] analysis of ''Salvadora persica'', there was an occurrence of [[carbohydrate]]s and/or [[trimethylamine]]; an alkaloid which may effectively be [[salvadorine]]; [[chloride]]s; [[sulfur]]; [[terpene]]s; [[vitamin C]]; [[glycoside]]s; large amounts of [[fluoride]] and [[silica]]; small amounts of [[tannin]]s, [[saponin]]s, [[flavonoid]]s and [[sterol]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Significance of chewing-sticks (miswaks) in oral hygiene from a pharmacological view-point |journal=Journal Pakistan Medical Association |date=April 1981 |first=M.S. |last=Akhtar |author2=M. Ajmal |volume=31 |issue=4 |pages=89–95 |pmid=6785501 |url= |format= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Preliminary phytochemical and propagation trial with Salvadora persica L. |journal=Agriculture and Forestry Research |date=2008 |first1=Salah |last1=Ahmed |author2=Soaad Esmaeil Essawy El-Gengaihi |author3=Mohamed El-Sayed Ibrahim |author4=Ewald Schnug |volume=1/2 |issue=58 |pages=135–138 |id= |url=http://cairo.daad.de/imperia/md/content/kairo/wissenschaftsjahr/biotech_abstract6 |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-02-16}}</ref>

==See also==

* [[Pilu oil]]

{{italicstitle}}{{taxobox
|name =  Flame thorn
|image = Acacia ataxacantha, habitus, Skeerpoort.jpg
|image_caption = summer
|image2 = Acacia ataxacantha, habitus, Little Eden.jpg
|image2_caption = winter
|status = nt

|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Senegalia]]''
|species = '''''S. ataxacantha'''''
|binomial = ''Senegalia ataxacantha''
|binomial_authority = ([[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle|DC.]]) Kyal. & Boatwr.
|range_map_caption = Native Range of ''Senegalia ataxacantha''
|synonyms = *''Acacia ataxacantha'' <small>DC.</small>
*''Acacia eriadenia'' <small>[[Benth.]] in Hook., Lond. Journ. Bot. 5: 98 (1846)</small>
*''Acacia lugardiae'' <small>[[N.E.Br.]]</small>
|}}

'''''Senegalia ataxacantha''''', commonly known as the '''Flame thorn''', is an [[Africa]]n tree species with conspicuous red pods and numerous hooked prickles.

==Range==
It is widespread in [[sub-Saharan]] Africa from [[Senegal]] in the west to [[Sudan]] in the east, [[Namibia]], [[Botswana]], [[Zimbabwe]], and in the [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]] and [[KwaZulu-Natal]]. In arid regions it prefers low-lying sites near streams, watercourses and in valleys, but in higher rainfall areas is a common constituent of the bush, often favouring forest margins. Once established, young trees are quite frost-hardy. 

==Description==
Its normal habit is that of a multi-stemmed, untidy, large shrub with a tendency for the shoots to scramble using their recurved prickles, and often develops into a single-stemmed tree of 5-10m in height and 300mm trunk diameter. The rounded crown of dense, dark green foliage is composed of very small [[pinnule]]s. Translucent red pods provide a colourful display when backlit. The flaking bark is light grey, splitting longitudinally and transversely, and revealing a buff under-colour. The persistent prickles are profuse on young twigs, but can also be found on older wood. Unlike members of the genus ''[[Acacia]]'', the prickles are not in pairs, but scattered along young twigs ('ataxacantha' = orderless prickles).

Flowers occur as clusters of off-white or cream-coloured terminal spikes which are fragrant and bloom during spring and summer. <ref>''A Field Guide to the Acacias of Southern Africa'' - Lynette Davidson, [[Barbara Jeppe]]</ref> The timber, resembling that of ''[[Acacia melanoxylon]]'', often has [[heart rot]], but is of good quality and handsomely streaked in black, dark brown, purple and cream, with markedly contrasting off-white sapwood.

The appearance of this species may be confused with ''[[Senegalia caffra]]'' which differs by having paired prickles, stouter pods and greyish-green markedly pendent foliage.

==Related articles==
*[[List of Southern African indigenous trees and woody lianes]]

156.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Speciesbox
|image = Acacia laeta ms 2460.jpg
|image_caption = ''Senegalia laeta'' on a hill near [[Djibo|Djibo, Burkina Faso]]
|taxon = Senegalia laeta
|authority = (R. Br. ex [[Benth.]]) Seigler & Ebinger
|range_map = Acacia-laeta-range-map.png 
|range_map_caption = Range of ''Senegalia laeta''
|synonyms = *''Acacia laeta'' <small>R. Br. ex Benth.</small>
*''Acacia trintigniani'' <small>[[Auguste Chevalier|A. Chev.]]</small>
synonyms_ref = <ref name = FAO/>
}}

'''''Senegalia laeta''''', the '''gay acacia''' or '''daga''', is a [[legume]] found in the family [[Fabaceae]]. It was formerly included in the genus ''Acacia''.

==Description==
''Senegalia laeta'' is a perennial shrub or small tree growing to a height of 4-10m with a greyish-green bark looking blackish from a distance, with a pink slash. The leaves are twice-pinnate, i.e. the pinnate leaves are further divided pinnately, the leaflets are 1–4 cm long, with 2-5 pairs of [[pinnation|pinnae]] and 2-5 pairs of leaflets per pinna ; leaflets are oblong and asymmetrical, measuring 6-1.2 x 0.3-0.5 cm, greyish green and almost hairless. These leaves distinguish ''Senegalia laeta'' from the related [[sympatry|sympatric]] species such as ''[[Senegalia dudgeoni]]'', ''[[Senegalia senegal]]'', ''[[Senegalia gourmaensis]]'' and ''[[Senegalia mellifera]]'' by its leaves. The thorns are paired and consist of recurved axillary prickles, with an occasional a third prickle recurved forward, if the third thorn is absent it is normally replaced with a leaf. The flowers are creamy white and very fragrant, with three flowers set on a stalk with multiple stalks growing on a spike. The pale brown leathery pods are pointed, whereas those of ''Seneglia senegal'' are not and this character is an easy feature to distinguish these ''Senegalia laeta'' from that species.<ref name = FAO>{{cite web | url = http://www.fao.org/ag/agp/agpc/doc/gbase/Data/pf000357.HTM | title = Acacia laeta | accessdate = 25 November 2016 | publisher = [[Food and Agriculture Organization]]}}</ref>

==Distribution==
''Senegalia laeta'' is native to [[Africa]], including the [[Sahara]] as far south as [[Tanzania]],  the [[Middle East]], and [[Western Asia]].<ref name = FAO/><ref name=fii>{{ cite web |url=http://www.flowersinisrael.com/AcaciaLaeta_page.htm |title=''Senegalia laeta'' (as ''Acacia laeta'')|accessdate=2016-11-25| publisher = Martha Modzelevich|work = Flowers in Israel}}</ref>

== Uses ==
Parts of the tree are used for [[dyestuff]]; The tree is used for [[fodder]]; the foliage and seed pods make good [[forage]] for [[livestock]] and the tree stands up well to this use.<ref name=UTP/>

It produces an edible gum which is used to make [[gum arabic]] but is not as good quality as the gum Arabic extracted from ''Senegalia senegal''. It is harvested at the end of the rainy season when the gum is exuded from the bark and branches and collected by scraping, the bark is sometimes cut to increase production.<ref name = UTP>{{cite web | url = http://tropical.theferns.info/viewtropical.php?id=Senegalia+laeta | title = Senegalia laeta | accessdate = 2016-11-25 | publisher = Useful Tropical Plants}}</ref> Other uses to which ''Senegalia laeta'' is put are as fuel-wood and charcoal, browse for domestic animals, dead fencing for [[boma (enclosure)|boma]]s, poles, fence-posts ; the bark from the trunk is used for making ropes and repairing calabashes and in medicine it is considered to have analgesic properties, it is also used to soften hides before tanning. It is drought tolerant and has been successfully planted in reafforestation programmes.<ref name = FAO/>

==Taxonomy==
Formerly included in the genus ''[[Acacia]]'' it has now been reassigned with many African species of acacia to the [[genus]] ''[[Senegalia]]'',.<ref name="acaciaresolution1">{{cite web |title=The Acacia debate |url=http://worldwidewattle.com/infogallery/nomenclature/nameissue/melbourne-ibc-2011-congress-news-tuesday-26-july.pdf |publisher=IBC2011 Congress News |accessdate=May 5, 2016}}</ref><ref name="acaciaresolution2">{{cite web |title=Conserving ''Acacia'' Mill. with a conserved type: What happened in Melbourne? |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/iapt/tax/2011/00000060/00000005/art00033 |journal=''Taxon'' |author=Smith, Gideon F. |author2=Figueiredo, Estrela |last-author-amp=yes |volume=60 |issue=5 |year=2011 |pages=1504–1506 |accessdate=27 September 2016}}</ref>  The specific name ''laeta'' is the feminine of ''laetus'' and means  "joyful, cheerful, happy" in Latin.<ref name =fii/>

== References ==
{{reflist}}

== External links ==
{{WestAfricanPlants|Senegalia laeta (as Acacia laeta)}}

*''Senegalia mellifera'' subsp. ''mellifera'' <small>(M. Vahl) Seigler & Ebinger</small>
|synonyms = * ''Acacia mellifera'' <small>(M. Vahl) Benth.</small>
* ''Mimosa mellifera'' <small>M. Vahl</small>
|}}

'''''Senegalia mellifera''''' is a common thorn tree in Africa.   The name ''mellifera'' refers to its sweet-smelling blossoms and honey.  Its lumber turns pitch black when oiled. Common names of the tree include Blackthorn and Swarthaak ([[Afrikaans]]). It is listed as being not threatened.<ref name="ILDIS">[http://www.ildis.org/LegumeWeb?version~10.01&LegumeWeb&tno~315&genus~Acacia&species~mellifera ILDIS LegumeWeb]</ref>

== Distribution ==
''Senegalia mellifera'' is found in the dry areas of [[Africa]] and the [[Arabian Peninsula]].<ref name="ILDIS" />

== Characteristics ==
''Senegalia mellifera'' can occur either as a multi-trunked bush up to seven meters high with more or less a funnel-shaped crown, or as a single-trunked tree that can reach a height of up to nine meters. It can form an impenetrable [[thicket]]s. In some areas of Africa, it is considered an [[invasive species]] as it can expand into and cover large ares of farmland.

== Uses ==
[[File:Acacia mellifera subsp. detinens01.jpg|thumbnail|left|190px|<center>Inflorescences</center>]]
In Africa, ''Senegalia mellifera'' is used as fencing, livestock feed and building material for huts. It flowers are sources of [[nectar]] for honey-producing bees. The wood is prized also for fuel and making charcoal.<ref name= "Noad + Birnie">Trees of Kenya, Tim Noad and Ann Birnie (1989) ISBN 9966-848-95-9</ref> It is widely used in traditional African medicine.<ref>{{cite journal | pmc = 2816522 | pmid=20162040 | volume=6 | title=Antimicrobial activity of pentacyclic triterpenes isolated from Acacia mellifera | year=2008 | journal=Afr J Tradit Complement Altern Med | pages=42–8 | last1 = Mutai | first1 = C | last2 = Bii | first2 = C | last3 = Rukunga | first3 = G | last4 = Ondicho | first4 = J | last5 = Mwitari | first5 = P | last6 = Abatis | first6 = D | last7 = Vagias | first7 = C | last8 = Roussis | first8 = V | last9 = Kirui | first9 = J}}</ref> The plant contains the psychoactive chemical DMT.<ref>http://shaman-australis.com.au/shop/acacia_spp_cp_72.php</ref>

== Animal uses ==
This tree is an important food resource for both cattle and wild animals especially in dry areas of Africa. The leaves and young branches are very nutritious, containing a high percentage of protein. The flowers are often eaten by [[kudu]]. Common browsers of the tree include [[elephants]], [[black rhino]], [[giraffe]] and the [[Taurotragus|eland]].

{{italic title}}{{taxobox
|name = ''Senegalia montis-salinarum''
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]

|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]

|species = '''''S. montis-salinarum'''''
|binomial = ''Senegalia montis-salinarum''
|binomial_authority = N.Hahn, 2016
|}}

'''''Senegalia montis-salinarum''''', is a species of thorn tree that is native to two separate localities in the [[Soutpansberg]] range in [[Limpopo]], South Africa. The total population is estimated at no more than 250 adult trees. Based on its morphology, it is assigned to the ''[[Senegalia burkei|S. burkei]]'' [[species complex]].<ref name="vzyl">{{cite news|last1=van Zyl|first1=Andries|title=Newly described endemic tree for Soutpansberg |url=http://zoutpansberger.co.za/articles/news/35211/2016-01-29/newly-described-endemic-tree-for-soutpansberg|accessdate=23 October 2016 |agency=Zoutpansberger |date=29 January 2016}}</ref><ref>[http://vhembebiosphere.org/sarchi/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Hahn_Senegalia-montis-salinarum.pdf Hahn ''Senegalia montis-salinarum'' vhembebiosphere.org]</ref>

==Habitat==
It grows on rocky scree slopes in the hot rain shadow of the Soutpansberg range.<ref name="vzyl"/> 

==Description==
It is a multi-stemmed tree. It has smaller flowers than ''A. burkei'' and produces more seeds. The wood is soft and semi-succulent, and dead wood decays quickly.<ref name="vzyl"/>

==Status==
It may qualify as endangered due to the small population size and the proximity of the type locality to Coal of Africa’s Makhado Colliery project.<ref name="vzyl"/>
