| binomial = ''Vachellia reficiens''
| binomial_authority = ([[Heinrich Wawra von Fernsee|Wawra]]) Kyal. & Boatwr.<ref name="Kyalangalilwa">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kyalangalilwa B, Boatwright JS, Daru BH, Maurin O, van der Bank M | title = Phylogenetic position and revised classification of ''Acacia s.l.'' (Fabaceae: Mimosoideae) in Africa, including new combinations in ''Vachellia'' and ''Senegalia''. | journal = Bot J Linn Soc | volume = 172 | issue = 4 | pages = 500–523 | year = 2013 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/boj.12047/abstract | doi = 10.1111/boj.12047 }}</ref>
| synonyms = *''Acacia reficiens'' <small>Wawra</small>
| subdivision_ranks = subspecies
| subdivision = *''Vachellia reficiens'' subsp. ''misera'' <small>(Vatke) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
*''Vachellia reficiens'' subsp. ''reficiens'' <small>(Wawra) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
}}

'''''Vachellia reficiens''''' ({{lang-af|Rooihak}}, {{lang-de|link=no|Rotrindenakazie}}), commonly known as '''red-bark acacia''', '''red thorn''',<ref name=Wiegand2008>{{cite journal|last=Wiegand|first=Kerstin|author2=David Saltz |author3=David Ward |author4=Simon A. Levin |title=The role of size inequality in self-thinning: A pattern-oriented simulation model for arid savannas|journal=Ecological Modelling|year=2008|volume=210|pages=431–445|doi=10.1016/j.ecolmodel.2007.08.027}}</ref> '''false umbrella tree''',<ref name=Wiegand2008 /> or '''false umbrella thorn''',<ref name="bester99">{{cite journal|last=Bester|first=F. V. |year=1999 |title=Major problem-bush species and densities in Namibia |journal=Agricola |volume=10 |pages=1–3 |url=http://www.nbri.org.na/old/agricola_files/Agricola1998_99_No10_02_Bester.PDF}}</ref> is a deciduous tree or shrub of the pea family ([[Fabaceae]]) native to southern Africa, often growing in an upside-down cone shape and with a relatively flat crown.

== Taxonomy ==
The Austrian naturalist [[Heinrich Wawra von Fernsee]] described ''Vachellia reficiens'' (as ''Acacia reficiens'') in 1859. It forms a species complex with ''[[Vachellia luederitzii|V. luederitzii]]'', also from central and southern Africa.<ref name=ross67>{{cite journal |author1=Ross, J. H. |author2=Brenan, J. P. M. |year=1967 |title=Notes on Mimosoïdeae: X |journal=[[Kew Bulletin]] |volume=21 |issue=1 |pages=67–73 |jstor=4108432 |doi=10.2307/4108432}}</ref> Two subspecies exist: ''V. reficiens'' subspecies ''reficiens'', which found in Angola and southwestern Africa,<ref name=ross67/> and has affinities to ''V. luederitzii'',<ref name=zipcodezoo/> and ''V. reficiens'' subsp. ''misera'' which is found in eastern Africa, from Sudan and Somalia through Kenya and into Uganda,<ref name=ross67/> and has affinities to ''[[Vachellia etbaica|V. etbaica]]''.<ref name=zipcodezoo>{{cite web |url=http://zipcodezoo.com/Plants/A/Acacia_reficiens/ |publisher=Zipcodezoo.com |title=''Vachellia reficiens'' (as ''Acacia reficiens'') |accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> With the re-typification of the genus ''[[Acacia]]''<ref>International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (Vienna Code). Regnum Vegetabile 146. A.R.G. Gantner Verlag KG</ref> this species was placed in ''[[Vachellia]]''.<ref>Maslin, B.R. 2008. Generic and subgeneric names in ''Acacia'' following retypification of the genus. Muelleria 26: 7–9.</ref>

==Description==
''Vachellia reficiens'' can grow up to {{convert|5|m}} in height. Its bark is reddish-brown or greyish-black, and is quite rough and fissured. The younger growing branches can have a purple-red appearance, hence its common names. An interesting characteristic about this plant is that it has both, long, straight thorns and shorter curved/hook-like thorns, but generally not both in one pair. Leaves are bipinnately compound (as is common in most African [[vachellia]] species) with 1 to 4 pinnae pairs, where each pinna again has 5 to 13 leaflet pairs. The flowers are white- to cream-coloured, and mostly seen during the summer months of December and January, but they can blossom almost all year round, depending on the geographical location. The fruit is a flat red-brown pod.

== Distribution and habitat ==
''Vachellia reficiens'' is found in the drier areas of Africa, in countries like [[Angola]], South Africa, [[Swaziland]] and [[Namibia]]. This plant seems to prefer rocky soil-types and it does not grow in high-rainfall areas, but rather in semi-desert and arid shrubland.

It is an abundant dominant species of arid shrubland throughout Kenya,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/004/AB396E/ab396e03.htm|title=State of Forest Genetic Resources in Kenya|last=Forest Resources Division|date=December 2001|work=Working papers FGR/18E|publisher=FAO|accessdate=11 February 2012|location=Rome, Italy}}</ref> and it forms up to 30% of total woody canopy in the South Turkana Ecosystem in the [[Turkana District]].<ref name=cough>{{cite journal|author1=Coughenour,  Michael B. |author2=Ellis, James E. |author3=Pop, Robert G. |year=1990|title= Morphometric Relationships and Developmental Patterns of ''Acacia tortilis'' and ''Acacia reficiens'' in Southern Turkana, Keny|journal=Bulletin of the Torrey Botanical Club|volume=117|issue=1|pages=8–17|jstor=2997124|doi=10.2307/2997124}}</ref>

== Ecology ==
This tree's leaves are browsed upon by game and small livestock like the [[Greater Kudu]] and goats.<ref name=cough/><!-- refs goat bit --> In some areas of Namibia, ''Vachellia reficiens'' subsp. ''reficiens'' is considered an [[invasive species]] as it can encroach on areas of farmland, especially on disturbed soil.<ref name="bester99"/> It is very opportunistic and hardy.

== Uses ==
The nomadic Ngisonyoka people in the Turkana District of Kenya use ''Vachellia reficiens'' wood to build temporary houses.<ref name=cough/> In Namibia's [[Kaokoveld]] region, the branches of this tree are used for fencing and the bark is used to curdle milk, while the thorns can be used to pierce ears. The seeds can be baked in hot ash, crushed, ground and mixed with tobacco to use as snuff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/majasjoskog/docs/plants_around_gobabeb|author=Sjöskog, Maja|publisher= Gobabeb Training & Research Centre|year=2012|accessdate=12 February 2012| title=Plants Around Gobabeb|page = 101}}</ref> The [[Giriama people]] use the wood for firewood and charcoal, and straight stems for poles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://146.230.128.141/jspui/bitstream/10413/3829/2/Pakia_Mohamed_2000_Vol2.pdf|author=Pakia, Mohamed|title=Plant Ecology and Ethnobotany of Two Sacred Forests (Kayas) at the Kenya Coast|accessdate=12 February 2012}}</ref>

== See also ==
* Mannheimer, C. A. & Curtis, B. A. (eds) 2009. Le Roux and Müller’s Field Guide to the Trees and Shrubs of Namibia. Windhoek: Macmillan Education Namibia.

 | subdivision_ranks   = varieties<ref>[http://www.ildis.org/LegumeWeb/6.00/fam/f2.shtml ILDIS]</ref><ref name="fao"/>
 | subdivision         = * ''Vachellia seyal'' var. ''fistula'' <small>(Schweinf.) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
* ''Vachellia seyal'' var. ''seyal'' <small>([[Alire Raffeneau Delile|Delile]]) P.J.H.Hurter</small>
}}

[[File:Acacia-seyal-bark.jpg|thumb|right|''Vachellia seyal'' bark]]
[[File:Acacia seyal Bild0830.jpg|thumb|right|''Vachellia seyal'']]

'''''Vachellia seyal''''', the '''Red acacia''', known also as the '''[[shittah tree]]''' (the source of '''shittim wood'''), is a thorny, {{convert|6|–|10|m|ft|abbr=on}} high tree with a pale greenish or reddish bark. At the base of the {{convert|3|–|10|cm|in|abbr=on}} feathery leaves there are two straight, light grey thorns, growing to {{convert|7|–|20|cm|in|abbr=on}} long. The blossoms are displayed in round, bright yellow clusters approximately in {{convert|1.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} diameter.

In ''Vachellia seyal'' var. ''fistula'', which is more common on heavy clay soils, some of the thorns are swollen and house symbiotic ants.<ref name=Young>
{{cite journal |last=Young |first=T.P. |author2=Cynthia H. Stubblefield|author3= Lynne A. Isbell |date=December 1996 |title=Ants on swollen-thorn acacias: species coexistence in a simple system |journal=Oecologia |volume=109 |issue=1 |pages=98–107 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/409h774ynjpqf68w/ |accessdate=2008-01-21 |doi=10.1007/s004420050063}}</ref>

It is distributed from [[Egypt]] to [[Kenya]] and west [[Senegal]]. In the [[Sahara]], it often grows in damp valleys. It is also found at [[wadi]]s in the [[Arabian Peninsula]].

== Uses ==

=== Gum arabic ===
''Vachellia seyal'' is, along with other [[Vachellia]]s, an important source for [[gum arabic]], a natural [[polysaccharide]], that exudes from damaged stems and solidifies.<ref name="purdue">[http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/duke_energy/Acacia_seyal.html Purdue University]</ref>

=== Tanning ===
Parts of the tree have a [[tannin]] content of up to 18-20%. The bark and seed pods of ''Vachellia seyal'' var. ''seyal'' have a tannin content of about 20%.<ref name="fao">[http://www.fao.org/docrep/V5360E/v5360e0h.htm FAO]</ref>

=== Wood ===
Wood from the tree is said to have been used in [[Ancient Egypt]] to make [[coffin]]s and also the [[Ark of the Covenant]].<ref name="BoDD">[http://www.botanical-dermatology-database.info/BotDermFolder/LEGU-12.html#Vachellia%20seyal ''Vachellia seyal''] in BoDD – Botanical Dermatology Database</ref>

=== Medicinal uses ===
[[File:Acacia in Ein Khadra Desert Oasis 00 (87).jpg|thumbnail|left|Acacia tree in Ein Khadra Desert Oasis, Nuweibaa, South Sinai, Egypt.]]
==== Bark ====
The bark is used to treat [[dysentery]] and [[bacteria]]l [[infection]]s of the [[skin]], such as [[leprosy]]. The bark is also used as a [[stimulant]].<ref name="purdue"/>

==== Gum ====
The gum is used as an [[aphrodisiac]], to treat [[diarrhoea]], as an [[emollient]], to treat [[hemorrhaging]], [[inflammation]] of the [[human eye|eye]], [[intestine|intestinal]] ailments and [[rhinitis]]. The gum is used to ward off [[arthritis]] and [[bronchitis]].<ref name="purdue"/>

==== Wood ====
[[Incense]] from the wood is used to treat pain from [[rheumatism]] and to keep expectant mothers from contracting rhinitis and [[fever]]s.<ref name="purdue"/>

== Hybrids ==
''Vachellia seyal'' occasionally hybridizes with ''V. xanthophloea''.

|subdivision = *''Vachellia tortilis'' subsp. ''heteracantha'' <small>(Burch.) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
*''Vachellia tortilis'' subsp. ''raddiana'' <small>(Savi) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
** var. ''pubescens'' <small>(A.Chev.) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
** var. ''raddiana'' <small>(Savi) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
*''Vachellia tortilis'' subsp. ''spirocarpa'' <small>(Hochst. ex. A.Rich.) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
** var. ''crinita'' <small>(Chiov.) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
** var. ''spirocarpa'' <small>(Hochst. ex. A.Rich.) Kyal. & Boatwr.</small>
*''Vachellia tortilis'' subsp. ''tortilis'' <small>(Forssk.) Galasso & Banfi</small>
|}}

'''''Vachellia tortilis''''', widely known as '''''Acacia tortilis''''' but attributed by [[APG III]] to the ''[[Vachellia]]'' genus,<ref>XVIII International Botanical Congress, 23–30 July 2011, Melbourne Australia</ref> is the '''umbrella thorn acacia''',  also known as ''umbrella thorn'' and ''Israeli babool'',<ref>[http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/duke_energy/Acacia_tortilis.html ''Vachellia tortilis'' (as ''Acacia tortilis'' (Forsk.) Hayne)], Purdue University, December 1997.</ref> a medium to large canopied tree native primarily to the [[savanna]] and [[Sahel]] of [[Africa]] (especially [[Sudan]]), but also occurring in the [[Middle East]].

== Distribution and growing conditions ==
''Vachellia tortilis'' tends to grow in areas where temperatures vary from 0 to 50 degree [[Celsius]] and rainfall is anywhere from about {{Convert|100|-|1000|mm|in|abbr=on}} per year.<ref>[http://www.fao.org/docrep/006/Q2190E/Q2190E10.htm Handbook on Seeds of Dry-Zone Acacias FAO]</ref>

== Characteristics ==
In extremely arid conditions, it may occur as a small, wiry bush.  It grows up to {{convert|21|m|ft|abbr=on}} in height.<ref>[http://www.worldagroforestrycentre.org/SEA/Products/AFDbases/AF/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=118 World Agroforestry Centre]</ref>  The tree carries leaves that grow to approx. {{convert|2.5|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} in length with between 4 and 10 pair of [[pinnation|pinnae]] each with up to 15 pairs of leaflets.  Flowers are small and white, highly [[aromatic]], and occur in tight clusters.  Seeds are produced in pods which are flat and coiled into a springlike structure.

The plant is known to tolerate high [[alkalinity]], [[drought]], high temperatures, sandy & stony soils, strongly sloped rooting surfaces, and sand blasting.  Also, plants older than 2 years have been observed to be somewhat frost resistant.

== Importance ==
Timber from the tree is used for [[furniture]], wagon wheels, fence posts, cages, and pens. Vachellia wood was also used exclusively by the [[Israelites]] in the [[Old Testament]] in the building of the [[tabernacle]] and the tabernacle furniture, including the [[Ark of the Covenant]]. The pods and foliage, which grow prolifically on the tree, are used as [[fodder]] for desert grazing animals.  The bark is often used as a string medium in [[Tanganyika]], and is a source for [[tannin]].  Gum from the tree is edible and can be used as [[Gum Arabic]].  Parts of the tree including roots, shoots, and pods are also often used by natives for a vast number of purposes including decorations, [[weapon]]s, [[tool]]s, and [[medicine]]s.<ref>[http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/duke_energy/Acacia_tortilis.html Purdue University]</ref>

The Umbrella thorn is also an important species for rehabilitation of degraded arid land; it tolerates drought, wind, salinity and a wide range of soil types, and has the additional benefit of fixing nitrogen - an essential plant nutrient - in the soil via its interaction with symbiotic root bacteria.

== Common names ==
[[File:Acacia tortilis subsp heteracantha, loof en peule, Wonderboom NR, a.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The pods are curled]]
[[File:Acacia tortilis, haak- en steekdorings, Springbokvlakte.jpg|thumb|right|250px|It has a combination of paired straight and paired hooked thorns, from which the Afrikaans name derives, meaning "hook and prick".]]
[[File:Acacia tortilis subsp heteracantha, blomtyd, Lekkerbreek-plaas, a.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The southern subspecies ''heteracantha'', here seen in flower, is smaller and often without a spreading crown]]
Spread over such a large area inhabited by diverse cultures, the ''V. tortilis'' is known by a wide number of common names.  These include (but are not limited to):<ref>[http://www.worldagroforestry.org/sea/Products/AFDbases/af/asp/SpeciesInfo.asp?SpID=118 World AgroForestryTree Database:  ICRAF / PROSEA network.]</ref>
* Afrikaans: haak-en-steek
* Arabic: sunut, samar, sammar, samor, samra, sayyal, seyal, seyyal
* English: karamoja, umbrella thorn
* Hebrew: shitat ha'sochech
* Hindi: Israeli babool
* Italian: acacia ad ombrello
* Ndebele: isanqawe, umsasane, umshishene, untshatshatsha
* Nyanja: mzunga, nsangu, nsangunsangu, nyoswa
* Samburu: ltepes
* Somali: abak, kura, maraa
* Swahili: mgunga, mugumba, munga
* Tigrigna: akba, akiba, alla, aqba
* Tongan: mukoka, muzungu, ngoka
* Tswana: mosu, mosunyana
* Zulu: umSasane
* Oromiffa: Lafto
* Amharic: Grar

192.text:
{{Redirect|Fever tree}}
{{italic title}}
{{Speciesbox
|name = Fever tree
|image = Ngorongoro Acacia xanthophloea.jpg
|taxon = Vachellia xanthophloea
|authority = (Benth.) P.J.H.Hurter<ref name="Kyalangalilwa">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kyalangalilwa B, Boatwright JS, Daru BH, Maurin O, van der Bank M | title = Phylogenetic position and revised classification of ''Acacia s.l.'' (Fabaceae: Mimosoideae) in Africa, including new combinations in ''Vachellia'' and ''Senegalia''. | journal = Bot J Linn Soc | volume = 172 | issue = 4 | pages = 500–523 | year = 2013 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/boj.12047/abstract | doi = 10.1111/boj.12047 }}</ref>
|synonyms = ''Acacia xanthophloea'' <small>Benth.</small>
|}}

[[File:Acacia xanthophloea00.jpg|thumb]]

'''''Vachellia xanthophloea''''' is a tree in the [[Fabaceae]] family and is commonly known in English as the '''fever tree''' (local East African names include olerai, kimwea, murera, and mwelele). This species of ''[[Vachellia]]'' is native to eastern and southern [[Africa]]. It can be found in [[Botswana]], [[Kenya]], [[Malawi]], [[Mozambique]], [[Somalia]], [[South Africa]], [[Swaziland]], [[Tanzania]], [[Zambia]] and [[Zimbabwe]]. It has also become a landscape tree in other warm climates, outside of its natural range.

==Description==
The trees grow to a height of {{convert|15|–|25|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The characteristic bark is smooth, powdery and greenish yellow, although new twigs are purple, flaking later to reveal the characteristic yellow.<ref name = agroforestry>{{cite web | url = http://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb2/speciesprofile.php?Spid=125 | title = Acacia xanthophloea | accessdate = 13 October 2016 | publisher = WorldAgroforestryCenter 2016}}</ref> It is one of the few trees where [[photosynthesis]] takes place in the [[bark]]. Straight, white spines grow from the branch nodes in pairs. The leaves are twice compound, with small leaflets ({{convert|8|×|2|mm|in|abbr=on|1}}). The flowers are produced in scented pale cream spherical inflorescences, clustered at the nodes and towards the ends of the branches. The pale brown pods contain 5-10 elliptical, flattened green seeds and are {{convert|5|–|19|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, straight, flat and rather papery, the segments are mostly longer than they are wide, often breaking up to form small clusters of segments each containing an individual seed. As the pods mature they change colour from green to pale greyish brown.<ref name = agroforestry/>

[[File:Natal Fever Tree (5045324678).jpg|thumb|left|Flowers]]

Fever trees are fast growing and short lived.  They have a tendency to occur as single-aged stands, and are subject to stand-level diebacks that have been variously attributed to elephants, water tables, and synchronous senescence.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Western, D.  |author2=C. Van Praet  |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Cyclical changes in the habitat and climate of an East African ecosystem| journal = Nature | volume = 241| pages = 104–106| year = 1973 |doi= 10.1038/241104a0 |issue= 5385}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Young, T.P.  |author2=W.K. Lindsay |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Role of even-aged population structure in the disappearance of ''Acacia xanthophloea'' woodlands| journal = African Journal of Ecology | volume = 26| pages = 69–72| year = 1988 |doi= 10.1111/j.1365-2028.1988.tb01130.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Ruess, R.W.  |author2=F.L. Walter  |lastauthoramp=yes | title = The impact of large herbivores on the Seronera woodlands, Serengeti National Park, Tanzania| journal = African Journal of Ecology | volume = 28| pages = 259–275| year = 1990 |doi= 10.1111/j.1365-2028.1990.tb01161.x |issue= 4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author= Mills, A.J. | title = The role of salinity and sodicity in the dieback of ''Acacia xanthophloea'' in Ngorongoro Caldera, Tanzania| journal = African Journal of Ecology | volume = 44| pages = 61–71| year = 2006 |doi= 10.1111/j.1365-2028.2006.00616.x}}</ref>

==Etymology==
The name ''xanthophloea'' is derived from [[Greek language|Greek]] and means "yellow bark" (ξανθός "yellow, golden"; φλοιός "bark"). The common name, ''fever tree'', comes from its tendency to grow in swampy areas: early European settlers in the region noted that [[malaria|malarial fever]] was contracted in areas with these trees. It is now understood that malarial fever is spread by [[mosquito]]s living in the swampy areas that often support this tree species, and not  by the tree species itself.<ref>[http://www.plantzafrica.com/plantab/acaciaxanth.htm ''Vachellia xanthophloea'' (as ''Acacia xanthophloea'') entry at PlantZAfrica.com]</ref>

==In popular culture==
These trees are immortalized by [[Rudyard Kipling]] in one of his ''[[Just So Stories]]'', "[[The Elephant's Child]]", wherein he repeatedly refers to "the great grey-green, greasy [[Limpopo River]], all set about with fever-trees."<ref>"[http://www.boop.org/jan/justso/elephant.htm The Elephant's hild]</ref>

==Shamanic usage==
This tree has been used for thousands of years by African tribes as a [[divination]] tool. Bark from this tree and four other herbs including ''[[Silene undulata|Silene capensis]]'' (African dream root) and ''[[Oneirogen|Synaptolepis kirkii]]'' are boiled into a brew. This is taken to induce lucid dreams, which they call "white paths". Before going to sleep a question is asked that will be answered in their dreams. Medicinally, the roots and a powder made from bark stripped from the trunk are used as an emetic and as a [[Preventive healthcare|prophylactic]] against malaria.<ref name = agroforestry/>

==Ecology==
''Vachellia xanthophloea'' is found growing near swamps, riverine forests or on lake shores, in semi-evergreen bush land and woodland where there is a high groundwater table. In seasonally flooded areas it often forms dense single species stands.<ref name = agroforestry/>

The leaves and pods are used to provide food for livestock while the young branches and foliage are eaten by [[African elephant]]s while [[giraffe]] and [[vervet monkey]]s eat the pods and leaves. The flowers are used for foraging by bees and provides favoured nesting sites for birds. Like other acacias and [[Fabaceae]] it is a nitrogen fixer, so improves soil fertility.<ref name = agroforestry/> The gum is part of the diet of the [[Senegal bushbaby]] (''Gallinago senegalensis'') especially in the dry season.<ref name = Kingdom>{{cite book | first1 = Jonathan | last1 = Kingdon | first2 = David | last2 = Happold | first3 = Mike | last3 = Hoffmann | first4 = Meredith | last4 = Happold | first5 = Jan | last5 = Kalina | year = 2013 | title = Mammals of Africa: Volumes I-6 | publisher =  A & C Black | ISBN = 978-1408122570}}</ref>

[[Butterflies]] recorded as feeding on ''Vachellia xanthophloea'' in Kenya included the Kikuyu ciliate blue (''[[Anthene kikuyu]]''),  Pitman's hairtail (''[[Anthene pitmani]]''), common ciliate blue (''[[Anthene definita]]''), African babul blue (''[[Azanus jesous]]''), Victoria's bar (''[[Spindasis victoriae]]'') and common zebra blue (''[[Leptotes pirithous]]'').  In addition 30 species of larger [[moth]]s have been recorded as feeding on this tree.<ref name = Agassiz>{{cite journal | last1 = Agassiz | first1 = David J.L. | last2 = Harper | first2 = David M. | year = 2009 | title = The Macrolepidoptera Fauna of Acacia in the Kenyan Rift Valley (Part 1) | url = http://www.troplep.org/TLR/19-1/Agassiz-Harper.pdf | journal = Trop. Lepid. Res | volume = 19 | issue = 1 | pages = 4–8}}</ref>

==Other uses==
''Vachellia xanthophloea'' are planted next to dams and streams on farms to control soil erosion, as a live fence or hedge and in ornamental planting for shade and shelter in amenity areas. ''Vachellia xanthophloea'' is often planted as a source of firewood, but its gummy sap leaves a thick, black, tarlike residue when burnt. The valuable timber of ''Vachellia xanthophloea'' is pale reddish brown with a hard, heavy texture, and, because it is liable to crack, it should be seasoned before use. The timber is used to make poles and posts.<ref name = agroforestry/>

==Invasive species==
In [[Queensland]] ''Vachellia xanthophlea'' is a prohibited invasive plant under the Biosecurity Act 2014 under which it must not be given away, sold, or released into the environment without a permit. The act further requires that all sightings of ''Vachellia xanthophlea'' are to be reported to the appropriate authorities within 24 hours and that within Queensland everyone is obliged to take all reasonable and practical steps to minimise the risk of ''Vachellia xanthophlea'' spreading until they have received advice from an authorised officer.  Although so far, it has only been found in a few gardens and not in the "wild".<ref name = "Queensland Government">{{cite web | url =  https://www.business.qld.gov.au/industry/agriculture/species/invasive-plants/restricted/yellow-fever-tree | title = Yellow fever tree | accessdate = 13 October 2016 | publisher = The State of Queensland}}</ref> It is also a "declared pest" in [[Western Australia]].<ref name = Acacia>{{cite web | url = https://www.agric.wa.gov.au/declared-plants/acacia-declared-pest | title = Acacia: declared pest | accessdate = 13 October 2016 | publisher = [[Government of Western Australia]]}}</ref>

'''''Voacanga africana''''' is a small tropical [[Africa]]n tree that grows to 6m in height. It has leaves that are up to 30 cm in length, and the tree produces yellow or white flowers, which become berries with yellow seeds.

== Uses ==

[[File:Voacangine.svg|thumb|Chemical structure of voacangine]]
[[File:Voacamine chemical structure.png|thumb|Chemical structure of voacamine]]

The bark and seeds of the tree are used in [[Ghana]] as a [[poison]], [[stimulant]], [[aphrodisiac]], and ceremonial [[Psychedelic drug|psychedelic]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} These effects are due to the presence of a complex mixture of [[ibogaine|iboga alkaloid]]s such as [[voacangine]], [[voacamine]], [[vobtusine]], [[amataine]], [[akuammidine]], [[tabersonine]], [[coronaridine]] and [[vobtusine]].

=== Medicinal uses ===

A number of these compounds have pharmaceutical uses. <ref>[http://www.erowid.org/plants/voacanga_africana/voacanga_africana_info1.shtml Review of Voacanga africana taxonomy, phytochemistry, ethnobotany and pharmacology.]</ref>{{Verify credibility|date=March 2012}} Of particular pharmaceutical interest is [[voacangine]], which is a common precursor in the semi-synthesis of the anti-addiction medication [[ibogaine]]. Small amounts of ibogaine are found in ''Voacanga Africana'' root bark but not in sufficient quantity to have much medicinal effect.{{Verify credibility|date=January 2015}}

[[Species]] include:<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ildis.org/LegumeWeb?version~10.01&genus~Xanthocercis&species~ | title = ILDIS LegumeWeb entry for ''Xanthocercis'' | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | website = International Legume Database & Information Service | publisher = Cardiff School of Computer Science & Informatics | accessdate = 30 January 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/splist.pl?12934 | title = GRIN species records of ''Xanthocercis'' | author = [[USDA]], [[Agricultural Research Service|ARS]], National Genetic Resources Program | date = | website = [[Germplasm Resources Information Network]]—(GRIN) [Online Database] | publisher = [[Henry A. Wallace Beltsville Agricultural Research Center|National Germplasm Resources Laboratory]], Beltsville, Maryland | accessdate = 30 January 2014 }}</ref>

*''[[Xanthocercis madagascariensis]]'' <small>Baill.</small> - [[Madagascar]]<ref>GRIN Taxonomy for Plants: [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?436681 Xanthocercis madagascariensis]</ref>
*''[[Xanthocercis rabiensis]]'' <small>Maesen</small><ref>PlantSystematics.org: [http://biopl-a-181.plantbio.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/dol/dol_terminal.pl?taxon_name=Xanthocercis&rank=genus&classif_id=0 Xanthocercis]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
*''[[Xanthocercis zambesiaca]]'' <small>([[John Gilbert Baker|Baker]]) Dumaz-le-Grand</small> (Mashatu tree) - [[Malawi]], [[Mozambique]], [[South Africa]], [[Zambia]] and [[Zimbabwe]]<ref>GRIN Taxonomy for Plants: [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?101974 Xanthocercis zambesiaca]</ref>

Members of this genus accumulate hydroxy[[pipecolic acid]]s and [[iminosugar]]s in their leaves.<ref name="Cardoso5">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kite GC, Cardoso D, Lewis GP, Zartman CE, de Queiroz LP, Veitch NC | year = 2015 | title = Monomethyl ethers of 4,5-dihydroxypipecolic acid from ''Petaladenium urceoliferum'': Enigmatic chemistry of an enigmatic legume | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031942215000928 | journal = Phytochem. | volume = 116 | issue =  | pages = 198–202 | pmid = 25817832 | doi = 10.1016/j.phytochem.2015.02.026}}</ref>

'''''Xylopia aethiopica''''' is an [[evergreen]], aromatic tree, of the [[Annonaceae]] family that can grow up to 20m high. It is a native to the lowland rainforest and moist fringe forests in the [[savanna]] zones of [[Africa]].

The dried fruits of ''X. aethiopica'' ([[grains of Selim]]) are used as a spice and an [[herbal medicine]].

==Etymology==
''Xylopia'' is a compression from Greek ''ξυλον πικρον'' (''xylon pikron'') meaning "bitter wood". The second part of the plant's binomial name, ''aethiopica'', refers to the origin of the tree, in Ethiopia, though currently it grows most prominently as a crop in [[Ghana]].<ref name=worldagroforestry/>

==Distribution==
''Xylopia aethiopica'' grows in [[Tropical Africa]].  It is present in rain forests, especially near the coast. It also grows in riverine and fringing forest, and as a pioneer species in arid [[savanna]] regions.<ref name=ville-ge>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ville-ge.ch/musinfo/bd/cjb/africa/details.php?langue=an&id=6515 |title=Xylopia aethiopica (Dunal) A.Rich. |accessdate=1 January 2013 |date=16 April 2007 |work=African Plant Database |publisher=[[Conservatoire et Jardin botaniques de la Ville de Genève]]}}</ref>

This species is present in the following countries:
{|
|-
| valign="top" |
* [[Angola]]<ref name=ville-ge/><ref name=congotrees>{{Cite web |url=http://congotrees.rbge.org.uk/species/details/xylopia-aethiopica |title=An introduction to the trees from the North of the Republic Congo |accessdate=1 January 2013 |year=2011 |publisher=Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh |author=Harris, D.J., Moutsamboté J.-M., Kami, E., Florence, J., Bridgewater, S. & Wortley, A.H.}}</ref>
* [[Benin]]

==Uses==
{{main|Grains of Selim}}

''Xylopia aethiopica'' is used extensively in construction, African cuisine and [[traditional medicine]].

The plant's [[bark]] is used to make doors and partitions.  The wood is known to be resistant to termite attack and is used in hut construction: posts, scantlings, roof-ridges and joists.  The wood is also used for boat construction: masts, oars, paddles and spars.  In Togo and Gabon, wood was traditionally used to make bows and crossbows for hunters and warriors.<ref name=burkill/>

An infusion of the plant's bark or fruit has been useful in the treatment of [[bronchitis]] and dysenteric conditions, or as a mouthwash to treat toothaches.  It has also been used as a medicine for biliousness and febrile pains.  The bark, when steeped in palm wine, is used to treat asthma, stomach-aches and rheumatism.<ref name=burkill/>

In Senegal, the fruit is used to flavor [[café Touba]], a [[List of coffee beverages|coffee drink]] that is the country's spiritual beverage and the traditional drink of the [[Mouride|Mouride brotherhood]].<ref>{{Cite news |author= BBC Afrique |title=Café Touba, du bonheur plein la tasse |url=http://www.seneweb.com/news/Societe/cafe-touba-du-bonheur-plein-la-tasse_n_74687.html |format=Reprint |publisher= seneweb.com |date= 15 August 2012 |accessdate=1 January 2013|language=fr}}</ref> In the [[Middle Ages]] the fruit was exported to Europe as a ‘pepper.’ 
In the eastern part of Nigeria, the plant's fruit is an essential ingredient in preparation of local soups to aid new mothers in breastfeeding.
It remains an important item of local trade throughout Africa as a spice, and flavouring for food and for medicine. The fruit is sometimes put into jars of water for purification purposes.<ref name=burkill/>

'''''Zanthoxylum atchoum''''' (synonym '''''Fagara atchoum''''') is a forest [[tree]] in the [[Rutaceae]] family that grows in [[Côte d'Ivoire]]'s [[Eastern Guinean forests]]. It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to Côte d'Ivoire where it is threatened by [[habitat loss]].  Waterman assigned ''Z. atchoum'' to this combination after morphological and [[secondary metabolite]] evidence revealed that ''Fagara'' should be subsumed in ''Zanthoxylum''.

==Sources==
* Assi, A. 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/32220/all ''Zanthoxylum atchoum''].   [https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ]  Downloaded on 24 August 2007.

'''''Ziziphus abyssinica''''' is a species of [[shrub]] in the [[Rhamnaceae]] family. 

It is [[Endemism|endemic]] to dryer habitats across tropical [[Africa]], south of the [[Sahel]] and north of the southern African deserts. 

==Description==
''Ziziphus abyssinica'' has distinct pairs of one hooked and one straight thorn, similar to the related southern African ''[[Ziziphus mucronata]]''.

|species = '''''Z. robertsoniana'''''
|binomial = ''Ziziphus robertsoniana''
|binomial_authority = [[Henk Jaap Beentje|Beentje]]<ref name=ipni1>{{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idPlantNameSearch.do?id=987406-1&back_page=%2Fipni%2FeditSimplePlantNameSearch.do%3Ffind_wholeName%3DZiziphus%2Brobertsoniana%26output_format%3Dnormal |title='''Ziziphus roberstoniana Beentje''' |publisher=[[International Plant Names Index|IPNI]]   |accessdate=September 7, 2009}}</ref>
|}}
'''''Ziziphus robertsoniana''''' is a species of [[plant]] in the [[Rhamnaceae]] family.<ref name=iucn>CAMP Workshop, Kenya 1998.  [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34437/all ''Ziziphus robertsoniana''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/34437/all |date=June 27, 2014 }}. [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627000000/http://www.iucnredlist.org |date=June 27, 2014 }}. Downloaded on 24 August 2007.</ref> It is found primarily in [[Kwale]], on the southern coast of [[Kenya]],<ref>Davis Wekesa Barasa, [http://www.krepublishers.com/06-Special%20Volume-Journal/S-T%20&%20T-00-Special%20Volumes/T%20&%20T-SV-01-Africa-Web/T%20&%20T-SV-01-13-141-07-Barasa-D-W/T%20&%20T-SI-13-141-07-Barasa-D-W-Tt.pdf Indigenous Knowledge Systems and Sustainable Development in Africa: Case Study on Kenya], p. 150</ref> and may also be found in [[Tanzania]]. It is threatened by [[habitat loss]].<ref name=iucn />

It was described in 1996 by Henk Jaap Beentje,<ref name=ipni1/><ref name=ipni2>{{ cite web |url=http://www.ipni.org:80/ipni/idAuthorSearch.do?id=12092-1&back_page=%2Fipni%2FeditSimplePlantNameSearch.do%3Ffind_wholeName%3DZiziphus%2Brobertsoniana%26output_format%3Dnormal |title='''Author Details for Beentje''' |publisher=IPNI   |accessdate=September 7, 2009}}</ref> after having been collected by Mrs. Ann Robertson from [[Malindi]], Kenya, in 1983.<ref>{{cite journal |title=A New Species of Ziziphus (Rhamnaceae) from Kenya |author=H. J. Beentje |journal=Kew Bulletin |volume=51 |issue=1 |year=1996 |pages=197–199 |jstor=4118760 |doi=10.2307/4118760}}</ref>

|regnum             = [[Plant]]ae

|binomial           = ''Ziziphus spina-christi''
|binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]])[[René Louiche Desfontaines|Desf.]]
|synonyms =
    {{Plainlist | style = margin-left: 1em; text-indent: -1em; |
*''Rhamnus spina-christi'' <small>L.</small>
    }}
|synonyms_ref = <ref>{{citation
|url=http://www.theplantlist.org/tpl1.1/record/tro-27501041
|title=The Plant List: A Working List of All Plant Species
|accessdate=30 January 2016}}</ref>
}}

'''''Ziziphus spina-christi''''' — known as the '''Christ's Thorn Jujube''' — is an evergreen tree or plant native to northern and tropical [[Africa]], [[Southern Asia|Southern]] and [[Western Asia]]. It is native to the countries [[Chad]], [[Djibouti]], [[Eritrea]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Kenya]], [[Mali]], [[Mauritania]], [[Nigeria]], [[Pakistan]], [[Senegal]], [[Somalia]], [[Tunisia]], [[Turkey]], [[Zimbabwe]]. <ref>http://www.worldagroforestry.org/treedb/AFTPDFS/Zizyphus_spina-christi.PDF</ref>

==Ecology==
In the [[Palestine (region)|region of Palestine]], it grows in valleys up to an elevation of 500 m.<ref>Zohary M. Flora Palaestina. II. Jerusalem: The Israel Academy of Science and Humanities; 1972. pp. 307–308 cited in {{citation|title=The ethnobotany of Christ's Thorn Jujube (Ziziphus spina-christi) in Israel|author1=Amots Dafni |author2=Shay Levy |author3=Efraim Lev  |last-author-amp=yes |pmc=1277088 | pmid=16270941|doi=10.1186/1746-4269-1-8 |volume=1 |year=2005 |journal=J Ethnobiol Ethnomed |pages=8}}</ref> The ripe fruits are edible.<ref>[http://www.beesfordevelopment.org/info/info/flora/christs-thorn-ziziphus-sp.shtml ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100424201940/http://www.beesfordevelopment.org/info/info/flora/christs-thorn-ziziphus-sp.shtml |date=April 24, 2010 }}</ref>

==Cultural and religious references==
In [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] a hundred years ago it was called ''[[Sidrat al-Muntaha|sidr]]'' (associated with the [[Sidrat al-Muntaha|Lote-trees]] of the [[Koran]]) and was common in the [[Jordan Valley (Middle East)|Jordan Valley]] and around [[Jerusalem]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Illustrated Bible Dictionary and Treasury of Biblical History, Biography, Geography, Doctrine, and Literature: With Numerous Illustrations and Important Chronological Tables and Maps. |author=[[Matthew George Easton|Easton, M.G., M.A., D.D.]] |year=1893 |location=London, Edinburgh and New York |publisher=T. Nelson and Sons |page=688 |url= |quote=«It overruns a great part of the Jordan valley.» p.174. Easton argues that the spina-christi is too brittle to be bent into a crown. He suggests another local plant which he says is called «nabk». |accessdate= }}</ref> There were some folklore traditions that said the trees were protected by benevolent spirits or dead saints ([[Wali|''weli'']]). By some traditions, it was the tree from which Jesus' [[crown of thorns]] was made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flowersinisrael.com/Ziziphusspina-christi_page.htm |title=Ziziphus spina-christi |publisher=Flowersinisrael.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-09}}</ref> [[Matthew George Easton|Easton]] argues that the spina-christi is too brittle to be bent into a crown, and suggests another local plant which he says is called "[[nabq|nabk]]"<ref>[[Matthew George Easton|Easton, M.G., M.A., D.D.]] (1893) 'Illustrated Bible Dictionary and Treasury of Biblical History, Biography, Geography, Doctrine, and Literature With Numerous Illustrations and Important Chronological Tables and Maps.'' T. Nelson and Sons, London, Edinburgh and New York. p.174 </ref>
